Personal and business papers of the Barbour and Johnson families of Orange County, including correspondence, pamphlets, newspapers, maps, speeches, documents, reports and the correspondence of James Barbour of Barboursville, Orange County dealing mainly with his official business while Governor of Virginia (1812), Secretary of War (1825), and Minister to England (1828). Some of the letters discuss the sale of slaves. Also included is a ledger listing the working hands and the sales of slaves for 1816-40.
(Acc. 1486)
Guide available at http://ead.lib.virginia.edu/vivaead/published/uva-sc/vivadoc.pl?file=viu02700.xml

div2.head: 196. BARNES FAMILY PAPERS
div2.p:
76 items, 1775-1873
Correspondence and business papers relating to this Lynchburg family, consisting mainly of letters from Charles F. Barnes and Edward Barnes, Confederate soldiers, to their mother, Mrs. R. A. Barnes. Two letters from Charles Barnes describe a race riot in west Florida in 1865. The papers contain a farm account book, 1795-1799, of Richard Dabney, including list of slave births for the period 1747-1787.
(Acc. 4444)

div2.head: 196a. BARNHART FAMILY PAPERS
div2.p:
ca. 790 items, 1832-1963
A collection of papers, correspondence, business and legal, and topical, pertaining chiefly to the Barnhart family of Augusta County, Virginia. The business and legal papers include two documents mentioning slaves. The first, an appraisement of the estate of G[eorge] Barnhart in the Business Papers of the Barnhart Family, ca. 1850, lists five slaves and their value; the second, a deed dated 1883 March 20, mentions slaves once held by Catherine (Barnhart) Cullen.
(Acc. 11264)
Guide available at http://ead.lib.virginia.edu/vivaead/published/uva-sc/vivadoc.pl?file=viu01311.xml

div2.head: 197. JANIE PORTER BARRETT DAY NURSERY PAPERS
div2.p:
ca. 75 items, 1943-48
Minutes, records, correspondence, and documents of this day nursery for black children in Charlottesville.
(Acc. 3283)
Guide available at http://ead.lib.virginia.edu/vivaead/published/uva-sc/vivadoc.pl?file=viu01864.xml

div2.head: 198. BARRINGER FAMILY PAPERS
div2.p:
ca. 2,800 items, 1828-1963
Correspondence, essays, and genealogical material of this Albemarle County and North Carolina family, principally of Paul Brandon Barringer. Two letters refer to the sale, price, and investment value of slaves and to the inclusion of slaves as part of a dowry. Numerous letters, essays, news clippings, and printed monographs by Paul B. Barringer et al. address the "Negro question." Included are two letters from Booker T. Washington.
(Acc. 2588, etc.)
Guide available at http://ead.lib.virginia.edu/vivaead/published/uva-sc/vivadoc.pl?file=viu00575.xml

div2.head: 198a. PAUL BARRINGER LETTERS
div2.p:
5 items, 1902
Barringer received letters from Edwin Alderman concerning the University of Virginia, from Booker T. Washington concerning race relations and from Theodore Roosevelt.
(Acc. 5438)

div2.head: 199. BARRON, WARING, AND BAYLOR FAMILY PAPERS
div2.p:
ca. 1,300 items, ca. 1820-1900
Business and personal papers of these Essex County families including papers of Samuel Barron, CSN. Scattered references to slavery include an October 27, 1862, letter describing the escape of nine blacks impressed for work and a November 2, 1860, letter describing differences in slave prices between Gloucester and Richmond.
(Acc. 10314)

div2.head: 200. WILLIAM TAYLOR BARRY LETTERBOOK
div2.p:
1 item, 1785-1835
This letterbook of the Kentucky statesman and postmaster general mentions African Americans on pages 25, 50, 72, 94, 123, 141, and 157. Most of the references are fleeting, but one, a letter of August 9, 1832, describes an epidemic of cholera among slaves.
(Acc. 2569)

div2.head: 200a. JOHN S. BATTLE JR. PAPERS
div2.p:
208 items, 1955-59
Papers pertaining to Battle in his capacity as Charlottesville, Va., City Attorney and attorney for the Charlottesville School Board. The collection consists chiefly of clippings regarding integration, segregation and the closing of the Charlottesville, Va., schools, 1958-1959.
(Acc. 11384)
Guide available at http://ead.lib.virginia.edu/vivaead/published/uva-sc/vivadoc.pl?file=viu01304.xml

div2.head: 201. BAYLOR FAMILY PAPERS
div2.p:
ca. 1,600 items, ca. 1760-1905
Correspondence and other papers of this New Market, Caroline County, family. An October 2, 1804, letter from David Morrow to John Baylor says that Baylor's servant Ned wanted to have money paid directly to him for work done rather than through Baylor. There are references in the business and legal papers to slavery; an 1865 farm account book contains entries entitled "Servants Accounts."
(Acc. 2257)
Guide available at http://ead.lib.virginia.edu/vivaead/published/uva-sc/vivadoc.pl?file=viu00032.xml

div2.head: 202. BAYLOR FAMILY PAPERS
div2.p:
ca. 300 items, ca. 1750-1850
Legal and business papers of this Rockingham County family. A number of the documents pertain to slavery, including a December 1793 deed of manumission for the slaves of William Ball of Culpeper
County and a manumission document dated January 12, 1801, for a slave named Milly belonging to Jacob Parrot of Shenandoah County. Other documents pertain to the work roles of slaves.
(Acc. 9732-c)
Guide available at http://ead.lib.virginia.edu/vivaead/published/uva-sc/vivadoc.pl?file=viu03953.xml

div2.head: 203. RICHARD BAYLOR FAMILY PAPERS
div2.p:
ca. 100 items, 1662-1867, microfilm (M-2272)
Personal, business, and legal papers of this Essex County family. The 1810-15 medical accounts of William Waring to Alexander Somervail record the treatment of slaves. An 1844-49 journal of Robert P. Waring has very good year-by-year evaluations slaves at a number of his plantations, including Edenatta, Glencairn, Thomas Neck, Greenfield, and Port Micon.
(Acc. 6056)

div2.head: 203a. BEDFORD COUNTY ESCAPED SLAVE LIST
div2.p:
1 item, 1864
The lists gives the names of the slave holders; whether the slaves were owned or hired; the number, ages, names and sex of the slaves; and their date of escape. All those listed fled on the 17th and 18th of June 1864, the days of Union General David Hunter's skirmishes with Jubal Early at Lynchburg.
(Acc. 11820)

div2.head: 204. BELL FAMILY PAPERS
div2.p:
ca. 200 items, ca. 1790-1880, microfilm (M-1313)
Business and legal papers of this Augusta County family. Slave documents include depositions attesting to the sale of slaves from John Bell's estate and a public sale notice of a superannuated female slave to be cared for by the lowest bidder. In a November 21, 1831, letter describing a wedding, the writer reported that she had heard that at the celebration the groom "left a pack of white people to wait on a pack of Negroes."
(Acc. 6688)

div2.head: 205. BERKELEY FAMILY PAPERS
div2.p:
ca. 20,000 items, ca. 1653-1930
Personal, business, and legal papers of this family of Barn Elms, Middlesex County; Aldie, Loudoun County; and Albemarle County. Scattered throughout are overseers' reports, accounts of slave expenses, slave lists, and bills of sale for slaves.
(Acc. 38-113)
Guide available at http://ead.lib.virginia.edu/vivaead/published/uva-sc/vivadoc.pl?file=viu01015.xml

div2.head: 205a. BERKELEY PLANTATION LEDGER
div2.p:
1 item, 1839-1877
Account and ledger book from Berkeley Plantation, Virginia, is divided into four sections: Berkeley Fishery, 1839-1845; Farm worker entries, 1876-1877; harvest records, 1843-1844; and accounts for the sale of corn, 1862. The fishery records include entries for money received and paid for workers including slave and free hands. Loose in the volume is a slave pass for "Joe," n.d.
(Acc. 11260)
Guide available at http://ead.lib.virginia.edu/vivaead/published/uva-sc/vivadoc.pl?file=viu01347.xml

div2.head: 206. GEORGE S. BERNARD DIARIES
div2.p:
5 items, 1858-84, microfilm (M-1680)
Diaries of this Petersburg lawyer contain an entry for March 22, 1859, about the legal status of whites, African Americans, and Indians in Virginia.
(Acc. 7745-a)

div2.head: 206a. BIG STONE GAP AND TACOMA, VIRGINIA PHOTOGRAPHS
div2.p:
15 items, 1890 and n.d.
Photographs of scenes from the area include a logging crew with African American laborers and African American railroad workers.
(Acc. 11211)
Guide available at http://ead.lib.virginia.edu/vivaead/published/uva-sc/vivadoc.pl?file=viu01326.xml

div2.head: 206b. W.E. BIBB PAPERS
div2.p:
18,250 items, 1830-1940.
Papers of the Louisa County lawyer,W. E. Bibb and other Louisa County families. There are a number of references to African Americans including the mention of a strike by African-American workers at the brick works (1891 Sep 14); African-American tobacco sellers (1899 Feb 14); reference to a lynching of African-Americans at Clifton Forge, Virginia, probably the participants in the riot of 1891; the witness of an ex-slave, Robert Barret, to the Union sentiments of the father of James G. Boxley (1899 Apr 3); and the application for payment for services rendered the Union under General Philip Sheridan for three months by African-American John Wallace (1895 Nov 25).
(Acc. 4171)
Guide available at http://ead.lib.virginia.edu/vivaead/published/uva-sc/viu00045.xml.frame

div2.head: 206c. BIRCKHEAD FAMILY PAPERS
div2.p:
ca. 230 items, 1827-1950
Correspondence, financial and legal papers, certificates and diplomas, photographs, and miscellaneous material pertaining to the Birckhead family of Albemarle County Virginia. Included are references to African Americans such as the December 1845 estate division between Mildred Birckhead and her son Edward F. Birckhead dividing the estate of her husband Thomas Birckhead along with slaves Anderson, Frances, Richard, and Thomas.
(Acc. 10667-a)
Guide available at http://ead.lib.virginia.edu/vivaead/published/uva-sc/vivadoc.pl?file=viu01762.xml

div2.head: 207. BLACK VOTERS, LIST OF, CHARLOTTESVILLE
div2.p:
1 item, 1900
List of black voters by ward.
(Acc. 9077)

div2.head: 207a. WILLIAM H. BLACKFORD DIARY
div2.p:
1 item, 1856
The entry for February 20 describes cruelty to three young female slaves by owner Mrs. James M. Boyd of Lynchburg.
(Acc. 4763)

div2.head: 207b. LAUNCELOT MINOR BLACKFORD PAPERS
div2.p:
99 items, 1832-1865
Papers of Launcelot Minor Blackford primarily consisting of Civil War letters from Blackford to his parents while at the Military School at the University of Virginia. Also included is a notebook, 1832, containing Mary Berkeley Minor Blackford's essay, Notes Illustrative of the Wrongs of Slavery.
(Acc. 5088)

div2.head: 208. BLACKWELL FAMILY PAPERS
div2.p:
15 items, ca. 1840-48
Personal correspondence of Elizabeth Blackwell and family members of Fauquier County. There is some mention of slaves, such as a letter of June 22, n.y., from Octavia noting that a slave tried to get away in Cincinnati as they were going to Missouri and a letter of June 30, n.y., from Sarah T. Buckner who wanted to collect on a loan so that she could buy a slave's husband and send them both west.
(Acc. 38-143-b)
Guide available at http://ead.lib.virginia.edu/vivaead/published/uva-sc/vivadoc.pl?file=viu03842.xml

div2.head: 209. ELIZABETH C. BLAETTERMAN LETTER
div2.p:
1 item, 1860
A letter from this Kentucky woman concerning the freeing of her slaves.
(Acc. 799)

div2.head: 209a. JOHN T. BLAKE PAPERS
div2.p:
166 items, 1842-89
Correspondence and business papers of itinerant dentist Dr. John T. Blake of Greenbrier County, West Virginia. Included is a letter from B. S. Brooke to My Dear Friend dated Nov. 14, 1859 from Staunton, Virginia discussing the John Brown raid at Harper's Ferry. Brooke writes There is considerable excitement here in reference to this insurrection. Many persons are selling and sending their negros [sic] to the South. (Acc. 8975)
Guide available at http://ead.lib.virginia.edu/vivaead/published/uva-sc/vivadoc.pl?file=viu02249.xml

div2.head: 210. BLAND-RUFFIN PAPERS
div2.p:
ca. 100 items, ca. 1740-1865
Includes letters of Theodorick Bland and Edmund Ruffin. A June 1863 letter to Ruffin from Charleston, South Carolina, mentions that Colonel Heyward's slaves had burned down his residence and run off.
(Acc. 3026)
Guide available at http://ead.lib.virginia.edu/vivaead/published/uva-sc/vivadoc.pl?file=viu03293.xml

div2.head: 211. THOMAS S. BOCOCK PAPERS
div2.p:
ca. 3000 items, 1760-1897
Correspondence, financial and legal papers, ledgers, and speeches of Bocock and the Bocock, Thornhill, Christian, Stephens, Flood, Patteson, and Diuguid families of Buckingham and Appomattox counties. Among the subjects discussed are slavery, abolition, the antebellum South, and the use of slaves on military fortifications. Included is a minute book of the New Hope Baptist Church, Augusta County, with many references to African Americans.
(Acc. 10612)
Guide available at http://ead.lib.virginia.edu/vivaead/published/uva-sc/vivadoc.pl?file=viu02720.xml

div2.head: 211a. RICHARD F. BOHN CIVIL WAR LETTERS
div2.p:
24 items, 1862-65
A Union private in Co. H., 205th Pennsylvania Infantry Regiment writes from the battlefields of Virginia, primarily from a camp near Petersburg, to his parents and sister. Included are letters about Bohn's obtaining lodging in a African American family's shanty after becoming lost (October 16, 1864), and the presence of African American soldiers and arrest of a African American Union soldier for killing a Confederate soldier (November 24, 1864).
(Acc. 11418)
Guide available at http://ead.lib.virginia.edu/vivaead/published/uva-sc/vivadoc.pl?file=viu01246.xml

div2.head: 211b. BLAIR BOLLING PAPERS
div2.p:
160 items, 1810-1908, microfilm (M-661)
Journal of his travels, 1810-39, through Virginia, mentioning the University of Virginia, Jefferson, funeral of John Randolph, his journeys by boat through various canals, the Norfolk navy yard, a trip to New York in 1822, etc. and a book of memorandums relating to the Plantations, 1827-38, a farm journal listing slaves and produce, chiefly tobacco and wheat.
(Acc. 11418)

div2.head: 211c. BONDURANT-MORRISON PAPERS
div2.p:
ca. 15000 items, 1787-1935
Contains references to the hiring of slaves; farm book, 1841-47. Also ledgers contain references to slaves; daybook, 1834-39; account book index, 1824, ledger of Thomas Bondurant, 1847-60.
(Acc. 3918)
Guide available at http://ead.lib.virginia.edu/vivaead/published/uva-sc/vivadoc.pl?file=viu00044.xml

div2.head: 212. BONNER, MERCER, AND PELHAM FAMILY PAPERS
div2.p:
ca. 200 items, 1762-1888
Correspondence, financial records, wills, and genealogical data of the
Bonner family of Greene County, Ohio, and the Mercer and Pelham families of Virginia, who had intermarried into the Bonner family. Included are emancipation documents and correspondence concerning Frederick Bonner's slave Dick.
(Acc. 10142)

div2.head: 213. ARMISTEAD L. BOOTHE PAPERS
div2.p:
ca. 11,000 items, 1948-69
Papers of this delegate and state senator from Alexandria. There are correspondence and material about Boothe's attempts as a state senator to keep the public schools in Virginia open during the integration crisis in the 1950s.
(Acc. 8319)

div2.head: 214. JAMES WOODBERRY BORDEN DIARY
div2.p:
1 item, 1837-38, microfilm (M-1223)
Written by this Essex County man while living in Charles City County, this diary contains comments on African Americans in Virginia.
(Acc. 5727)

div2.head: 215. WALTER BOWIE JOURNALS
div2.p:
2 items, 1848-61
Entries for 1860-61 by this Westmoreland County planter record the hiring and renting of slaves, e.g., January 2, 7, 14, 17, and 30, 1861.
(Acc. 8528)

div2.head: 216. SARAH PATTON BOYLE PAPERS
div2.p:
ca. 10,000 items, 1950-70
Personal, legal, and business papers of this Charlottesville woman who was involved in school integration and other civil rights issues in central Virginia in the 1950s and 1960s. Included is correspondence with African American leaders such as Ralph Abernathy and Martin Luther King.
(Acc. 8003)

http://www.lib.virginia.edu/harrison/exhibits/journeys/on-the-road/fire-night.html
Cross burned on the lawn of Sarah Patton Boyle, 29 August 1956
Guide available at http://ead.lib.virginia.edu/vivaead/published/uva-sc/vivadoc.pl?file=viu02095.xml

div2.head: 217. WILLIAM STANLEY BRAITHWAITE COLLECTION
div2.p:
ca. 4,700 items, 1905-60
Correspondence of this noted African American poet, critic, and anthologist, consisting mainly of letters written to Braithwaite in connection with his anthologies.
(Accs. 6787 & 8990)
Guide to 6787 available at http://ead.lib.virginia.edu/vivaead/published/uva-sc/vivadoc.pl?file=viu02965.xml

div2.head: 218. BRAXTON FAMILY PAPERS
div2.p:
ca. 60,000 items, 1785-1911
Primarily the papers of Allen Caperton Braxton, a Staunton attorney, with a very small group of papers of the Braxton family from Chericoke, King William County. Of particular importance are the notes and correspondence of Allen Caperton Braxton when he was a member of the Virginia Constitutional Convention of 1901-2 that disfranchised the African American voter.
(Acc. 3329, -a)

div2.head: 218a. ASSOCIATES OF THE LATE DR. THOMAS BRAY PAPERS
div2.p:
6 items, 1690-1808, microfilm (M-7a & 7b)
Papers from the manuscripts of the Society for the Propagation of the Gospel, especially relative to the establishment of African American schools in Williamsburg, Va. and Annapolis, Md.
(Acc. 669)

div2.head: 219. BRECKINRIDGE FAMILY PAPERS
div2.p:
ca. 1,000 items, ca. 1725-1925 , microfilm (M-2246-48)
Business, legal, and personal papers of this family of Grove Hill, Botetourt County. Included are many references to slavery, such as a November 29, 1825, letter from Mrs. M. Gilmer to Emma describing the murder of Captain John Edgar and the apprehension and trial of a African American man, Harry; an August 28, 1831, letter from William Gilmer to Peachy Gilmer mentioning trouble with African American in Albemarle County and the insurrection in Southampton County; and an October 3, 1831, letter from Emma at Grove Hill mentioning a rumor that Nat Turner passed through Botetourt County.
(Acc. 9846)

div2.head: 220. JAMES BRECKINRIDGE PAPERS
div2.p:
ca. 440 items, 1780-1912
Personal papers of this Grove Hill, Botetourt County, planter and businessman. Many documents pertain to slavery, especially slaves employed at Breckinridge's ironworks, and there is an 1820 letter from a former slave.
(Acc. 10395)

div2.head: 221. BREMO RECESS PAPERS
div2.p:
ca. 3,500 items, ca. 1690-1950
Business and personal papers of the Cocke and Cabell families of Bremo Recess in Fluvanna County. The papers contain a number of references to African Americans and letters of former slaves who had emigrated to Liberia, e.g., Matilda Skipwith to Miss S. F. Cocke, October 1844, and
Matilda Lomax to Miss Sarah Cox, 1853. Included are an 1865 list of slaves at Recess; an 1856 letter from the president of the American Colonization Society, J. H. Latrobe; and an 1823 letter (9513-h) from Ann B. Cocke to Louisiana Cocke about a slave wedding.
(Acc. 9513, etc.)

div2.head: 222. BRITISH ANTISLAVERY COLLECTION
div2.p:
1 item, 1821-87
Included in this bound volume of letters and documents pertaining to the British antislavery movement are a number of letters written by Frederick Douglass.
(Acc. 3846)
Guide available at http://ead.lib.virginia.edu/vivaead/published/uva-sc/vivadoc.pl?file=viu02958.xml

div2.head: 223. BROAD RUN BAPTIST CHURCH MINUTES
div2.p:
1 item, 1762-1859
African American members are noted in the minutes of the congregational meetings of this Fauquier County church, as well as actions taken concerning them.
(Acc. 4305)

div2.head: 224. AUSTIN BROCKENBROUGH PAPERS
div2.p:
1 item, ca. 1780-1840
Papers of this Tappahanock doctor contain a February 7, 1832, letter from Congressman John Jones Roane inquiring on behalf of a third party about the purchase of fifty slaves or more in family units.
(Acc. 38- 157)

div2.head: 224a. AUSTIN BROCKENBROUGH MEDICAL ACCOUNTS AND NOTEBOOK
div2.p:
2 items, ca. 1780-1820
Accounts including entries for personal expenses, i.e., the purchase of foodstuffs, sundries, and household goods, as well as entries for the treatment of his patients, including Revolutionary War soldiers and slaves.
(Acc. 919)

div2.head: 224b. BROCKENBROUGH, LAMB AND RELATED FAUNTLEROY AND SMITH FAMILY PAPERS
div2.p:
ca. 1500 items, 1835-1945
Consists primarily of family papers of the Brockenbrough and Lamb families of the farm known as "Belle Ville" in Warsaw, Richmond County, in the Northern Neck area of Virginia. Of interest are papers regarding the sale of Bay Quarter, a part of Belle Ville, 1897-1899; papers concerning a ferry at Tappahannock, 1899-1907; and papers re the settlement of the estates of Austin Brockenbrough and Lucy Y. Gray both of which contain slave records. Other slave records are found in a Negro and farm ledger, 1842-1860, from James Muse Smith's farms at [Bay and Middle Quarter?] and an account book, 1863-1881, that includes lists of slaves inherited by Willoughby N. Smith from James M. Smith.
(Acc. 10987-a)
Guide available at http://ead.lib.virginia.edu/vivaead/published/uva-sc/vivadoc.pl?file=viu02169.xml

div2.head: 225. ROBERT S. BROOKE PAPERS
div2.p:
100 items, 1792-1927
The collection consists chiefly of correspondence between Brooke and his wife Margaret Lyle Smith Brooke written while he was serving in the General Assembly. Subjects include family and household affairs in Augusta County including slave hiring and "correction" and social and political news from Richmond.
(Acc. 38-137)
Guide available at http://ead.lib.virginia.edu/vivaead/published/uva-sc/vivadoc.pl?file=viu00009.xml

div2.head: 226. BROWN FAMILY PAPERS
div2.p:
3 items, 1781-1903
Genealogical records of this Buckingham County family. The Bible records include birth and death entries for slaves.
(Acc. 4417)

div2.head: 227. BROWN FAMILY PAPERS
div2.p:
18 items, 1811-76
Store ledgers, 1850-1856, of a general store in Culpeper County, Va., with numerous entries for cloth and cloth items, tobacco, and dry goods. Included is a slave bill of sale, 1824, for one month old child.
(Acc. 4117)

div2.head: 228. HENRY JAMES BROWN PAPERS
div2.p:
110 items, ca. 1830-84
Personal correspondence and diary of this Powhatan County painter and farmer who had a farm in Missouri run by an overseer. In a November 4, 1848, letter to Brown, the overseer, L. Weedin, described the health of the slaves and an episode about a runaway brought back to a neighboring farm. There are other scattered references to slaves in Missouri and Virginia. In a diary written on a trip from Virginia to Missouri, probably in 1844, Brown referred often to fears that abolitionists would take his female slave, especially in Cincinnati.
(Acc. 9930)
Guide available at http://ead.lib.virginia.edu/vivaead/published/uva-sc/vivadoc.pl?file=viu02888.xml

div2.head: 228a. MARY ELIZA WARREN BROWN PAPERS
div2.p:
112 items, ca. 1849-1935
Papers pertaining chiefly to the Warren family and other descendants of Robert Nimmo, emigrant from Falkirk, Scotland. Mary Eliza Warren (later Brown), served as a governess to several families in Nelson County and Petersburg, Virginia. Bible records note the births of two slaves, 1862, 1864.
(Acc. 11392)

div2.head: 229. WILLIAM S. BROWN DIARY
div2.p:
3 items, 1843-46, microfilm (M-640)
The diary of this clerk of the court of King George County contains a December 17, 1843, description of a song and prayer meeting in the slave quarters; a January 17, 1844, mention of the murder of one slave by another; an April 12, 1845, record of an attack on Captain John S. Washington by a African American man; and a November 1, 1845, mention of the will of N. H. Hove that freed his slaves and sent them to Africa.
(Acc. 4492)

div2.head: 230. BRUCE FAMILY PAPERS
div2.p:
ca. 14,000 items, 1769-1863
Correspondence, journals, and account books of James Bruce and his son, James Cole Bruce, of Berry Hill, Halifax County. There are lists of slaves, e.g., a November 22, 1849, list and inventory of slaves on the plantation of Messrs. Bruce, Seddon, and Williams and an 1852 "Register of Negroes," plus many entries in the account books and other material relating to slavery.
(Acc. 2692)
Guide available at http://ead.lib.virginia.edu/vivaead/published/uva-sc/vivadoc.pl?file=viu02762.xml

div2.head: 231. BRUNSWICK COUNTY PAPERS
div2.p:
ca. 30 items, 1811-69
Documents and letters, some of which refer to the hiring and leasing of slaves. A December 11, 1824, letter apparently was written by a African American woman in Petersburg attempting to gain some form of recompense for an ancestor, Ned Brandom, who served as a substitute in the Revolutionary War.
(Acc. 3307, -a)

div2.head: 232. BRYAN FAMILY PAPERS
div2.p:
5 items, 1845-65
Annotated listings of the slaves at Eagle Point in Gloucester County.
(Acc. 9822-d)

div2.head: 233. BUCK FAMILY PAPERS
div2.p:
200 items, ca. 1830-60
Correspondence, personal, and business papers of this Winchester family. It is a very good archive of one family's business and personal interests. There is much correspondence about slavery, including October 6 and 27, 1848, letters from a slave hunter, Joseph Kinsel; a November 30, 1848, letter from a runaway slave to his mother requesting that she ask "Master William" to take him back; and a February 1, 1843, letter about a family of slaves afflicted by a serious illness.
(Acc. 4932)

div2.head: 233a. BUCK FAMILY PAPERS
div2.p:
ca. 300 items, ca. 1836-56
Papers of William Mason Buck and the Buck family, chiefly correspondence between members of the Buck, Blakemore, and Bayly families of Virginia, Baltimore, and Missouri -- Letters, 1830s of R.D. Harris describe life in Missouri. Other subjects include land, supplies, the sale and hire of slaves.
(Acc. 6290)

div2.head: 234. BUCKINGHAM COUNTY FREEDMEN'S RECORDS
div2.p:
1 item, 1865-70, microfilm (M-784)
Microfilm copies of the original records in the National Archives.
(Acc. 10154-a)

div2.head: 235. BUCKINGHAM COUNTY TAX BOOK
div2.p:
1 item, 1851 microfilm (M-635)
Tax assessment book kept by John Horsley. Includes taxes based on the number of slaves.
(Acc. 4487)

div2.head: 235a. BUCKINGHAM COUNTY PAPERS
div2.p:
1 item, 1824-1867, microfilm (M-635)
Includes ledger, 1858-1860, of accounts for the Maysville Hotel, Buckingham County, Va., kept by A. Trent Moseley including accounts and inventory of the estate of Rolfe Eldridge, Jr., court clerk for Buckingham County, Va. and a slave bill of sale, 1824, Goochland County, Va.
(Acc. 4490)

div2.head: 235b. HORATIO BUCKTROUT LETTER
div2.p:
1 item, July 14, 1846
Bucktrout's letter to Jordan Powell discusses his knowledge of the recently deceased Godfrey Powell. Bucktrout writes that a woman who is claiming Godfrey Powell's property as his legal wife was never in fact Powell's wife, had always mistreated him, and had long since abandoned him. Bucktrout was writing as the preacher in charge of the African M.E. Church South in Norfolk.
(Acc. 5677)

div2.head: 236. JOHN BUFORD PAPERS
div2.p:
ca. 1,000 items, ca. 1840-60, microfilm (M-2188)
Business, legal, and personal papers of this Bedford County businessman who was engaged in building the Virginia-Tennessee Railroad in 1851-60. Check rolls of the company contain information on hired African American gangs; there are also individual receipts for the hiring of slaves to work on the railroad and a July 15, 1851, letter from Ro. Mitchell to Buford about the work of some of the blacks. Documents dated November 27, 1861, record that two free African American, found guilty of a crime (not stated), were sold and purchased by Buford.
(Acc. 9782)

div2.head: 236a. JOHN T. BUMPASS & GEORGE W. DAVIS PAPERS
div2.p:
ca. 150 items, ca. 1870-90
Documents of these Vernon Mills residents which includs a Louisa County pollbook dated 1875 May 27 and a letter from Thomas F. West to Jack Woolham concerning General [Williams Carter] Wickham and "negro hire" dated 1875 August 27.
(Acc. 9096-b)

div2.head: 236b. BUNCH, CREASE, LEWIS, WARWICK AND RELATED VIRGINIA FAMILIES PAPERS
div2.p:
ca. 1,300 items, ca. 1823-1965
Chiefly genealogical research materials on the families, compiled by Tilghman Howard Bunch of Washington, D.C. There are also letters, and financial, legal, and business papers of these families, especially of the Lewis family of Bath County. An 1831 letter from Charles Cameron Lewis, a student at the University of Virginia from 1825-1826, notes that African American slaves are very valuable property in and around Chickasaw land, and are treated better than those in southern Virginia.
(Acc. 6528-b)
Guide available at http://ead.lib.virginia.edu/vivaead/published/uva-sc/viu03437.xml.frame

div2.head: 237. RICHARD C. BURNET NOTEBOOK
div2.p:
1 item, 1836-65, microfilm (M-39)
A notebook of articles from newspapers based on letters from Burnet discussing slaves, runaways, etc., in Texas.
(Acc. 1288)

div2.head: 238. BURWELL FAMILY PAPERS
div2.p:
ca. 250 items, 1734-1893
Business and personal papers, chiefly those of Colonel Lewis Burwell of Kings Mill near Williamsburg and of the family of Bedford County. A seventeen-page manuscript by William Burwell reviews the economic conditions of African Americans in the South in the 1870s, and a November 1853 letter to C. K. Marshall apparently from William Burwell discusses the relationship of African Americans in southern society. Correspondence in the 1840s and 1850s examines the influence of slavery on national politics.
(Acc. 4400-b)
Guide available at http://ead.lib.virginia.edu/vivaead/published/uva-sc/vivadoc.pl?file=viu02785.xml

div2.head: 239. BURWELL FAMILY PAPERS
div2.p:
170 items, 1761-1845
Business and legal papers of Nathaniel Burwell of Carter's Grove and Carter's Hall in James City County. Many of these concern the estates of William Pasteur and John Paradise. Included are estate appraisals for Pasteur's livestock, slaves, and household and farming implements.
(Acc. 5757-c)
Guide available at http://ead.lib.virginia.edu/vivaead/published/uva-sc/vivadoc.pl?file=viu00194.xml

div2.head: 239a. BUXTON, LEA AND MARSHALL FAMILY PAPERS
div2.p:
3000 items, 1860-1950
Papers of the Buxton, Lea, and Marshall families of Pennsylvania and Virginia. Courtship letters between Joseph Tatnall Lea and Annie Cabeen written during his Civil War service in the 114th Regiment Pennsylvania volunteers discuss among other topics African-American soldiers. The letters of Dr. Harry Taylor Marshall discuss Theodore Roosevelt's lunch for Booker T. Washington and the "disenfranchising of the Negro" in Maryland,
1901. (Acc. 11412)
Guide available at http://ead.lib.virginia.edu/vivaead/published/uva-sc/vivadoc.pl?file=viu01219.xml

div2.head: 240. CABELL FAMILY PAPERS
div2.p:
ca. 500 items, 1727-1875
Business and personal papers of Nicholas Cabell, William Cabell, and Nathaniel Francis Cabell of Buckingham County. An 1844 list details births of slaves; a December 23, 1860, letter from W. C. Scott to Mrs.
Francis Cabell gives permission for a slave to marry; and there is a June 1865 "List of servants at Liberty Hill."
(Acc. 5084)

div2.head: 241. JOSEPH CARRINGTON CABELL PAPERS
div2.p:
ca. 5,000 items, ca. 1730-1920
Business, personal, and political papers of this Amherst (now Nelson) County planter, businessman, and politician. Although much of the collection is political in nature, there are detailed records concerning slavery and plantation life, e.g., March and April 1814 letters reporting raids by the British in which slaves were taken.
(Acc. 38-111, etc.)
Guide available at http://ead.lib.virginia.edu/vivaead/published/uva-sc/vivadoc.pl?file=viu00191.xml

div2.head: 242. WILLIAM D. CABELL PAPERS
div2.p:
ca. 3,600 items, 1806-93
Correspondence and other papers of this Nelson County and Washington, D.C., educator. Scattered throughout are infrequent references to slavery, such as a December 5, 1863, letter from John Fry to Cabell discussing the hiring of slaves; an 1864 list of farm servants; an 1863 valuation of a slave at $3,250 by a committee of freeholders; a September 18, 1863, letter from a slave asking Cabell to keep his wife; an 1864 list of shoes delivered to slaves; and an August 18, 1856, letter from Cabell to Joseph C. Cabell mentioning that a number of slaves had been killed by poisonous brandy.
(Acc. 276, etc.)
Guide available at http://ead.lib.virginia.edu/vivaead/published/uva-sc/vivadoc.pl?file=viu00018.xml

div2.head: 243. GEORGE WASHINGTON CABLE COLLECTION
div2.p:
ca. 100 items, ca. 1865-1920
Letters and manuscripts of this American author. One forty-page manuscript by Cable is entitled "Creole Slave Songs."
(Barrett Library Acc. 7161-g)

div2.head: 243a. CA IRA LEDGER
div2.p:
1 item, 1793-1804
Cumberland County account book containing 74 folios of a ledger, that appears to be of a plantation store. It contains entries for, two African Americans "Aaron" and "Henry," and members of the Baldwin, Bolling, Page, Pollard, Skipwith, and Thornton families.
(Acc. 4747)

div2.head: 244. CALLAWAY FAMILY BIBLE RECORDS
div2.p:
ca. 10 items, ca. 1740-1950
Included in these records of the Campbell and Albemarle counties and Asheville, North Carolina, family is a page listing slave births.
(Acc. 7903)

div2.head: 245. WILLIAM CAMPBELL LETTER
div2.p:
1 item, September 4, 1831
A letter by this Norfolk resident discusses the excitement and confusion in the wake of Nat Turner's revolt. The whites were armed, and many rumors were flying of other alleged slave revolts.
(Acc. 1441)

div2.head: 246. CAPERTON FAMILY PAPERS
div2.p:
ca. 400 items, ca. 1840-95 microfilm (M-2133)
Personal and business papers of the Caperton and allied families from Monroe City, containing few references to slavery, such as two letters from John Caperton in New Orleans to William Caperton in Monroe City, December 4, 1847, and January 2, 1848, in which John empowered William and others to sell all of his Virginia slaves and send him the money.
(Acc. 7482-b)

div2.head: 246a. PHILENA CARKIN COLLECTION
div2.p:
3 items, 1866-1902
The collection contains a bound manuscript journal of this Massachusetts schoolteacher of freedmen in Charlottesville, 1866-75, under the auspices of the American Freedmen's Aid Commission entitled "Reminiscences of my Life and Work among the Freedmen of Charlottesville, Virginia, from March 1st 1866 to July 1st 1875," vol. 1, together with a carte-de-visite portrait, n.d., of Carkin by Charlottesville photographer William Roads, and a copy of her certificate of commission as a teacher of ex-slaves issued by the Eastern Department of the American Freedman's Aid Commission.
(Acc. 11123, -a)
Guide available at http://ead.lib.virginia.edu/vivaead/published/uva-sc/vivadoc.pl?file=viu01395.xml

div2.head: 247. CARLTON PAPERS
div2.p:
13 items, 1801-75
Included is an 1833 slave valuation for this Albemarle County plantation.
(Acc. 38-216)

div2.head: 247a. DR. JAMES CARMICHAEL PAPERS
div2.p:
ca. 675 items, 1816-34
Letters to Dr. Carmichael of Fredericksburg, Virginia requesting medical treatment, prescriptions, and visits. Many of the letters detail treatment of slaves and they are itemized in the on-line guide.
(Acc. 11373)
Guide available at http://ead.lib.virginia.edu/vivaead/published/uva-sc/vivadoc.pl?file=viu01265.xml
Transcriptions and images available at http://carmichael.lib.virginia.edu/

div2.head: 247b. CARPENTER AND WHITE FAMILY PAPERS
div2.p:
280 items, 1836-1965
Consists primarily of private correspondence, legal and financial documents, genealogies and some printed material of the Carpenter and White families of North Garden, Albemarle County, Virginia. Included are an 1844 slave sale, tax in kind estimates and assessments, 1864 and 1865; doctor visits to family and slaves.
(Acc. 11613)
Guide available at http://ead.lib.virginia.edu/vivaead/published/uva-sc/vivadoc.pl?file=viu02094.xml

div2.head: 247c. WALTER CARPENTER LETTERS
div2.p:
11 items, 1888-89
The collection contains letters from Carpenter, University of Virginia to his Aunt Sarah Harvie, and Miss Isobel Harvie, describing his year at the University of Virginia. He mentions touring Washington, D. C., on his journey to Charlottesville, hazing as he is a northerner, the reaction of Carpenter and other students to Benjamin's Harrison's victory in the election of 1888 and African American servants.
(Acc. 15085)

div2.head: 248. CARR FAMILY PAPERS
div2.p:
ca. 1,500 items, 1745-1880
Personal and business papers of the Carr family and George Carr of Albemarle County. Included are references to the emancipation of slaves and an estate evaluation. See items dated November 14, 1830, November 29, 1837, June 14, 1847, and February 13 and April 18, 1854, for emancipated slaves; January 5, 1822, for the separation of slave families; and an 1840 speech. Also included are a photograph of a African American woman (Poore family) and a May 6, 1868, letter about the death of a African American woman.
(Acc. 4869, etc.)

div2.head: 249. CARR AND CARY FAMILY PAPERS
div2.p:
417 items, 1785-1839
Family correspondence between the related members of the Carr, Cary, Randolph, Nicholas, Jefferson, and Stevenson families of Albemarle and Fluvanna counties. There are some scattered references to slavery, such as a December 31, 1806, letter from Peter Carr to Mary Carr informing her of the sale of a slave, Nelly; "the poor creature is so distressed."
(Acc. 1231)
Guide available at http://ead.lib.virginia.edu/vivaead/published/uva-sc/vivadoc.pl?file=viu01145.xml

div2.head: 249a. CARRINGTON FAMILY LETTERS
div2.p:
7 items, 1855-64
Letters to Edward C. Carrington, Eliza Carrington and Virginia Carrington of Virginia. Included is an October 7, 1861, from W.[A.?] Glasgow, Fincastle, Virginia, to Mrs. E.H. Carrington, telling her that he had obtained a restraining injunction to prevent Thom [a slave?] from being taken by the Army.
(Acc. 11173)
Guide available at http://ead.lib.virginia.edu/vivaead/published/uva-sc/vivadoc.pl?file=viu01460.xml

div2.head: 249b. RICHARD WATKINS CARRINGTON PAPERS
div2.p:
ca. 43,000 items, 1880-1933
Personal and professional papers of the corporation lawyer and civic leader, Richard Watkins Carrington of Richmond, Virginia, and the related Davenport Family. Of interest in his professional papers are correspondence with the Inter-Racial Committee, Richmond Urban League for Social Service Among Negroes, securing a charter for a credit union at Hampton Institute and a Richmond segregation ordinance to prohibit African Americans from buying property on majority white blocks.
(Acc. 2705)
Guide available at http://ead.lib.virginia.edu/vivaead/published/uva-sc/vivadoc.pl?file=viu01404.xml

div2.head: 250. CARTER LETTERBOOK
div2.p:
1 item, 1732-82
Letters of John, Charles, and Landon Carter, executors of Robert "King" Carter of Corotoman, in Lancaster County. Mainly business accounts, a series of April 1737 letters discuss the slave trade on the ship Antelope. Other letters discuss the slave trade very thoroughly, such as a May 28, 1737, letter to agents in Liverpool; see also those of September 25, 1737, and August 3, 1738.
(Acc. 4996)

div2.head: 251. CARTER-SMITH PAPERS
div2.p:
ca. 2,700 items, 1726-1870
Materials on the Carter, Coles, Smith, and Nicholas families. Primary interest centers on General Samuel Smith and his son, John Spear Smith of Baltimore, and his daughter Margaret who married Robert Hill Carter of Redlands, Albemarle County. A series of April 1870 letters from A. Drummond in Williamsburg to the Coles family in Albemarle discuss among other things the selling and buying of slaves.
(Acc. 1729)

div2.head: 252. ROBERT "KING" CARTER PAPERS
div2.p:
6 items,1722-43, microfilm (M-570)
The 1722-27 diary, four letterbooks, and the corn book of this
Corotoman, Lancaster County, planter. Extremely good material on slavery in early eighteenth-century Virginia is found throughout. The diary contains many notations in July and August 1727 on the buying and selling of slaves at auction and a mention of boarding a "Negro Ship." The corn book has entries on the amounts of corn paid to slaves. The letterbooks contain slavery information such as an October 10, 1727, letter from Robert Carter to his overseer, Robert Jones, instructing him to cut off the toes of a runaway slave. Also included on the microfilm are the Robert Carter letterbooks at the Virginia Historical Society.
(Acc. 3807)

Diary of Robert King Carter, 1722-1727. Entries for 15 April to 13 June 1726.
http://www.lib.virginia.edu/harrison/exhibits/journeys/under-duress/immigrants-chains.html
Transcriptions of some documents from letterbook available online at: http://www.vcdh.virginia.edu/gos/slaveHolderRecords/yatesLetters.php
Transcriptions of Carter diaries available online: http://etext.lib.virginia.edu/users/berkeley/

div2.head: 252a. JOE CASH PHOTOGRAPH
div2.p:
1 item, n.d.
Sepia photograph of the "colored gentleman of Old Charlottesville," with notes by William Allan Perkins.
(Acc. 5054)

div2.head: 253. JOHN CATLETT FAMILY PAPERS
div2.p:
33 items, 1790-1870
Business, legal, and personal papers of this Port Royal farmer. A number of items concern slavery, such as a February 1, 1782, deed of sale for two slaves and a January 4, 1847, letter from Patrick Catlett to Elizabeth Catlett regarding hiring of slaves.
(Acc. 9398j)

div2.head: 254. RICHARD CAVE LEDGER
div2.p:
1 item, 1735-1855, microfilm (M-548)
This ledger contains some entries on birth and death dates of slaves at Montebello in Orange County.
(Acc. 3527)

div2.head: 255. SAMPSON CEASAR LETTERS
div2.p:
5 items, 1834-35
This freed slave who emigrated to Liberia, Africa, wrote to David S. Haselden and to his former master Henry F. Westfall, both of Buchannon, about his life in Liberia, studies, religious sentiment, and illnesses. He related his impressions of the country and the natives and discussed the possibility of success for the freed slaves in their new home.
(Acc. 10595)
Guide available at http://ead.lib.virginia.edu/vivaead/published/uva-sc/vivadoc.pl?file=viu02800.xml

div2.head: 256. E. G. CHAPMAN FARM JOURNAL
div2.p:
1 item, 1843-51, microfilm (M-638)
The daily record of this Madison County farmer is complete only for 1843 and1851. There are a few entries on slaves and an entry for June 24, 1843, that reads: "went below Bethesda meeting house to examine some Negroes who had been engaged in a riot."
(Acc. 4472)

div2.head: 256a. CHAPMAN ACCOUNT BOOK
div2.p:
1 item, 1838-54, microfilm (M-2333)
Chapman was a Waynesboro constable and later resident of Mt. Sidney. The book was used for personal accounts and memoranda, and inventories of estate sales. Later Chapman used the volume to record marriages and deaths of both whites and African-Americans in the Waynesboro and Mt. Sidney areas.
(Acc. 823)

div2.head: 257. CHARLOTTESVILLE-ALBEMARLE CHAPTER OF THE VIRGINIA COUNCIL ON HUMAN RELATIONS PAPERS
div2.p:
ca. 3,000 items, 1955-70
Working papers of this organization, which include materials on the integration of schools in the Charlottesville-Albemarle area.
(Acc. 9606, etc.)
Guide available at http://ead.lib.virginia.edu/vivaead/published/uva-sc/vivadoc.pl?file=viu02735.xml

div2.head: 257a. CHARLOTTESVILLE DEPARTMENT OF PARKS AND RECREATION PAPERS
div2.p:
ca. 300 items, 1963-86
Correspondence, records and other papers, photographs, and newspaper clippings primarily kept by Nannie Burwell Crow, director of the Charlottesville Department of Recreation for twenty-nine years until her retirement in August 1966. The albums and scrapbooks contain over 300 photographs of events sponsored by the Charlottesville Dept. of Parks and Recreation, including some of events in Washington Park, the city's park for African Americans during the years of segregation.
(Acc. 11347)
Guide available at http://ead.lib.virginia.edu/vivaead/published/uva-sc/vivadoc.pl?file=viu01306.xml

div2.head: 257b. CHARLOTTESVILLE FAIR HOUSING COMMITTEE RECORDS
div2.p:
ca. 1220 items, 1938-1973
This organization was formed in May 1965 "to support and encourage freedom of residence in our community so that all persons, regardless of race, religion or national origin, can obtain the housing they desire and can afford." In addition to information concerning housing for African Americans in Charlottesville, the collection contains items relating to other aspects of race relations and to church social programs within the city.
(Acc. 10355, -a)
Guide available at http://ead.lib.virginia.edu/vivaead/published/uva-sc/vivadoc.pl?file=viu02116.xml
Guide available at http://ead.lib.virginia.edu/vivaead/published/uva-sc/vivadoc.pl?file=viu01425.xml

div2.head: 258. CHARLOTTESVILLE INTERRACIAL COMMISSION PAPERS
div2.p:
ca. 100 items, 1942-43
The minutes and documents, such as constitutions and programs, of this local citywide commission.
(Acc. 3161)
Guide available at http://ead.lib.virginia.edu/vivaead/published/uva-sc/vivadoc.pl?file=viu01048.xml

div2.head: 258a. CHARLOTTESVILLE LETTER
div2.p:
1 item, 1863 March 18
From an unidentified correspondent, who is living temporarily in the Farish House, giving a detailed description of land he has purchased in Texas and closing by noting that the slave "Bob" is constantly misbehavng, ran off from the place where he was hired, goes out at night and has been shot at by the watch, and therefore, will be sold.
(Acc. 13585)

div2.head: 259. CHARLES WADDELL CHESTNUT PAPERS
div2.p:
ca. 2,000 items, 1891-1932, microfilm (M-2235)
Papers in the Western Reserve Historical Society of this African American novelist and short story writer.
(Acc. 7475)

div2.head: 259a. CHESNUT GROVE BAPTIST CHURCH RECORDS
div2.p:
3 items, 1773-1970, microfilm (M-197, 1369 & 1377)
On microfilm, records of this Albemarle County church, 1773-1778, 1792-1811, which include minutes and list of white and African-American members, kept by George Twyman; minutes pertaining to funerals, baptisms, and cases of excommunication, for which some of the reasons given are disorderly conduct, intoxication, adultery, disobedience, and running away from masters; minute books, 1855-1921, which concern recording of members present at meetings, determination of delegates sent to the Albemarle Association meetings; Civil War period entries record deaths of Confederate soldiers and the flight of slaves and entries, 1866, concerning the membership's opposition to the establishment of a Sunday School for the benefit of the African-American members, followed by later entries concerning the combined application of African-American members to leave the church in good standing to establish their own church.
(Acc. 7403, etc.)

div2.head: 259b. CHESTERFIELD COUNTY MILITIA AND PLANTATION ACCOUNT BOOK
div2.p:
1 item, 1850-53 This volume was first used as a militia company roll book for the months of April, May and October, 1850 and then subsequently as a plantation account book, including transactions related to slaves. "Negro accounts, 1853" consists of two pages of payments for various goods and services, especially "ditching."
(Acc. 10777)
Guide available at http://ead.lib.virginia.edu/vivaead/published/uva-sc/vivadoc.pl?file=viu03807.xml

div2.head: 259c. CHICHESTER FAMILY PAPERS
div2.p:
ca. 125 items, [1716?]-1890
Papers of Chichester, Taliaferro, and related families of Fauquier and Culpeper counties, including personal and business correspondence, wills, deeds, plats, muster rolls, and published books. Of special interest are lists of slaves, a memorandum book of slave hire, letters mentioning the selling of slaves, and bills of sale for slaves.
(Acc. 11047)
Guide available at http://ead.lib.virginia.edu/vivaead/published/uva-sc/vivadoc.pl?file=viu01035.xml

div2.head: 260. CHRIST EPISCOPAL CHURCH RECORDS
div2.p:
ca. 50 items, 1836-1970, microfilm (M-2113 & 2273)
Records of this Charlottesville church. The Parish Register, 1838-65, contains records of the marriages and burials of African Americans. There are only a couple of entries for African Americans in the baptism and communicants sections. The Parish Register for 1868-87 contains records of the burials of African Americans members.
(Acc. 9682)
Guide available at http://ead.lib.virginia.edu/vivaead/published/uva-sc/vivadoc.pl?file=viu02183.xml

div2.head: 260a. CIVIL WAR DISABLED VETERAN LETTER
div2.p:
1 item, 1888 January 17
Letter written by a resident [Jesse] of the National Home for Disabled Volunteer Soldiers, Southern Branch [Hampton, Virginia] to his cousin and mentioning visiting the "Normal and Industrial School for the Instruction of Negroes & Indians" [Hampton Normal & Agricultural Institute ?] for elementary education and various trades. The trades he mentions include: blacksmithing, wheel wright, carpentry, cabinet making, shoe making, harness making, tin smithing, printing, book binding, farming, and a large sawmill. The school also has an excellent library and reading room with the best magazines and newspapers, where he spends most of his time.
(Acc. 11376)
Guide available at http://ead.lib.virginia.edu/vivaead/published/uva-sc/vivadoc.pl?file=viu01310.xml

div2.head: 261. THOMAS H. CLAGETT PAPERS
div2.p:
ca. 400 items, 1834-52
Business and personal papers of this Leesburg doctor and merchant. A number of letters, 1834-41, are from Philip Nelson, a free African American, to Clagett, who was apparently acting as Nelson's agent in Virginia to settle his debts and business obligations, sell his land, and make arrangements to move his family.
(Acc. 5182)
Guide available at http://ead.lib.virginia.edu/vivaead/published/uva-sc/vivadoc.pl?file=viu02911.xml

div2.head: 261a. CLARKE COUNTY VOLUMES
div2.p:
2 items, 1832-48
Account book, 1832-1848, kept by Abraham Kendrick, also of White Post, with a number of administrators' accounts, especially for tuition and some slave sales.
(Acc. 9096-bn)

div2.head: 262. CLAY FAMILY PAPERS
div2.p:
ca. 100 items, 1866-78, microfilm (M-542)
This collection of Clay Family Papers at the University of Kentucky includes speeches on slavery and the free states by Henry Clay and others.
(Acc. 5182)

div2.head: 263. HENRY CLAY LETTERS
div2.p:
5 items, 1834-48
A letter to Lewis Tappan discusses efforts to suppress the slave trade.
(Acc. 6643-b)

div2.head: 264. JOHN CLAYTON WILL
div2.p:
1 item, 1773
A typescript copy of the will of this Gloucester County resident. Included is the division of his slaves to various heirs.
(Acc. 5807)

div2.head: 264a. SAMUEL CLENDENING WILL
div2.p:
1 item, August 20, 1859
A will of this resident of Loudoun County, Va. dividing his property among the children of his siblings, and including extensive instructions regarding the eventual manumission of his slaves.
(Acc. 2)

div2.head: 265. WILLIAM W. COBB PAPERS
div2.p:
2 items, 1856-57
Papers of this Pittsylvania County farmer consisting of a January 1865 account with merchant Robert W. Calloway for livestock and grains and a tax bill, paid January 18, 1858, for slaves and personal property.
(Acc. 38-94-a)

div2.head: 265a. CHARLES COCKE LETTER
div2.p:
1 item, 2 April 1844
Charles Cocke, Esmont, Virginia, to C.L. Mosby discussing the financial default of a Mr. Sydnor, his own liability because of a bond he has signed, Sydnor's slaves conveyed by a trust to another party, and the failure of Mosby's bank to demand payment.
(Acc. 11172)
Guide available at http://ead.lib.virginia.edu/vivaead/published/uva-sc/vivadoc.pl?file=viu01454.xml

div2.head: 266. JOHN HARTWELL COCKE PAPERS
div2.p:
ca. 50,000 items, ca. 1725-1930
Correspondence, diaries, account books, and plantation records of this Fluvanna County planter and of various members of the Cocke and related families. This collection, a combination of many separate accessions, is invaluable for a study of slave life on large plantations. Other areas of interest are the American Colonization Society and letters from freed slaves in Liberia. A 1961 University of Virginia Ph.D. dissertation on Cocke by Martin Boyd Coyner is a very helpful tool to use in approaching the Cocke manuscripts.
(Acc. 640, etc.)
Diary of John Hartwell Cocke, May to December 1843. Entry for 13 December 1843.
http://www.lib.virginia.edu/harrison/exhibits/journeys/lg-html/MSS640_Box107_31Dec1843_pg01.html
Guide available at http://ead.lib.virginia.edu/vivaead/published/uva-sc/vivadoc.pl?file=viu00103.xml

div2.head: 267. JOHN C. COHOON ACCOUNT BOOK
div2.p:
1 item, ca. 1810-60, microfilm (M-1937)
The detailed ledger kept by this planter of Cedar Vale in Nansemond County is rich in demographic material on his slaves over a fifty-year period. Names, birth and death dates, parentage, source of acquisition, and hiring statistics are supplied.
(Acc. 8868)

div2.head: 268. COLEMAN FAMILY PAPERS
div2.p:
ca. 1,000 items, ca. 1780-1930
Included is a journal of Mrs. Jane Lindsay Coleman of Bedford near Augusta, Georgia, containing records of the births and ages of slaves, 1832-63. There does not appear to be any other references to slavery in the collection.
(Acc. 1794)
Guide available at http://ead.lib.virginia.edu/vivaead/published/uva-sc/vivadoc.pl?file=viu00029.xml

div2.head: 269. COLEMAN FAMILY PAPERS
div2.p:
6 items, 1830-1925
Business papers of this Halifax County family include an account book kept by Ethelbert Algernon Coleman for his ward, Jane C. Coleman Hamilton, listing the births and deaths of her slaves.
(Acc. 7014)

div2.head: 270. EDWARD COLES PAPERS
div2.p:
14 items,ca. 1840-60
Included is a photostat of a letter written in 1865 by a former slave wishing to return to her master.
(Acc. 1626)

div2.head: 271. KATE FLANAGAN COLES PAPERS
div2.p:
ca. 120 items, 1904-40
Correspondence of a former slave at Gale Hill in Albemarle County, home of William Wardlaw Minor. Most of the letters are to the Minor family; they contain family news and touch on the relationship between African Americans and whites in early twentieth-century Virginia.
(Acc. 10322)

Kate Flanagan Coles Papers.
Guide available at http://ead.lib.virginia.edu/vivaead/published/uva-sc/vivadoc.pl?file=viu02117.xml
Several Kate Flannagan Coles letters available at: http://www.vcdh.virginia.edu/afam/proffit/colesltrs/

div2.head: 272. COLONIAL SLAVE DOCUMENT
div2.p:
1 item, 1770
Instructions sent to Lieutenant Governor William Nelson of Virginia on December 10, 1770, by George III ordering Nelson to disallow a law passed by the colony which placed an additional tax on the importation of slaves.
(Acc. 3195)

div2.head: 273. COLONIAL SLAVE DOCUMENTS
div2.p:
4 items, 1772-74
Copies of four documents concerning the sentencing and execution of slaves in Sussex and Charlotte counties.
(Acc. 3076)

div2.head: 274. COMPTON FAMILY PAPERS
div2.p:
24 items, 1825-47
Letters of this Culpeper County family chiefly written to Thomas A. Compton in Mississippi. Included are an 1826 letter in which the writer indicated a willingness to part with some of his slaves in exchange for land; an 1846 estate list, including slaves; and an 1847 request to see that the writer's slaves got across a river by ferry safely.
(Acc. 38-116)
Guide available at http://ead.lib.virginia.edu/vivaead/published/uva-sc/vivadoc.pl?file=viu03840.xml

div2.head: 275. "CONDITIONS AMONG THE NEGROES"
div2.p:
1 item, 1918
Speech given by F. H. Parrish apparently before a group interested in church missionary work.
(Acc. 9222)

div2.head: 275a. CONFEDERATE PRISON MUSTER ROLL
div2.p:
1 item, 1864, April 27
The roll lists 58 prisoners, both Union and Confederate soldiers and 5 civilians and records date of incarceration; regiment and state; cause, date and place of arrest; hospital commitments; and discharges. Includes a note on Francis Fitzhugh, free woman [a free African American].
(Acc. 11362)
Guide available at http://ead.lib.virginia.edu/vivaead/published/uva-sc/vivadoc.pl?file=viu01270.xml

div2.head: 276. CONWAY FAMILY PAPERS
div2.p:
3 items, 1806-80
A small collection of three account books of this family from Orange and Madison counties. In the farm account book of 1849-66 are a few pages detailing birth and death records of slaves.
(Acc. 2485)

div2.head: 277. COOLIDGE-JEFFERSON COLLECTION
div2.p:
ca. 300 items, ca. 1790-1840
Mainly personal correspondence of Thomas Jefferson's descendants, especially his granddaughter Ellen Wayles Coolidge. The letters contain some discussion of slavery, such as one of August 1825 from Martha Randolph to Ellen mentioning complications in selling slaves.
(Acc. 9090)
Guide available at http://ead.lib.virginia.edu/vivaead/published/uva-sc/vivadoc.pl?file=viu00095.xml

div2.head: 278. ROBERTSON COONS ACCOUNT BOOK
div2.p:
1 item, 1818-60, photocopy
An account book of this Culpeper County resident. It includes entries on sales of slaves and the hiring out of slaves.
(Acc. 4323)

div2.head: 279. WILLIAM COX LETTERBOOK
div2.p:
1 item, 1763-68, microfilm (M-2123)
The 1763-68 letterbook of this Baltimore merchant contains occasional references to slaves he had for sale. Original manuscript at the New- York Historical Society.
(Acc. 9530)

div2.head: 279a. LEROY WESLEY COX MEMOIRS
div2.p:
1 item, 1861-1865
The memoirs of this Albemarle County Confederate soldier describe his service with James McDowell Carrington's Company Virginia Light Artillery (Charlottesville Artillery) and in Company D, 46th Virginia Regiment. Carrington relates anecdotes about an African American barber in the battery.
(Acc. 5049)

div2.head: 280. COX-McPHERSON FAMILY PAPERS
div2.p:
209 items, 1758-1949
This collection contains papers of Leroy Wesley Cox, a Charlottesville carriage and wagon manufacturer and Republican party worker. It includes an 1884 account book from his carriage business, voter registration lists, papers about party meetings, and 1896 lists of African American voters and African American members of the McKinley and Hobart Club on the stationery of Thomas L. Rosser.
(Acc. 38-11)
Guide available at http://ead.lib.virginia.edu/vivaead/published/uva-sc/vivadoc.pl?file=viu00013.xml

div2.head: 280a. COVE PRESBYTERIAN CHURCH RECORDS
div2.p:
3 items, 1801-1927
Among the records are personal accounts of Francis B. Hart, including personal accounts, 1834-1857, property inventory, 1834, slave birthdays, 1836-1857, and lists of slaves received into the church.
(Acc. 4740)

div2.head: 280b. RICHARD KENNER CRALL PAPERS
div2.p:
200 items, 1829-1860
Cralle was a newspaper editor, confidential clerk of John C. Calhoun, and editor of the The works of John C. Calhoun. The collection includes correspondence about newspapers, and national politics and a letter, C.H. Winder to John C. Calhoun as Sec. of State, regarding Catholics and slavery.
(Acc. 3875)

div2.head: 281. PAUL CUFFE LETTER
div2.p:
1 item, August 24, 1816
A letter from this African American sea captain and emigration organizer to W. Roper.
(Barrett Library Acc. 7174)

div2.head: 282. COUNTEE CULLEN COLLECTION
div2.p:
3 items, 1927-33
One letter, a manuscript of his poem "Requiescam," and a copy of a sketch of this African American poet.
(Barrett Library Acc. 8364)

div2.head: 282a. JOHN S. CROCKER LETTERS
div2.p:
30 items, 1843-90
Correspondence of this Union Civil War General from New York; commander of the 93rd New York Infantry Regiment (Morgan Rifles). Included is a letter 1864 March 20 from Harriet S. Crocker to "My Dear Husband" (JSC), Cambridge, noting tha a Doctor Wallace [possibly Assistant Surgeon Theodore C. Wallace, 93rd New York; see Adjutant-General's Office, Official Army Register, 2:575] arrived with two horses and one contraband [a runaway slave now his personal hired servant].
(Acc. 11312)
Guide available at http://ead.lib.virginia.edu/vivaead/published/uva-sc/vivadoc.pl?file=viu01266.xml

div2.head: 282b. D.F. CROSBY LABOR CONTRACT
div2.p:
1 item, 1867
Article of agreement between Crosby and five freedmen to work Crosby's plantation in Fairfield District, S.C.
(Acc. 5755-b)

div2.head: 283. HOMER STILLE CUMMINGS PAPERS
div2.p:
ca. 124,000 items, ca. 1890-1956
Business, political, and personal papers of Franklin Roosevelts attorney general. One file of material is on a 1936 case investigating charges that African Americans were used as slaves in Arkansas.
(Acc. 9973)
Guide available at http://ead.lib.virginia.edu/vivaead/published/uva-sc/vivadoc.pl?file=viu01993.xml

div2.head: 283a. CUMMINS FAMILY PAPERS
div2.p:
300 items, ca. 1815-1880
Papers of the Cummins and Eskridge families of Fauquier County, Va. including the wills of Sally Combs and John H. Pettit. The latter will provides for the emancipation of his slaves with a codicil in favor of the American Colonization Society. Also papers re the estate of Sally Combs, 1833-1839, include property and slave sale lists, court orders, and other papers regarding the disposition of her property.
(Acc. 4737)

div2.head: 283b. CURRIER & IVES HORSE RACING CARDS
div2.p:
9 items, 1881
Currier & Ives cards of race horses and jockeys, including the depiction of an African American jockey on Longfellow.
(Acc. 11092-f)

div2.head: 284. DABNEY AND DAVIS FAMILY PAPERS
div2.p:
ca. 13,000 items, ca. 1800-1970
Personal correspondence of these central Virginia families, primarily of Richard Heath Dabney and his wife Lucy Heth Davis Dabney. There are a few scattered references to slaves, such as a document hiring a slave in January 1865; a February 10, 1867, letter from Alice
Dabney (a former slave) to "Old Master"; and a March 17, 1885, letter from another former slave, George Page, to Susan Dabney Smedes.
(Acc. 9852)

div2.head: 285. VIRGINIUS DABNEY PAPERS
div2.p:
ca.52,000 items, ca. 1930-
Personal and business papers, manuscripts, photographs, and memorabilia of this noted Richmond journalist and Pulitzer Prize- winning author. There is a great deal of material on African Americans, civil rights, school desegregation, the NAACP, etc.
(Acc. 7690)
Guide available at http://ead.lib.virginia.edu/vivaead/published/uva-sc/vivadoc.pl?file=viu02923.xml

div2.head: 285a. JOHN WARWICK DANIEL PAPERS
div2.p:
ca 14,000 items, ca. 1816-1936
The papers of John Warwick Daniel through his student days at U.Va., his political career in the Virginia State Legislature and the U.S. House, and his 23 years in the U.S. Senate. At the 1901-1902 Virginia Constitutional Convention he served as chairman of the committee on the elective franchise, which successfully sought to disfranchise African Americans. Political papers, 1877-1904, discuss the bribing of African American voters, 1879.
(Acc. 158, etc.)
Guide available at http://ead.lib.virginia.edu/vivaead/published/uva-sc/viu00593.xml.frame

div2.head: 285b. JOHN HANNAH DANIEL PAPERS
div2.p:
ca 22,800 items, 1921-1971
Consists mainly of political papers from Daniel's terms as Virginia delegate, 1943-1970. There are many papers from the school desegregation fight in Prince Edward Co., part of Daniel's 22nd district, and the eventual establishment of the Prince Edward School Foundation to build a private segregated academy.
(Acc. 9886)

div2.head: 286. DANVILLE, KENTUCKY, COLONIZATION SOCIETY
div2.p:
1 item, 1829-35
A typescript copy of the constitution and minutes of the society.
(Acc. 4040)

div2.head: 287. CHARLES E. DAVIDSON ACCOUNT BOOKS
div2.p:
2 items, 1863-67
Medical account books of this Buckingham Court House physician. There are many entries on treatment of slaves.
(Acc. 4156)

div2.head: 287a. DAVIS FAMILY PAPERS
div2.p:
105 items, ca. 1847-1928
Manuscripts of this Orange County, Va., family including a sharecropper contract, 1872.
(Acc. 4738)

div2.head: 288. DAVIS FAMILY PAPERS
div2.p:
3 items, 1839-65
Memoirs of W. F. Davis of Charlottesville and a diary kept by his father, J. H. Davis, during the Civil War. J. H. Davis noted a local force organized in Charlottesville at the beginning of the war to control the African American population. The diary notes that a family slave, Thornton, traveled with W. F. Davis during the war and on May 15, 1864, returned home to report that he had been captured.
(Acc. 7396)

div2.head: 289. DAVIS FAMILY PAPERS
div2.p:
200 items, ca. 1835-85
Personal papers of this Albemarle County family, including a November 1850 letter from Eugene Davis of Charlottesville to [Thomas Hewitt Key] in London asking advice on freeing a female slave. Also present is a draft, 1850, of letter to Thomas Hewitt Key from Eugene Davis concerning the legal options of a slave named Sally [Cottrell Coles], currently the wife of a Reuben Coles. Sally was originally purchased from Joseph Coolidge and was thought to be manumitted by Key, but considered herself a slave so that she might stay in Virginia.
(Acc. 2483-a)

div2.head: 290. ISAAC DAVIS PAPERS
div2.p:
ca. 1,500 items, ca. 1770-1850
Business, legal, and personal papers of this Orange County resident, including some slavery material, such as sales and a September 17, 1824, letter from Nany [surname not recorded], Boone County, Kentucky, to her children [not named], Orange County, Virginia, 17 September 1824 available at http://www.lib.virginia.edu/harrison/exhibits/journeys/lg-html/MSS320_Box1_17Sept1824.html.
(Acc. 320)

div2.head: 291. JACKSON DAVIS PAPERS
div2.p:
ca. 6,000 items, 1882- 1947
Papers of Jackson Davis, assistant director of the Virginia General Education Board. Davis took nearly 6,000 photographs of African American schools, teachers and students throughout the Southeastern United States. There is also correspondence on African American education in the South with such people as Robert R. Moton, principal of Tuskegee Institute, and Virginia Randolph.
(Acc. 3072, -b,c,e,f,g)
Photographs and guide available at http://www.lib.virginia.edu/small/collections/jdavis/

div2.head: 292. W. W. DAVIS IRON MANUFACTURING COMPANY PAPERS
div2.p:
ca. 1,000 items, 1841-1907
Mainly business and personal letters of W. W. Davis concerning his iron business in Rockbridge County and other activities. A February 9, 1844, letter from Benjamin A. Firebaugh to A. B. Stuart discusses the possibility of hiring out a slave, and a January 1845 bond for the hire of a female slave specifies her clothing allotment, as does one for 1858. This collection has a good amount of material on the practice of hiring out slaves.
(Acc. 378)
Guide available at http://ead.lib.virginia.edu/vivaead/published/uva-sc/vivadoc.pl?file=viu00020.xml

div2.head: 293. DEARING FAMILY PAPERS
div2.p:
12 items, 1768-1983, photocopies
The papers contain seven letters, 1841-75, about family matters, business, crops, slave purchases, and life in Kentucky.
(Acc. 10565)

div2.head: 293a. DEBREE LETTER
div2.p:
1 item, January 29, 1829
A letter written from Norfolk by M. W. deBree to her father John B. deBree containing personal news and a mention of an aborted slave insurrection planned for a ship bound for New Orleans.
(Acc. 10930)
Guide available at http://ead.lib.virginia.edu/vivaead/published/uva-sc/vivadoc.pl?file=viu01575.xml

div2.head: 294. DETTINGEN PARISH VESTRY BOOK
div2.p:
1 item, 1744-1802 photocopy
The original of this Prince William County vestry book is in the Virginia State Library. Indentures have been copied and bound into the book; some concern free blacks such as a 1750 document about the mulatto offspring of a free black.
(Acc. 2536)

div2.head: 294a. GEORGINA FRANCES BARRETT DEVLIN DIARY
div2.p:
1 item, 1852-80, microfilm
The diary of this resident of Yazoo City, Mississippi covers the Civil War years and includes a mention, 1864 February 7, of African American troops.
(Acc. 10882)

div2.head: 295. DICK JOURNAL
div2.p:
1 item, 1806-9
The diary of a minor British official, Alexander Dick, appointed by Parliament to examine documents in the United States relative to American claims. There is much comment on slavery and the treatment of African Americans.
(McGregor Library Acc. 4528)

div2.head: 296. DICKINSON FAMILY PAPERS
div2.p:
ca. 20 items, 1822-58
Papers of this family of Franklin County. Letters of March 28 and May 29, 1858, to Miss Sallie describe the capture of a fugitive slave in Cincinnati.
(Acc. 38-176)

div2.head: 297. DILLARD FAMILY PAPERS
div2.p:
ca. 19,500 items, ca. 1720-1965
Personal and business papers of this Nansemond County family, including prominently the papers of James Hardy Dillard (1856-1940), a southern educator known for his role in the advancement of race relations and African American education in the South which began while he was at Tulane and continued throughout his life. His longest and most widely known association was with the Negro Rural School Fund (the Jeanes Foundation), of which he was president from 1907-1931, and the John F. Slater Fund, of which he was director from 1910-1917 and president from 1917-1931. He was also a long time member of the Phelps-Stokes Fund, of which he was vice-president in 1925, the Southern Education Board (1908-1940), and the General Education Board (1917-1940). In 1912 he helped found the Southern University Race Commission and was a long time associate with this organization. In 1923-1924 he was an American representative on the Educational Commission on East Africa. A framed charge of rape against several Negro boys during the early 1930's caught his attention and he accepted the chairmanship of the American Scottsboro Committee in 1935-1936 to help clear the charges.
(Acc. 9498)
Guide available at http://ead.lib.virginia.edu/vivaead/published/uva-sc/viu00599.xml.frame

div2.head: 298. JASON DOUGLAS PAPERS
div2.p:
ca. 1,000 items, 1735-1900
Personal and business correspondence of this Greene County resident. Tax assessments for 1863 giving the number and value of slaves and an 1841 will of Richard White of Greene County are included. Correspondence includes family news and social news from family members in Kentucky and Missouri; and letters, 1861-1865, of Captain John M. Douglass, 155th Regiment, 1st District, 1st Company, Greene County, Va., to his wife Sallie and daughter Bettie, concerning the management of the plantation in his absence and frequent references to the slaves. Also includes a letter, 1867, from C.V. Hill, a freedwoman working in Baltimore, and a letter, 1870, from Emily, a freedwoman working at the Exchange Hotel in Harrisonburg and plantation accounts, 1837-1877, with notations for corn, flour, household items; freedmen's agreements and sharecropping agreements.
(Acc. 702)

div2.head: 299. FREDERICK DOUGLASS COLLECTION
div2.p:
3 items, ca. 1895
Two letters and one photograph of this noted African American abolitionist, writer, and journalist.
(Barrett Library Acc. 7181)

div2.head: 299a. PATRICK HENRY DREWRY PAPERS
div2.p:
ca. 16,500 items, 1897-1947
The Patrick Henry Drewry Collection is comprised of legal correspondence, family financial papers, and some personal correspondence. Most of the material relates to Drewry's legal practice in Petersburg as a member of the firm Lassiter and Drewry (1907-1921) and later during the partnership of Drewry & Old. Additionally he was a member of the Virginia State Senate (1912-1920) and as a U.S. Congressman (1920-1947). Of interest are letters regarding the 1906 murder trial of an indigent African American.
(Acc. 8255)
Guide available at http://ead.lib.virginia.edu/vivaead/published/uva-sc/viu03535.xml.frame

div2.head: 300. RICHARD THOMAS WALKER DUKE PAPERS
div2.p:
21 items, 1836-1919
Collection consists of the correspondence of Duke and his son, Judge Richard Thomas Walker Duke of Albemarle County. Topics include the hiring of former slaves.
(Acc. 9521j)
Guide available at http://ead.lib.virginia.edu/vivaead/published/uva-sc/vivadoc.pl?file=viu00189.xml

div2.head: 301. PAUL LAWRENCE DUNBAR COLLECTION
div2.p:
6 items, 1892-1902
Letters and one manuscript of this major African American poet.
(Barrett Library Acc. 6323)

div2.head: 302. PAUL LAWRENCE DUNBAR PAPERS
div2.p:
ca. 10,000 items, 1873-1936, microfilm (M-2236-44)
The microfilm edition of his papers held by the Ohio Historical Society.
(Acc. 7147)

div2.head: 302a. WILLIAM DUNCAN LETTER
div2.p:
1 item, 1830
William Duncan to Major William Henley, 1830 November 30, Duncan writes concerning his family's emigration to Missouri and living conditions in Calloway County. He mentions his intentions to set up a business, problems caused by a drought and the anticipated sale of some of his slaves.
(Acc. 5331)

div2.head: 302b. JAMES LANGSTAFF DUNN LETTERS
div2.p:
150 items, 1850-1906
Letters from James Langstaff Dunn, a Brigade Surgeon to the 2nd Brigade, Banks Corp, 2nd Brigade, 2nd Division, 12th and 20th Army Corps, to his wife (with a few exceptions). On June 30, 1862, he writes to his wife about slaves who flee the advance of the army and in a December 20, 1864 letter, he describes the march to Savannah which included the exodus of 20,000 slaves gaining freedom.
(Acc. 8301, -a, -b)
Guide available at http://ead.lib.virginia.edu/vivaead/published/uva-sc/vivadoc.pl?file=viu02231.xml

div2.head: 303. LEON DURE PAPERS
div2.p:
ca. 2,400 items, 1945-71
Personal papers of this Charlottesville resident who was a spokesman for "Freedom of Choice" as the solution to the problem of integration of the Virginia public schools in the 1960s. Included is correspondence with African American leaders.
(Acc. 9751)

div2.head: 304. MARTHA TABB DYER DIARIES
div2.p:
3 items, 1823-39
Three diaries, 1823-39, kept by this Calloway County, Missouri, woman with references to sewing, etc., for her slaves.
(Acc. 7776)

div2.head: 305. EARLY-DAVIS COLLECTION
div2.p:
4 items, 1791-1862
Papers of these Orange, Greene and Albemarle County families including copies from a family Bible, with slave births, 1817-1832.
(Acc. 4555)

div2.head: 306. EDGEHILL SCHOOL LETTER
div2.p:
1 item, January 10, 1864
A letter written from this Albemarle County school about the purchase of slaves for $11,000.
(Acc. 38-421)

div2.head: 306a. WILLIAM A. ELWOOD CIVIL RIGHTS LAWYERS PROJECT COLLECTION
div2.p:
284 items, 1984-89
The collection consists of 284 videotapes shot by Elwood for the Civil Rights Lawyers Project. The tapes were used in the award-winning documentary film arranged by Elwood "The road to Brown : the untold story of 'the man who killed Jim Crow'," about the life of Charles Hamilton Houston, his crusade for civil rights, and the events that led to Brown v. the Board of Education, the 1954 Supreme Court decision that declared the doctrine of separate but equal to be illegal.
(Acc. 12801)

div2.head: 307. EMERSON FAMILY PAPERS
div2.p:
8 items, ca. 1835-65
Personal papers of this Augusta County family. The diary of Nancy Emerson has occasional references to family slaves and an account of the flight of the Reverend Luther Emerson and his slaves from advancing Union troops in the Valley of Virginia.
(Acc. 9381)
Digital copy and transcript available at http://valley.vcdh.virginia.edu/personalpapers/collections/augusta/emerson.html

div2.head: 307a. EVANS FAMILY COLLECTION
div2.p:
7 items, 1889-1903
An African-American family of Knoxville, Maryland; Mary Evans, a former slave, and her son Henry write to her former owner, Brian Philpot, Chicago, conveying news of family and friends in Knoxville. Several letters thank Philpot for gifts of clothing and money.
(Acc. 11018)
Guide available at http://ead.lib.virginia.edu/vivaead/published/uva-sc/vivadoc.pl?file=viu01534.xml

div2.head: 308. ESSEX COUNTY COURT HOUSE LEDGERS
div2.p:
13 items, 1813-65
General merchandise and farm records of J. Sanders & Co., Moore, Robinson & Co., J. B. Robinson, and J. K. Robinson. Included are scattered slavery references.
(Acc. 38-47)

div2.head: 309. EX-SLAVE INTERVIEWS
div2.p:
5 items, 1927
Five transcripts of ex-slave interviews conducted by WPA workers.
(Acc. 3462)

div2.head: 310. EX-SLAVE LETTERS
div2.p:
3 items, 1909-10
Included are two letters by a former slave living in California to his master's son, in Virginia, requesting to spend his last years on the old home place and recalling the Civil War, which "broke us up."
(Acc. 2331)

div2.head: 310a. EWING FAMILY PAPERS
div2.p:
ca. 250 items, 1806-1926
Consists of the personal correspondence of the Ewing families of Rockbridge County, Virginia, and Kanawha County, West Virginia. Topics of note include a description of poor whites and African American slaves in Albemarle and Buckingham Counties (1806 Nov 20) and the sentiments of a young man about slavery (1807 Jun 3).
(Acc. 10799)
Guide available at http://ead.lib.virginia.edu/vivaead/published/uva-sc/vivadoc.pl?file=viu01665.xml

div2.head: 311. FIFE FAMILY PAPERS
div2.p:
ca. 5,000 items, 1747-present
Business and personal papers of the Fife and related Herndon, Strickler, and Graves families, chiefly of Albemarle, Madison, and Spotsylvania counties. A Herndon account book, 1810-22, contains entries for "Dr. Thos. Colson's Old Negroes or the Fund for their Support."
(Acc. 5943)

div2.head: 312. FIRST BAPTIST CHURCH HISTORY
div2.p:
1 item, 1981
The manuscript of Keeping the Faith: A History of First Baptist Church, 1863-1980, in Light of Its Times, West Main and Seventh Streets, Charlottesville, Virginia (Charlottesville: The Church, 1981) by Richard I. McKinney, a history of the oldest African American church in Charlottesville.
(Acc. 10479)

div2.head: 313. FITZHUGH FAMILY PAPERS
div2.p:
ca. 100 items, 1775-1803
Personal correspondence of William Fitzhugh of Chatham. Included is a July 14, 1796, letter from William Fitzhugh to Benjamin Grymes discussing a smallpox epidemic which was killing the slaves.
(Acc. 5242)

div2.head: 314. FITZHUGH AND MARYE LAW OFFICE PAPERS
div2.p:
5 items, 1863-68
General correspondence of a Fredericksburg law firm, including the sale of Mrs. Thornton's slaves in May 1838. It compares slave prices in Virginia and Alabama.
(Acc. 2062)

div2.head: 315. HORACE ASHTON FITZHUGH PAPERS
div2.p:
12 items, 1817-92
Business, legal, and financial papers of this King George County resident. Included is an 1858 list of the valuation of slaves.
(Acc. 5723)

div2.head: 316. PETER FLEMING NEWSPAPER CLIPPING
div2.p:
1 item, May 1866
An item concerning the devotion of a Virginia African American man to his former master.
(Acc. 38-412)

div2.head: 317. FLUVANNA COUNTY COLLECTION
div2.p:
9 items, 1827-1907, microfilm (M-1725)
Includes a letter, ca. 1874, from Frank Morton, an ex-slave living in Claiborne County, Mississippi, to Joe Perkins of Fluvanna County in which Morton asked Perkins if he knew of the whereabouts of any of his five boys whom he had to leave in 1855 when he was sold to Mississippi.
(Acc. 8386)

div2.head: 318. FOLLY FARM PAPERS
div2.p:
ca. 560 items, ca. 1800-1900
Business and personal papers of the Cochran family of Folly Farm near Staunton. Includes a number of slavery items, such as lists of slaves for hire in 1856-60 and two lists of gifts to slaves.
(Acc. 9380)
Guide available at http://ead.lib.virginia.edu/vivaead/published/uva-sc/vivadoc.pl?file=viu00097.xml

div2.head: 319. FONTAINE FAMILY PAPERS
div2.p:
ca. 1,000 items, 1798-1861, microfilm (M-621)
Business, legal, and personal papers of Colonel Walter S. Fontaine of Buckingham County and of the Fontaine, Brown, Thompson and allied families. There are letters and business records regarding the sale of slaves, such as a March 21, 1817, letter from Benjamin Lewis to Fontaine asking him to sell two slaves but to try to respect the slaves' wishes to remain in the neighborhood, if possible, and testimony from relatives and neighbors regarding an accusation that overseer Christopher Johnson beat a slave to death.
(Acc. 4149)

div2.head: 320. WALTER FONTAINE PAPERS
div2.p:
ca. 200 items, ca. 1810-1910
Mainly legal and business papers of this Buckingham County merchant. Included are an 1820 estate valuation of William Toney listing the estate's slaves and values; a receipt for hiring out a slave on August 23, 1831; and a December 1822 deed of sale for a female slave and her two children.
(Acc. 7984)
Guide available at http://ead.lib.virginia.edu/vivaead/published/uva-sc/vivadoc.pl?file=viu00085.xml

div2.head: 321. JAMES WESTHALL FORD PAPERS
div2.p:
800 items, ca. 1820-80
