Personal and business papers of this Richmond portrait artist (1806- 1868). Two letters from Joseph Mills in Norfolk to Ford, January 13 and July 28, 1840, ask Ford to sell a African American woman, Delphina, owned by Mills because she did not want to live in Norfolk.
(Acc. 6073)
Guide available at http://ead.lib.virginia.edu/vivaead/published/uva-sc/vivadoc.pl?file=viu02859.xml

div2.head: 321a. FORMER SLAVE CHILDREN RETURNED TO FORMER MASTER
div2.p:
1 item, September 15, 1865
Captain [Thomas?] Birmingham finds that two African American children in Covington are not cared for in their current situation and authorizes their former master, Christopher Damron, to take them and provide for them as he has promised.
(Acc. 11821)

div2.head: 322. ADAM FOSTER LETTER
div2.p:
1 item, January 9, 1877, photocopy
A letter from Foster to Cynthia in which he described in much detail the life on Tidewater plantations, especially Auborn in Mathews County. He went into detail on the work of the slaves and also expressed his interpretation of their feelings.
(Acc. 10103)

div2.head: 323. RICHARD FOSTER PAPERS
div2.p:
ca. 30 items, 1773-1877
A small collection of business and legal papers of this Mathews County merchant and planter. Included is a May 20, 1803, deposition signed by the justice of peace of Mathews County taking custody of a runaway slave turned over to him.
(Acc. 3523)

div2.head: 323a. WALTER FRANK PAPERS
div2.p:
480 items, 1925-70
Contains correspondence, manuscripts, photographs, printed material and bound volumes pertaining to Frank's memberships, law practice, and lifelong advocacy of civil liberties and racial equality civil liberties as a lawyer who practiced in the law offices of Kurzman & Frank in New York. He was also vice-chairman of the executive committee of the Citizens Union, a member of the national board of the American Civil Liberties Union, the National Consumers League, and the Citizens League for Industrial Democracy. Included are letters, 1942- 1961, from Abram Lincoln Harris (1899-1963) rich in relating the feelings and experiences of an African American man in the academic world.
(Acc. 10951, -a)
Guide available at http://ead.lib.virginia.edu/vivaead/published/uva-sc/vivadoc.pl?file=viu01565.xml

div2.head: 324. FRAZIER AND COLEMAN FAMILY PAPERS
div2.p:
ca. 700 items, 1801-1905
Business and personal papers of these families from Orange and Amherst counties. Data on slave births and deaths are recorded in the
Frazier family Bible, as well as an 1847 list of slaves owned by Lancelot Burrus and an 1860 list of slaves belonging to the Coleman family.
(Acc. 4114, etc.)

div2.head: 324a. FREDERICK COUNTY VIRGINIA DOCUMENTS
div2.p:
4 items, 1778-1881
Documents tracing the ownership of land tracts near Cedar Creek in Frederick County, Virginia. Included is a January 19, 1819 will of Frederick County resident William Tyler (?--1822). Among its provisions are bequests of various lands and possession to members of his family as well as instructions freeing specific slaves and of the emancipation of others upon their reaching the age of twenty-five; Tyler also stipulates that "should the laws of Virginia be unfavourable to the emancipation of slaves, I enforce it on my executor, in order to insure the freedom of my negroes, as aforesaid, that he remove them to some other state more favourable to liberty and there set them free."
(Acc. 10852)
Guide available at http://ead.lib.virginia.edu/vivaead/published/uva-sc/vivadoc.pl?file=viu01623.xml

div2.head: 325. FREDERICKSBURG AND STAFFORD COUNTY LEDGERS
div2.p:
5 items, 1804-76
Included is a daybook kept by George P. King of Stafford County which shows how African Americans were hired as tenant farmers beginning in 1867.
(Acc. 5307)
Guide available at http://ead.lib.virginia.edu/vivaead/published/uva-sc/vivadoc.pl?file=viu02894.xml

div2.head: 326. FREDERICKSBURG COURT RECORDS
div2.p:
13 items, 1796-1855, microfilm (M-597-98)
Court records for the corporation of Fredericksburg and the county of Spotsylvania. The Hustings Court records include entries on prosecutions of slaves and freedmen such as five loose warrants, 1845-1855, issued by the Mayor's Court, which includes incidents of two free African-American hands on a steamboat using provoking language.
(Acc. 4141)

div2.head: 327. FREEDMEN WORK AGREEMENTS
div2.p:
2 items, 1865-67
Work agreements with former slaves of George Hannah of Gravel Hill.
(Acc. 2602)

div2.head: 328. FREEDMEN'S BUREAU RECORDS
div2.p:
1 item 1865-67 , microfilm (M-632)
A microfilm copy of the records of Charlottesville and Albemarle County made from the originals in the National Archives.
(Acc. 4443)

div2.head: 328-a. FRANKLIN FRETWELL PAPERS
div2.p:
ca. 2900 items, 1819-1886
Business papers of Franklin Fretwell ofNew Hope, Virginia. Fretwell mainly dealt with merchants from Richmond and Lynchburg, Virginia during the 1850s, with merchants from Richmond, Virginia during the Civil War, and with merchants from Baltimore, Maryland after the war. Letters from Brightberry Fretwell discuss business matters including incidences of measles among the children and the negroes (March 21 and April 18, 1858); and the loss of negroes to illness (July 2, 1858, November 8, 1859 and December 4, 1859).
(Acc. 11296, -a)
Guide available at http://ead.lib.virginia.edu/vivaead/published/uva-sc/vivadoc.pl?file=viu01365.xml

div2.head: 329. FRY, BARKSDALE, McLEMORE, SANDERS, AND RELATED FAMILY PAPERS
div2.p:
32 items, 1759-1969
A 1759-95 account book of the Reverend Henry Fry of Albemarle County which includes an entry for George Washington and one for James Madison, Sr. There are also two pocket almanacs, 1783? and 1795, kept by Fry, account books, and notebooks. The 1806-62 account book contains lists of slaves.
(Acc. 10659-a)

div2.head: 330. GANNAWAY FAMILY PAPERS
div2.p:
ca. 1,000 items, ca. 1755-1935
Business and personal letters of this family of Red Oak, Buckingham County. In the business papers is an 1848 listing and valuation of the slaves of Archibald Clark and Mary C. Molloy.
(Acc. 3784)

div2.head: 330a. INVENTORY AND APPRAISAL OF THE ESTATE OF DR. JOHN W. GANTT
div2.p:
1 item, 1860 November 29
The inventory of this Albemarle County Virginia resident, compiled by executor Henry Gantt and recorded by clerk of court Ira Garrett, lists 57 slaves.
(Acc. 11430)
Guide available at http://ead.lib.virginia.edu/vivaead/published/uva-sc/vivadoc.pl?file=viu01250.xml

div2.head: 331. GARNETT FAMILY PAPERS
div2.p:
ca. 40 items, ca. 1770-1865, microfilm (M-1262)
Business and legal papers of this Essex County family. Included is an 1830 account of L. Lewis for furnishing support of slaves of George Washington's estate.
(Acc. 6053)

div2.head: 332. MUSCOE R. E. GARNETT MANUSCRIPT
div2.p:
1 item, 1850
Remarks to the Virginia Constitutional Convention of 1850 on a measure concerning free blacks.
(Acc. 5115)

div2.head: 333. GARRETT FAMILY PAPERS
div2.p:
ca. 300 items, ca. 1800-1935
Correspondence, personal, and business papers of this family of York County. Many scattered references to slavery include a July 2, 1843, letter to William Nelson giving permission for a slave, Jim, to be baptized; a December 20, 1851, letter from G. R. Garrett to his brother who had reported trouble at a Richmond college because African Americans were allowed to be married there; an April 15, 1852, letter telling of a Captain Ravley who stabbed several African Americans and killed at least one African American person and, according to an October 11, 1852, letter, was found not guilty; and an October 4, 1852, letter mentioning that Fanny had been sold for behaving badly.
(Acc. 9974, -a)

div2.head: 334. H. C. GARRETT LETTER
div2.p:
1 item, November 12, 1841
This letter from H. C. Garrett to Richard Stewart of Culpeper Court House includes a reference to the buying of slaves.
(Acc. 38-463-a)

div2.head: 334a. JOHN P. GARRETT JOURNAL
div2.p:
ca. 7,000 items, 1847, microfilm (M-244)
Farm journal of Ash Lawn in Albemarle County kept by John P. Garrett including materials on slavery, among them a detailed list of slaves in 1838.
(Acc. 2794)

div2.head: 334b. THOMAS H. GEE ACCOUNT BOOK
div2.p:
1 item, 1853-64
The account book was kept by this Lunenberg Co. resident who was named as administrator of several estates including here the estates of Peter F. Clark, Susan Clark, George C. Harrison and John F. Shelton. Two 1853 entries concern the hiring of an African American.
(Acc. 8979-o)

div2.head: 335. GILLFIELD BAPTIST CHURCH RECORDS
div2.p:
7 items, ca. 1827-1940, microfilm (M-1397)
Records of this African American Baptist church of Petersburg beginning with the April 1827 Record Book.
(Acc. 10041)

div2.head: 336. GILLIAM FAMILY PAPERS
div2.p:
ca. 1,500 items, 1802-1932
Primarily the personal and political correspondence, various accounts, and bills of this Dinwiddie County family. A specific section of this collection is devoted entirely to slavery and includes papers on the hiring out, trading, and purchasing of slaves.
(Acc. 2608)
Guide available at http://ead.lib.virginia.edu/vivaead/published/uva-sc/vivadoc.pl?file=viu03275.xml

div2.head: 337. GILLIAM FAMILY PAPERS
div2.p:
300 items, ca. 1840-90
Primarily business and personal correspondence of this family of High Meadow near Richmond. A number of letters discuss slave prices and the buying and selling of slaves, such as a June 29, 1859, letter of J. T. Foster to Gilliam commenting on the high price of slaves and the fact that he would have to send to "Delaware for our supply."
(Acc. 3593, -a)

div2.head: 337a. GLOVER DAVENPORT GILLIAM LEDGERS
div2.p:
3 items, ca. 1820-90
Contains the accounts from Gilliam's plantation, mill, and medical practice in Campbell Co. A journal, 1832-55, has various entries for services performed or expenditures pertaining to African Americans such as the following: January 24, 1848 entry for Mrs. Mary Cobbs to visit to negroes & med. and a December 4 1848 entry to Mr. S. Jones for hire of John.
(Acc. 6586-c)

div2.head: 338. GEORGE GILMER DAYBOOK
div2.p:
1 item, 1770-75
A medical daybook of this Charlottesville physician who counted Thomas Jefferson and James Madison among his patients. There are many entries on medical treatment for slaves.
(Acc. 6145)

div2.head: 339. Z. LEE GILMER CIVIL WAR DIARY
div2.p:
2 items, 1861-62
The two diaries contain a November 9, 1861, entry by this
Charlottesville soldier about a personal servant, Tarleton, who carried arms for the Confederate Army.
(Acc. 4459)

div2.head: 340. GOOCH FAMILY PAPERS
div2.p:
ca. 1,800 items, ca. 1800-1890
Correspondence and papers of Colonel Claiborne William Gooch of Richmond, his wife Rebecca, and sons Richard Barnes, Philip, and Arthur Fleming. The collection is primarily political in nature with much material on the U.S. Bank, nullification, and states' rights. Scattered slavery references include John Floyd's February 17, 1825, letter to C. W. Gooch which contains views on the slavery question and a January 22, 1845, letter of P. B. Gooch to P. C. Gooch discussing the sale of slaves.
(Acc. 3921, -a)

div2.head: 341. GOOCHLAND PARISH REGISTER
div2.p:
1 item, 1750-95, microfilm (M-700)
Compiled by Reverend William Douglass, this register includes a page entitled "Register of Negroes born & christened."
(Acc. 923)

div2.head: 342. SCHOOL TRUSTEES, BYRD DISTRICT, GOOCHLAND COUNTY, BOARD MINUTES
div2.p:
2 items, 1871-1900
Includes literacy statistics for white and African American students and a September 17, 1896, teacher listing by race and salary.
(Acc. 1032)

div2.head: 343. GOODWIN FAMILY PAPERS
div2.p:
4 items, 1770-1940 , photocopies
Genealogical records of the Goodwin, Burruss, Hart, and Winston families from the Goodwin family Bible that contain information on slaves' births and deaths from 1823 to 1865.
(Acc. 4125)

div2.head: 343a. GOODWIN AND WINFREE LETTERS
div2.p:
2 items, 1843 and 1859 Consists of a December 16, 1843, letter from W.P. Goodwin, Rose Hill, Va., to James M. Beazley about a delinquent account partially caused by his slaves' poor management of the tobacco crop and a May 27, 1859, letter from John B. Winfree, Woodlawn [near Petersburg], Va., to his brother Christopher V. Winfree, Lynchburg, Va., discussing plans for recently inherited slaves, the hiring out of a slave and the refusal to hire out a female slave for factory work.
(Acc. 10969)
Guide available at http://ead.lib.virginia.edu/vivaead/published/uva-sc/vivadoc.pl?file=viu01555.xml

div2.head: 344. GOOSE CREEK BAPTIST CHURCH RECORDS
div2.p:
2 items, 1775-1853, microfilm (M-649)
Church records, 1775-1853, including lists of slave members.
(Acc. 4496)

div2.head: 345. GORDON FAMILY PAPERS
div2.p:
ca. 50 items, 1745-1900
Collection includes the 1845-88 diary of William Gordon, a planter of Nelson County. It contains frequent references to, as well as annual records of, the plantation slaves.
(Acc. 9553)

div2.head: 346. GORDON FAMILY PAPERS
div2.p:
ca. 1,000 items, ca. 1810-1915
Personal and political papers of William Fitzhugh Gordon of Orange County. Some of the family personal correspondence involves the slaves, such as a December 15, 1830, letter relating that a slave, Nancy, had been sold to her reputed father and sent to Philadelphia, a February 18, 1847, letter reporting that some of the slaves had to be sold to meet debts and a letter from Maria Lindsay Walker to her sister E. L. Gordon giving details of the sack of "Soldier's Joy" in Nelson County by Union troops under George Armstrong Custer claiming that the slaves all remained faithful and told the Union troops they had the best master and mistress there was.
(Acc. 10089)

div2.head: 346a. DR. JOHN NEWTON GORDON LETTERS
div2.p:
23 items, 1858-85
Transcripts of letters to Gordon and other family members from brothers and sisters who emigrated to Kansas and Texas discuss farm life in Texas, financial hardships in Kansas, emigration routes, land prices, slaves, sharecropping, effect of Civil War, and family news.
(Acc. 5613)

div2.head: 347. GRAHAM FAMILY PAPERS
div2.p:
ca. 3,000 items, 1808-1900
Business records of the Wytheville ironworks of Joseph J. and David Graham. A seven-volume time book for 1828-52 consists of records of African American labor, slaves hired and at what prices, information on runaways, etc. There is also a five-volume time book for 1846-70. Included are slave bills of sale and records of the Barren Springs Mining Company, the C.R. Mines, Calfee and Robinson, Fair Play Furnace, David Graham and Son, Graham's Forge Farmer's Club, Jackson Forge, Norfolk and Western Railroad, Graham's Forge, Samuel Quesenberry, Reed Island Iron Company, Paramont Furnace, and Peach Bottom Copper Mine.
(Acc. 38-106, etc.)

div2.head:
347a. JOHN V.GRAHAM MATERIAL CONTAINING REPORTS AND STATISTICS ON BLACK STUDIES PROGRAMS
AND THE ADMISSION AND RECRUITMENT OF BLACK STUDENTS AT THE UNIVERSITY OF VIRGINIA
div2.p:
ca. 1,000 items, 1969-70
Printed and manuscript material collected and compiled by this University of Virginia faculty member in English.
(Acc. 6660-a)

div2.head: 347b. GRAHAM-SANDERS-TATE FAMILY PAPERS
div2.p:
ca. 220 items, 1853-1991
Correspondence, financial and legal papers, genealogical and historical information of the Graham, Sanders, and Tate families of Wythe County. Letters, 1861-1864, from James Graham Tate, written from various camp sites, were sent to his sister, Nannie, and his father, Charles Campbell Tate. In them he mentions his views on "negro property" and claims for lost slaves.
(Acc. 9232-q)
Guide available at http://ead.lib.virginia.edu/vivaead/published/uva-sc/viu00119.xml.frame

div2.head: 347c. GRAND ARMY OF THE REPUBLIC REUNION PHOTOGRAPH
div2.p:
1 item, ca. 1910 African-Americans at a reunion of Grand Army of the Republic (G. A. R.), in Norfolk, Virginia. It is believed photographer H. (Harry) C. Mann took it at Elmwood Cemetery.
(Acc. 11436)
Guide and image available at http://ead.lib.virginia.edu/vivaead/published/uva-sc/vivadoc.pl?file=viu02106.xml

div2.head: 347d. JOHN SEGAR GRAVATT PAPERS
div2.p:
500 items, 1949-99
Consists primarily of the papers of Judge John Segar Gravatt of Blackstone, Nottoway County, Virginia focusing on the struggle over the desegregation of Virginia schools, 1959-1962, and his role as counsel for the Board of Supervisors of Prince Edward County, Va., when the decision was made to close the county's schools.
(Acc. 11584)
Guide available at http://ead.lib.virginia.edu/vivaead/published/uva-sc/vivadoc.pl?file=viu01431.xml

div2.head: 348. GRAVEL HILL PAPERS
div2.p:
ca. 1,500 items, 1804-88
Records and correspondence of the Hannah family of Gravel Hill, Charlotte County. There are a few references to African Americans, such as George Hannah's "Register of My Black Family's Ages, 1800-1851" and medical accounts of George Hannah for 1855-60 including treatment of African Americans.
(Acc. 2320)

div2.head: 349. GRAVES FAMILY COLLECTION
div2.p:
56 items, ca. 1830-60
A small collection of family letters primarily of this Georgia and North Carolina family. Among a few documents on slave sales and hiring out are a March 17, 1844, sale of four slaves and a January 20, 1859, sale of a male slave described as a brick mason.
(Acc. 1776)

div2.head: 350. JEREMIAH WHITE GRAVES COLLECTION
div2.p:
3 items, 1822-78, microfilm (M-686)
Account book, 1822-53, and diaries, 1843-78, of this Pittsylvania County planter, with references to slavery.
(Acc. 5047)

div2.head: 350a. GREEN FAMILY PAPERS
div2.p:
75 items, 1859-66
Letters of Benjamin H. Green, Chief Engineer of Gen. Ewell's Corps, and John W. Green who served on Gen. W.J. Hardee's staff, both from Georgia. Additionally, there are letters in typescript from Emmie E. Holmes, Charleston, to Lizzie Green. These long letters describe Charleston society, preparations for secession and war, the firing on the Star of the West, the fall of Fort Sumter, rumors of slave revolts, effects of the blockade, the capture of the Sea Islands.
(Acc. 6211)

div2.head: 351. PHILIP GREEN JOURNALS
div2.p:
4 items, ca. 1810-55
Letters, sermons, etc., bound in journals belonging to a Methodist circuit preacher and containing numerous references to slavery.
(Acc. 7652)

div2.head: 352. GREEN-FLETCHER FAMILY PAPERS
div2.p:
ca. 150 items, ca. 1790-1890
Papers of these Culpeper and Rappahanock County families including a list of the slaves owned by the Green family and an August 4, 1865, letter discussing African American labor in New Orleans.
(Acc. 4694)

div2.head: 353. GREENLEE PAPERS
div2.p:
ca. 800 items, 1819-98
Legal papers and documents of John F. Greenlee, clerk of Rockbridge County Court. Included are an 1860 alphabetical list of free blacks in Rockbridge County and a September 22, 1863, list of the number of slaves drafted in Rockbridge County to work in the defense of Richmond.
(Acc. 5213-c)
Guide available at http://ead.lib.virginia.edu/vivaead/published/uva-sc/vivadoc.pl?file=viu03374.xml

div2.head: 353a. GREGORY-WHITMORE FAMILY PAPERS
div2.p:
ca. 2,700 items, 1846-1997
Chiefly letters from Mary Susan Gregory Whitmore (September 19, 1846 - April 4, 1923) to her sons, Harry Gregory Whitmore and Samuel L. Whitmore in various central Virginia locations. There are references to African Americans in the correspondence.
(Acc. 10754)
Guide available at http://ead.lib.virginia.edu/vivaead/published/uva-sc/vivadoc.pl?file=viu01729.xml

div2.head: 354. GRINNAN FAMILY PAPERS
div2.p:
ca. 6,000 items, 1749-1899
Business records, correspondence, and account books of this family of Fredericksburg. Many of the documents contain references to slavery. Among them are bills of sale, correspondence among family members regarding slavery, an October 7, 1790, payment for sold slaves; a February 12, 1851, letter from Louisa to A. G. Grinnan with references to the fugitive slave bill; an April 13, 1864, letter from Robert Grinnan to A. G. Grinnan about the sale of slaves; an April 18, 1855, letter from G. B. Wallace to Andrew Grinnan (in family correspondence, 1854-56) which discusses slave breeding; a letter from a slave asking to be purchased (in the 1824-30 folder); and letters containing references to abolitionism, a letter from a slave to his master, and an April 3, 1834, letter referring to payment for the "hauling" of African Americans (in the 1832-39 folder).
(Acc. 49, etc.)
Guide available at http://ead.lib.virginia.edu/vivaead/published/uva-sc/vivadoc.pl?file=viu03209.xml

div2.head: 355. WILLIAM HUGH GROVE DIARY
div2.p:
1 item, 1732
This travel diary of an Englishman describes life in Virginia around Williamsburg and Yorktown. The entries describe slave quarters near Williamsburg and the life-style of slaves, as well as traveling on a slave ship.
(McGregor Library Acc. 3850)

div2.head: 356. GEORGE E. GRYMES MANAGER'S JOURNAL
div2.p:
1 item, 1855-57
A daily plantation account of Mount Stuart in King George County, with a list of slaves noting occupations and valuations.
(Acc. 4494)

div2.head: 356a. ALEX HALEY COLLECTION
div2.p:
19 items, 1961-63
Manuscripts and research notes for this noted African American authors book Dark Secret's Last Race about the champion thoroughbred racehorse and his final victory at the 1934 Jockey Club Gold race.
(Acc. 11204)
Guide available at http://ead.lib.virginia.edu/vivaead/published/uva-sc/vivadoc.pl?file=viu01318.xml

div2.head: 357. HALIFAX COUNTY PETITION
div2.p:
1 item, ca. 1860
From a group of citizens to Governor John Letcher asking that a death sentence given a slave be commuted.
(Acc. 10287-a)

div2.head: 358. E. G. HALLER PAPERS
div2.p:
10 items, ca. 1825-90
Papers, account books, and memorabilia of this physician of Wytheville. Haller's report in 1870 to the overseers of the poor for Wytheville township records the medical treatment of the poor including African American citizens. There is also material on the medical treatment of slaves.
(Acc. 981)

div2.head: 358a. FRANCES HAMILTON DOCUMENT
div2.p:
1 item, 1864
A court decree dated February 15, 1864, concerning a group of twenty-six slaves to be divided among the heirs of Mrs. Frances Hamilton, widow of John Hamilton [of Virginia?]. The slaves, valued at $37,750, were divided into seven lots for distribution.
(Acc. 10938)
Guide available at http://ead.lib.virginia.edu/vivaead/published/uva-sc/vivadoc.pl?file=viu01562.xml

div2.head: 359. HAMLET FAMILY PAPERS
div2.p:
26 items, 1805-89
Correspondence and accounts of the Hamlet family of Campbell County. Included is a copy of an October 1, 1878, letter from Thomas Clark to "Brother" Hamlet explaining the expulsion for "grossly immoral conduct" of a slave woman from the Baptist church at Union Hill.
(Acc. 3270-b)

div2.head: 360. HAMOND NAVAL PAPERS
div2.p:
ca. 40 items, 1766-1825, microfilm (M-1722-24)
Records of letters received and sent and orders received and issued directly related to the naval commands and duties of Captain Andrew Snape Hamond and Admiral Graham Eden Hamond of the Royal Navy. Andrew Hamond's papers are concerned principally with British naval operations during the American Revolutionary War. The letterbooks for May and June 1776 mention the use of Afro-American troops by English forces in the Tidewater area.
(McGregor Library Acc. 680)

div2.head: 360a. JEROME S. HANDLER PAPERS
div2.p:
ca. 300 items, 1991-1999
Handler's papers as a member of the Federal Steering Committee to advise the General Services Administration on The African Burial Ground of New York City.
(Acc. 11442-a)
Guide available at http://ead.lib.virginia.edu/vivaead/published/uva-sc/vivadoc.pl?file=viu01226.xml

div2.head: 361. GEORGE C. HANNAH COLLECTION
div2.p:
22 items, 1843-64
Consists of bills of sale from Charlotte County for slaves, with bonds for annual hiring of slaves. Also included is a receipt and valuation, 1864, for a slave impressed by the Confederate Army.
(Acc. 970)

div2.head: 362. HANOVER COUNTY TAX BOOK
div2.p:
1 item, 1836-62 , microfilm (M-657)
A tax book of Hanover County residents kept by Henry C. Bowles. Included is a list of free blacks and a birth list of slaves.
(Acc. 4643)

div2.head: 363. HARRIS-BRADY PAPERS
div2.p:
150 items, 1819-59
The bulk of this collection deals with the slave market around Scottsville and Richmond. Many letters detail the prices of slaves and the time to buy and sell. Most of the correspondence is from Richmond friends and business acquaintances of James Brady of Scottsville, describing the state of the slave market.
(Acc. 38-597)
Guide available at http://ead.lib.virginia.edu/vivaead/published/uva-sc/vivadoc.pl?file=viu00016.xml

div2.head: 364. HARRISON-ROBERTS FAMILY PAPERS
div2.p:
70 items, ca. 1860-80
Consists primarily of letters of E. L. Roberts, a Confederate soldier, to his wife and daughter. A December 18, 1861, letter from Roberts describes a planned slave insurrection in Shreveport and a slave who threatened to kill his Alabama master. A February 21, 1862, letter describes how a slave freed by Union soldiers escaped and returned to the Confederate lines.
(Acc. 10207)

div2.head: 364a. FRANK HARTMAN PHOTOGRAPHS
div2.p:
ca. 150 items, ca. 1935-98
Photographs of historic sites in Charlottesville, Va. including Vinegar Hill (an African American neighborhood) taken before its demolition in 1963 and a few photographs of area African-Americans including Jack Brown, John Henry and Clarence "Tippy" Rhodes.
(Acc. 11405)
Guide available at http://ead.lib.virginia.edu/vivaead/published/uva-sc/vivadoc.pl?file=viu01241.xml

div2.head: 365. JOHN W. HASKINS PAPERS
div2.p:
20 items, 1811-87
Legal and business papers of this Buckingham Court House lawyer. A will of Abraham Neighbours on April 4, 1850, divides his slaves among his survivors.
(Acc. 1173)

div2.head: 365a. MARCUS MORTON HAWES LETTERS
div2.p:
23 items, 1862
Civil War letters of Lt. Marcus Morton Hawes, Quartermaster, 2nd Regiment, Massachusetts Volunteers, from various camps in Virginia and Maryland. Of interest are accounts of his African-American servant Jack Denmark.
(Acc. 11372)
Guide available at http://ead.lib.virginia.edu/vivaead/published/uva-sc/vivadoc.pl?file=viu01269.xml

div2.head: 366. HAWFIELD PLANTATION ACCOUNT BOOKS
div2.p:
ca. 120 items, ca. 1840-1930
The account books, ledgers, and journals of this Orange County plantation. Noted is a photograph of African American and white miners at Mineral Springs, a sulphur mine on the plantation. The account books of the 1840s and 1850s have infrequent references to payment of slaves. There is also a plantation record book kept by the overseer.
(Acc. 2198)

div2.head: 367. HAWKINS FAMILY PAPERS
div2.p:
ca. 300 items, 1769-1849
Primarily the business papers of Laban Hawkins of Prince Edward County. Slave references include tax receipts, doctor's bills, and bills of sale for slaves.
(Acc. 38-142)

div2.head: 367a. A. P. HAYNE LETTER
div2.p:
1 item, July 12, 1844
This letter concerns a shipment of clothes for slaves.
(Acc. 4561)

div2.head: 368. HEMINGS GENEALOGIES
div2.p:
14 items, ca. 1960
Genealogies of the slaves at Monticello, home of Thomas Jefferson, compiled by John Cook Wylie.
(Acc. 6636, -a, -b, -c)

div2.head: 369. ATCHESON HENCH PAPERS
div2.p:
665 items, 1939-48
Papers of Hench as Charlottesville School Board member and member of various committees including curriculum, personnel, education facilities for African Americans, and the special committee to investigate conditions at Jefferson High, containing correspondence, memoranda, meeting dockets, and related material. General topics include school budgets, teachers' salaries, Miller School applicants, school activities and programs, war activities, and statistics. Specific topics of interest are the opening of Lane High School, 1940; petitioning for equalization of salaries for African Americans and whites; and teacher-principal conflicts at Jefferson High School, 1945-46.
(Acc. 927)
Guide available at http://ead.lib.virginia.edu/vivaead/published/uva-sc/vivadoc.pl?file=viu03237.xml

div2.head: 370. ATCHESON HENCH COLLECTION
div2.p:
ca. 5,000 items, ca. 1800-1930
A miscellaneous collection of letters, primarily by Virginians, collected by Hench. Included are some letters discussing slavery and an 1860 deposition and conviction notice of Lafayette Lee for selling liquor to a slave.
(Acc. 4030)
Guide available at http://ead.lib.virginia.edu/vivaead/published/uva-sc/vivadoc.pl?file=viu03308.xml

div2.head: 370a. HENKEL FAMILY PAPERS
div2.p:
ca. 475 items, 1805-1941
Papers of New Market, Shenandoah County, family of Lutheran clergy and printers, operators of the German/English Henkel Press. Contains a letter in German, February 22, 1816, from Jacob Crigler to Dr. Solomon Henkel about a slave ill with dysentery.
(Acc. 8653-f)
Guide available at http://ead.lib.virginia.edu/vivaead/published/uva-sc/vivadoc.pl?file=viu00089.xml

div2.head: 370b. HENKEL FAMILY PAPERS
div2.p:
3 items, 1861-66, electrostatic copies
Documents relating to the estate of Michael Henkle of Pendleton County, Virginia. Included are a "Conditions of Sale," November 18, 1861; a "Conditions of Sale of Negroes," November 19, 1861; and, a receipt, 1866, from the Clerk of Pendleton County.
(Acc. 10828)
Guide available at http://ead.lib.virginia.edu/vivaead/published/uva-sc/vivadoc.pl?file=viu01641.xml

div2.head: 370c. HENKEL FAMILY PAPERS
div2.p:
11 items, 1808-34
Letters to Ambrose Henkel containing a legal notice for the trade of three slave children.
(Acc. 5001-d)

div2.head: 371. HENRY FAMILY PAPERS
div2.p:
15 items, 1766-1866
Included are an 1823 receipt for the purchase of two slaves and a reference in an 1840 letter to a slave who had run away to Canada.
(Acc. 38-473)

div2.head: 372. HARRY HETH PAPERS
div2.p:
ca. 4,000 items, 1763-1841
Business, personal, and legal correspondence and documents of this Richmond and Norfolk area businessman who owned the Black Heath coal pits. Scattered references to slavery include a December 25, 1796, letter about the hire of slaves; a list of slaves, ca. 1810; and an 1821 certificate concerning the apprehension of a runaway slave.
(Acc. 38-114)
Guide available at http://ead.lib.virginia.edu/vivaead/published/uva-sc/vivadoc.pl?file=viu03775.xml

div2.head: 373. HETH-SELDEN FAMILY PAPERS
div2.p:
ca. 220 items, 1725-1925
Papers and personal correspondence of these Richmond-area families. Included is a list of slaves bought at auction on December 15, 1842, with prices.
(Acc. 5071)

div2.head: 373a. ELIZA OSWALD HILL DIARY
div2.p:
1 item, 1860-63
Hill was the mother of sons Frederick J., Thomas S. and Joe, all of whom served in the Confederate Army, and a daughter, Eliza, who was married during the war to Capt. James M. Mason. Fred served with the Starke Cavalry, Co. D of the 28th Regiment Mississippi Volunteers and Tom with the Burt Rifles, Co. K of the 18th Mississippi Volunteers. There are scattered references to slaves at home in North Carolina and references to Noah, a slave traveling with Thomas.
(Acc. 6960)
Guide available at http://ead.lib.virginia.edu/vivaead/published/uva-sc/viu02578.xml.frame

div2.head: 374. HILL FAMILY PAPERS
div2.p:
70 items, ca. 1820-85
Business, legal, and personal papers of this family of King William and King and Queen counties. In the farm diaries kept by Edward Hill for 1860-66 there are numerous entries on slaves including one on May 31, 1863, noting that a slave named William was missing.
(Acc. 6548)

div2.head: 375. HILL, DICKINSON &COMPANY DOCUMENT
div2.p:
1 item, ca. 1860
Printed form used by this company for slave purchases.
(Acc. 2146)

div2.head: 376. HILLYER FAMILY PAPERS
div2.p:
ca. 350 items, ca. 1790-1860 , microfilm (M-209)
Letters between Asa Hillyer of Connecticut and his sons. Most of the correspondence is with his son Shaler of Poplar Grove, Georgia. The social comment mainly concerns Georgia. Included are a slave bill of sale; a "Cotton Book" listing the number of pounds picked by each hand; and a list of slaves "Freed by Abe Lincoln's Proclamation."
(Acc. 2130)

div2.head: 377. WILLIAM SILLIMAN HILLYER PAPERS
div2.p:
ca. 640 items, 1822-1931
Correspondence, military papers, speeches, photographs, printed material, and memorabilia of this Civil War Union officer (1831-1874). Military papers of Hillyer include references to various services by African Americans.
(Acc. 10645)
Guide available at http://ead.lib.virginia.edu/vivaead/published/uva-sc/vivadoc.pl?file=viu03799.xml

div2.head: 377a. FRANCES HODGSON MANUSCRIPT
div2.p:
1 item, 1925
A typescript History of Columbia, Va. which mentions "Free Hill," the site of a settlement of free people of color within the town of Columbia.
(Acc. 6129-a)

div2.head: 378. MARY JANE HOLLADAY JOURNAL
div2.p:
1 item, 1851-61
Most of the journal concerns a trip to famous natural scenic spots in the Valley and Blue Ridge Mountains of Virginia. The account includes a short description of a African American church in Lexington. Also there are entries, 1859 Jan. 12-June 7, and 1861 March, with comments on a child's illness and the burden of owning slaves. The journal was privately printed in 1970 as The Journals of Mary Jane Boggs Holladay. 1851-1861, and portions of it were published in the Virginia Magazine of History and Biography 77 (1969): 78-111.
(Acc. 9703)

div2.head: 379. HOLLAND FAMILY PAPERS
div2.p:
ca. 3,000 items, 1830-70
Consists of the legal papers of Asa Holland, sheriff of Rockingham County. Included are an indenture of October 29, 1847, mentioning the sale of slaves to pay a debt; a bill of sale for a young boy in 1846 for $500; and an 1805-12 cash book which lists the ages of African American children.
(Acc. 902)

div2.head: 379a. HOLLAND AND WHITE FAMILY PAPERS
div2.p:
ca. 525 items, ca. 1775-1859
Correspondence, business and legal papers, genealogical information and miscellaneous printed material of these Fluvanna County Virginia families. There is considerable discussion of slave hiring and slave prices.
(Acc. 11356)
Guide available at http://ead.lib.virginia.edu/vivaead/published/uva-sc/vivadoc.pl?file=viu01275.xml

div2.head: 379b. B. T. HOLLIDAY ACCOUNT
div2.p:
1 item, 1913
Holliday describes joining Roger Preston Chew's battery, the action around Culpeper September 12-13, 1863, hiding out in the federally occupied town, attempt to reach Confederate lines, incarceration at Old Capitol Prison and Point Lookout where prisoners were guarded by U.S. Colored Troops.
(Acc. 4121)

div2.head: 380. HOLLOWAY FAMILY PAPERS
div2.p:
1 item, 1853-56
The medical account journal of Drs. William Amiss and William S. Alsop of Rappahannock County. The accounts include references to medical treatment of slaves such as an entry of April 4, 1852, noting the extraction of a tooth for a "negro woman."
(Acc. 6133-b)

div2.head: 381. HOLSINGER STUDIO COLLECTION
div2.p:
ca. 10,000 items, ca. 1890-1920
Glass and film negatives of this local Charlottesville studio. Included among the many portraits are those of a few local African Americans citizens.
(Acc. 9862)
Photographs available at http://www.lib.virginia.edu/small/collections/holsinger/

div2.head: 382. HOOE-HARRISON LETTERS
div2.p:
20 items, 1832-50
Personal letters primarily from Nathaniel Hooe of King George County to his son-in-law William A. Harrison in Alabama. Some discuss the movement of slaves from Virginia to Alabama, slave labor and the health of slaves.
(Acc. 10548)

div2.head: 382a. PAPERS OF JOHN HOOE
div2.p:
150 items, 1685-1855
Legal and financial papers of John Hooe, Jr., the Hooe family and Richard Foote of Prince William County, Virginia. Included are a slave hire receipt for John from Mrs. Susannah F. Graham (1831 Jan 7) and a report on the estate of Slighter Smith by B. Hooe, listing slaves John, Nace, and Felicia (1842 Dec 22).
(Acc. 11357)
Guide available at http://ead.lib.virginia.edu/vivaead/published/uva-sc/vivadoc.pl?file=viu01259.xml

div2.head: 383. JOHN HOOK AND BOWKER PRESTON PAPERS
div2.p:
146 items, 1787-1882
Personal correspondence, business correspondence, and ledgers of Hook and his son-in-law, Bowker Preston, of Franklin and Bedford
counties. Included are a one-volume ledger, 1851-69, with slave birth records, etc.; a promissory note on a hired-out slave in 1787; and an 1806 warrant for the arrest of a man suspected of harboring a fugitive slave. A September 9, 1834, letter describes the death of a young male slave from cholera; an October 8, 1834, letter describes the sickness of a slave with a bowel complaint; and a December 23, 1835, letter mentions the possibility of hiring out slaves.
(Acc. 247)

div2.head: 384. HOOPER-WRIGHT PAPERS
div2.p:
ca. 2,000 items, ca. 1760-1895
Correspondence and financial records of Nicholas Hooper of Front Royal and Middletown and of George Wright of Middletown. Included is a deed of manumission for Rachael Smith dated December 1799.
(Acc. 4392)

div2.head: 385. MARCUS HOPKINS DIARY
div2.p:
1 item, 1868
The diary of Major Marcus Hopkins, a Civil War soldier from Ohio, who was an official in the Freedmen's Bureau in central Virginia. There is much discussion of the treatment of African Americans.
(Acc. 4656)

div2.head: 385a. MAUDE TERRILL HOPKINS LETTER
div2.p:
1 item, 1926 April 3
Letter from Maude Terrill Hopkins, Keswick, Virginia, to her family, describing in great and vivid detail the funeral of her African-American laundress, Georgia (Anderson) Ashton, the wife of her butler, Nelson Ashton.
(Acc. 11179)
Guide available at http://ead.lib.virginia.edu/vivaead/published/uva-sc/vivadoc.pl?file=viu01458.xml

div2.head: 386. GUSTAVUS RICHARD BROWN HORNER PAPERS
div2.p:
ca. 7,000 items, 1822-91
Personal correspondence, business records, account books, and diaries of this medical doctor who served as ship's surgeon in the U.S. Navy. Many letters written by relatives in Warrenton mention the physical condition of slaves. An entry in the diary for 1880 recounts a lynching near Warrenton.
(Acc. 379)

div2.head: 387. ERASTUS HOSKINS PAPERS
div2.p:
ca. 50 items, 1862-64
Letters of a captain in the Quartermaster Corps of the Confederate army stationed in Mississippi, as well as letters of James Preston Pinkston and a few other family members. A March 17, 1853, letter from Hoskins to his son mentions that "Cousin John" had some sick slaves that had been "pressed" by the government. A letter of March 17, 1864, from Alice Pearson to her aunt reports that the northern soldiers burned the house of Aunt Maryan, the slaves told the soldiers where everything was hidden, and twenty-eight slaves went with the Federal troops.
(Acc. 7478)

div2.head: 387a. WILLIAM S. HOTCHKIN CIVIL WAR DIARIES
div2.p:
2 items, 1864-65
Diaries of this Union soldier and company clerk in Company E, 1st Regiment New York Engineers "Serrell's Engineers." During the period covered by these diaries his regiment served in Virginia during the Army of the James' and the Army of the Potomac's (Union) campaigns against the Army of Northern Virginia (Confederate). An entry for April 16, 1865 notes the arrival of new recruits; the all- African American 25th Corps.
(Acc. 11226)
Guide available at http://ead.lib.virginia.edu/vivaead/published/uva-sc/vivadoc.pl?file=viu01333.xml

div2.head: 388. WILLIAM HOWARD PAPERS
div2.p:
1 item, 1782-1824
A Book of Common Prayer recording the births of slaves of an Albemarle County family, 1782-1824.
(Acc. 7988)

div2.head: 389. HUBARD FAMILY LETTERS
div2.p:
3 items, 1827-54
Two letters to Robert T. Hubard, Sr., in Cumberland County and an 1827 diary probably kept by a family member. The diary has notations on sales of slaves, runaways, and entries for the hire of a free African American to do some "ditching."
(Acc. 4253)

div2.head: 390. HUBARD FAMILY PAPERS
div2.p:
ca. 12,000 items, ca. 1750-1950
Correspondence, legal, and business documents of Robert T. Hubard, Sr., and his descendants of Rosny and Chellowe in Buckingham County. This large family collection has references to slavery including a list of Hubard's slaves and their value at emancipation; a list of Virginia counties having fewer than 500 taxable slaves; a table of the population, both slave and white, of Virginia by decades from 1790 to 1870; and a December 22, 1854, letter from Charles Jones to Robert Hubard written for a slave, Walker, who wanted Hubard to buy his wife who was going to be sold.
(Acc. 8039 -a, -b, -c)
Guide available at http://ead.lib.virginia.edu/vivaead/published/uva-sc/vivadoc.pl?file=viu03531.xml

div2.head: 391. HUBARD FAMILY PAPERS
div2.p:
135 items, 1825-1910
Additional business and personal papers of Robert T. Hubard, Sr. An 1844 letter from Thomas Gilmer to Hubard states "it was useless to deny or doubt that this Negro question is the question on which our fate hangs. We must give up our slaves or give up the Union." A February 14, 1843, letter from William B. Hubard to Robert Hubard speaks of William's desire to acquire a good "body servant."
(Acc. 7093-c,-e,-f)

div2.head: 392. HUBARD FAMILY PAPERS
div2.p:
ca. 5,000 items, 1810-70
Additional papers of this family, chiefly receipts and accounts, detailing every phase of the operation of Rosny, in Buckingham County, and Tye River Quarter, in Nelson County. In several notebooks, 1836-62, Robert T. Hubard, Sr., made notes for the instruction of his sons in farming methods, of his crops produced each year on the plantations, and on his slaves. Post-Civil War material includes many receipts of payment to freedmen for work on his plantations.
(Acc. 8708)

div2.head: 393. HUBARD FAMILY PAPERS
div2.p:
1 item, 1841-46
A register entitled "Negroes in Buckingham" kept by Hubard. The document includes records of slave purchases and deaths.
(Acc. 7786-l, m, -n)

div2.head: 394. HUBARD FAMILY PAPERS
div2.p:
2 items, 1860-65
Included is a Civil War diary kept by Hubard which contains occasional mention of his personal servant, Davy, who accompanied him to the front.
(Acc. 10522)

div2.head: 395. HUBARD FAMILY PAPERS
div2.p:
1 item, January 10, 1864
A letter from A. D. Almond, Howardsville, to A. R. Blakey, Madison Court House, describing conditions on the Hubard farm and mentioning procurement of "linen for all our Negroes."
(Acc. 7786-v)

div2.head: 395a. HUBARD FAMILY PAPERS
div2.p:
ca 100 items, 1767-1907
The papers consist primarily of business letters to Robert T. Hubard from Alfred T. Harris of Harris and Gibson concerning the tobacco trade, stocks, bonds, the Bank of Virginia and orders for supplies. Letters from family and friends include one from George Jones on the sale of slaves in 1848; one from Richard G. Morris on the danger to slavery if the West comes to dominate Congress and a letter from Jesse Jones re slave hires (1822 Aug 24.)
(Acc. 11556-a, -b)
Guide to 11556-a available at http://ead.lib.virginia.edu/vivaead/published/uva-sc/vivadoc.pl?file=viu01218.xml
Guide to 11556-b available at http://ead.lib.virginia.edu/vivaead/published/uva-sc/vivadoc.pl?file=viu01432.xml

div2.head: 396. HUGER FAMILY PAPERS
div2.p:
ca. 50 items, 1773-1863, microfilm (M-1256)
Mainly the papers of Joseph A. Huger, a plantation owner near Savannah, Georgia. A "plantation book" for 1855-61 has detailed information on the numbers of slaves, clothing issued them, births, deaths, and work assigned. Also included is a letter, 24 November 1797, from Harriet Lucas Pinckney, Charleston, S.C., to her stepmother, mentioning a race riot in Charleston "with the French negroes and a letter, 2 September 1822, from Thomas Pinckney, Altamont, S.C., to his sister, Harriott Pinckney Horry, Charleston, S.C., regarding family matters and Francis Kinloch Huger's provisioning of his slaves.
(Acc. 6019)

div2.head: 397. BENJAMIN HUGER PAPERS
div2.p:
ca. 600 items, ca. 1830-70 microfilm (M-2277-79)
Correspondence of this career army officer from South Carolina who served in the Mexican War and the Civil War. There is practically no material on African Americans, but an October 10, 1837, letter from a friend of Huger, Captain Gait, who was serving in the Indian wars in Florida, mentions that a number of African Americans slaves had surrendered to the post in St. Augustine. He thought that the slaves were let loose by the Indians because of a food shortage.
(Acc. 9942)

div2.head: 397a. LANGSTON HUGHES COLLECTION
div2.p:
84 items, 1925-82
Letters and manuscripts of the African American poet and writer. The papers contain manuscripts of the poems "Motto," "Youth," "Snail," "Alabama earth (At Booker Washington's grave)," "Cross" and "Mississippi-1955 ("To the memory of Emmett Till lynched in Mississippi, USA/August 1955")," and reprints of "Low to high" and "High to low." There are forty-four letters, postcards and notes to Youra Qualls and Ina Qualls Steele in which Hughes discusses speaking engagements, travel including Africa in 1962, his writing, and the production of his dramas and eight letters to journalist and N.A.A.C.P. public relations director Henry Lee Moon discuss his work and mention Tuskegee Institute, Zora Neale Hurston, and Alain Locke. (Clifton Waller Barrett Library Acc. 8870, -a,b,c,d,e,f,g and h)
Guides available at http://ead.lib.virginia.edu/vivaead/published/uva-sc/vivadoc.pl?file=viu00742.xml
http://ead.lib.virginia.edu/vivaead/published/uva-sc/vivadoc.pl?file=viu00904.xml

http://ead.lib.virginia.edu/vivaead/published/uva-sc/vivadoc.pl?file=viu00906.xml
http://ead.lib.virginia.edu/vivaead/published/uva-sc/vivadoc.pl?file=viu00907.xml
http://ead.lib.virginia.edu/vivaead/published/uva-sc/vivadoc.pl?file=viu00908.xml
http://ead.lib.virginia.edu/vivaead/published/uva-sc/vivadoc.pl?file=viu00909.xml
http://ead.lib.virginia.edu/vivaead/published/uva-sc/vivadoc.pl?file=viu00987.xml

div2.head: 398. HULLIHEN-STANDARD-KLINE FAMILY PAPERS
div2.p:
ca. 3,500 items, ca. 1740-1940
Business, legal, and personal papers of various Virginia families. An account book of R. C. Ambler, 1831-36, notes medical treatment, including treatment of slaves.
(Acc. 6394)

div2.head: 399. HUME FAMILY LETTERS
div2.p:
3 items, 1836-59
Letters of the Hume family of central Virginia including a letter, 1859 June 30, from Alfred Hume, Grayson City, Texas, to his mother, sends news of family and crops and includes a postscript "My love to all the slaves."
(Acc. 5243)

div2.head: 399a. FONTAINE HUMPHREY ACCOUNT BOOK
div2.p:
2 items, 1819-31
Farm notebooks kept at Palmyra, with references to the health of slaves, etc.
(Acc. 1623)

div2.head: 400. JOHN H. HUNTER PAPERS
div2.p:
86 items, 1861-64
Official correspondence of this CSA surgeon. An October 12, 1861, letter to Hunter requests a pass for a sick African American "teamster."
(Acc. 166)
Guide available at http://ead.lib.virginia.edu/vivaead/published/uva-sc/vivadoc.pl?file=viu03132.xml

div2.head: 400a. HUNTER-GARNETT FAMILY PAPERS
div2.p:
ca. 2,000 items, ca. 1700-1940
Papers of the Hunter-Garnet families consisting primarily of personal, financial, and political correspondence of Muscoe Garnett (1821-1864) and architectural plans, plats, and legal documents concerning the family estate Elmwood. Also included are a daybook of William Hunter containing lists of slaves and clothing and shoe allotments and a daybook of James Mercer and Mercer Garnett as estate administrators containing slave lists and evaluations.
(Acc. 38-45-C)
Guide available at http://ead.lib.virginia.edu/vivaead/published/uva-sc/vivadoc.pl?file=viu03019.xml

div2.head: 401. HUTCHINSON-ABERNETHY GENEALOGY
div2.p:
3 items, 1780-1850
Bible records of the Isaac Hutchinson family, 1781-1850, of Virginia and West Virginia, including his son's slaves.
(Acc. 4735)

div2.head: 402. HUTTON FAMILY PAPERS
div2.p:
ca. 50 items, ca. 1775-1850, microfilm (M-633)
Papers of the Hutton family of Broughton, England, and of Isaac Hutton who emigrated to America in 1814 and lived in Albany, New York. Included are the 1816 minutes of Albany's Sunday Free Schools for Negroes of which Isaac was president.
(Acc. 4325)

div2.head: 403. INDENTURE
div2.p:
1 item, August 19, 1865
An indenture binding a "Free girl of color," Susan, to John F. Hawkins to learn to be a house servant.
(Acc. 6060)

div2.head: 404. RICHARD IRBY PAPERS
div2.p:
ca. 500 items, 1825-1900, microfilm (M-33)
Correspondence and plantation records of this Nottoway County resident. The many slave references include an 1805 memorandum book which is chiefly a record of slaves; accounts of slaves, 1848-53; an 1858 overseer's notebook; 1805 slave records; and plantation records with slave accounts for 1847 and 1854-56.
(Acc. 1194)

div2.head: 405. IRVINE-SAUNDERS FAMILY PAPERS
div2.p:
ca. 3,500 items, 1763-1925
A large collection consisting of the papers of these Campbell and Prince Edward counties families. Among the many business and legal papers and documents are slave sale transactions. The personal letters, especially those of the Civil War period, discuss slaves and slave problems, e.g., an October 7, 1861, letter from Fleming Saunders to his mother concerning troubles with slaves and an October 24, 1863, letter relating news of a murder by a slave. Also included are three special orders involving the U.S. Colored Troops stationed near Petersburg in 1864.
(Acc. 38-33)
Guide available at http://ead.lib.virginia.edu/vivaead/published/uva-sc/vivadoc.pl?file=viu00017.xml

div2.head: 406. WASHINGTON IRVING COLLECTION
div2.p:
11 items, n.d.
Fragments of Washington Irving manuscripts including an incomplete discussion of the case concerning the Spanish slave ship Amistad and the ownership of the ship and cargo following the mutiny of the slaves, as well as a story of a German "who had an amour with a slave."
(Clifton Waller Barrett Library Acc. 6256-aj)

div2.head: 406a. IVY CREEK FOUNDATION PAPERS
div2.p:
ca. 150 items, 1916-88
Papers of the Ivy Creek Foundation of Albemarle County and Charlottesville, Virginia includes legal and financial papers of Mary Carr Greer (1884-1973) and her husband, Conley Greer (? -1956), a local African American family who ran a model farm named "River View" in the Ivy Creek area and copies of photographs of the Carr family.
(Acc. 10770)
Guide available at http://ead.lib.virginia.edu/vivaead/published/uva-sc/vivadoc.pl?file=viu02147.xml

div2.head: 406b. JOSEPH JACKSON DIARY
div2.p:
1 item, 1847 January 1 to June 30
The diary contains legal and social entries including notes of court schedules in Richmond, Henrico, Hanover, Goochland, and Chesterfield Counties. Entries include very brief notations on cases and clients, the sale of a slave, and free papers for a freed woman.
(Acc. 11429)
Guide available at http://ead.lib.virginia.edu/vivaead/published/uva-sc/vivadoc.pl?file=viu01251.xml

div2.head: 407. PHOEBE JACKSON ACCOUNT BOOK
div2.p:
1 item, 1843-45
The account book of this African American Petersburg resident who performed medical services such as "cupping" and "leeching." She noted many visits to servants.
(Acc. 2120)

div2.head: 408. LOUIS I. JAFFE PAPERS
div2.p:
ca. 5,600 items, 1914-50
Personal and business correspondence of the editor of the Norfolk Virginian-Pilot. There is correspondence with Governor Harry F. Byrd, Sr., concerning a proposed antilynching bill and with such prominent Afro-Americans as Walter White and P. B. Young, editor of the Norfolk Journal and Guide.
(Acc. 9924-a thru 9924-o)
Guides available at http://ead.lib.virginia.edu/vivaead/published/uva-sc/viu03889.xml.frame

div2.head: 409. LOUIS I. JAFFE PAPERS
div2.p:
430 items, 1931-49
Articles, reports, speeches, news clippings, pamphlets, and other printed material, photographs, and some correspondence, all pertaining to subjects of concern to Jaffe as editor of the Virginian- Pilot. The chief topic is the use by Norfolk Polytechnic College (Virginia State University) of a vacated nurses home at the former St. Vincent's Hospital in a predominantly African American section of Norfolk. Also of interest are materials on the Southern Regional Council including minutes of the executive committee and board meetings and copies of The Southern Frontier and The New South. Other topics include suffrage reform, particularly in regard to the poll tax; World War II, especially the military buildup in Norfolk and attendant problems; Virginia politics and the Byrd machine; Norfolk civic issues; public health; and Judaism. Of unusual interest is a letter from Bravid W. Harris about Third World democracy and Liberia.
(Acc. 9924-k)
Guide available at http://ead.lib.virginia.edu/vivaead/published/uva-sc/vivadoc.pl?file=viu02203.xml

div2.head: 410. EDWARD WILSON JAMES PAPERS
div2.p:
ca. 2,000 items, 1635-1906
Records of the James family of lower Norfolk County consisting mostly of legal and business records. Occasional slave bills of sale are included, such as an 1829 bill for the sale of a woman, as are 1784 lists of tithables and taxable property for various Tidewater districts.
(Acc. 38-402)

div2.head: 411. JAMES RIVER AND KANAWHA CANAL COMPANY PAPERS
div2.p:
1 vol., 1859-80
Minutes of stockholders' meetings that in March 1865 mention the use of African American labor to repair locks destroyed by Sheridan.
(Acc. 10421-a)

div2.head: 411a. JANNEY FAMILY PAPERS
div2.p:
2750 items, 1755-1944
Papers of the Janney and allied families of Gilmour and Pollock consisting of personal and political correspondence, financial and legal papers, genealogical material and photographs, particularly of John Janney of Loudoun County, Va. The papers cover Janney's legal practice, his career as a Whig politician, a member of the Virginia House of Delegates, and president of Virginia's secession convention. Of interest in Janney's financial and legal papers is a slave bill of sale for one Harriet Jackson. Papers of Solomon Parsons contain an 1829 letter from a slave to "Dear Master." Political letters of 1849 discuss the issue of slavery and the new territories. There is a June 20, 1829 letter from Baldwin Bradford, Warrenton, to Parsons, concerning an enclosed letter dictated and marked by an African-American woman, Nancy Jackson, requesting another African-American woman, Patsy Johnson, to give ten dollars to Solomon Parsons after her death. It notes that Samuel Johnson, husband of Patsy Johnson, is a free African American man who lives with Bradford. The enclosure, February 9, 1829, [Nancy Jackson] to "Dear Master" states her intentions. Letters of July 14 and July 18, 1829 between Parsons and Thomas W. Hewitt concern the John Coffey estate and an inquiry into the sale of the slaves and whether or not they brought as much as they were worth.
(Acc. 8409, a,b,c)
Guide available at http://ead.lib.virginia.edu/vivaead/published/uva-sc/vivadoc.pl?file=viu02228.xml

div2.head: 412. JARRETT, BYNUM, ETC., FAMILY PAPERS
div2.p:
ca. 100 items, 1813-96
Largely private correspondence of a number of North Carolina and other southern families. Many of the letters discuss slaves: prices, runaways, etc. A May 30, 1838, letter to Major Thomas B. Cooper from George Phillips mentions a slave's attempt to kill an overseer.
(Acc. 1030)

div2.head: 413. ISAAC JEFFERSON COLLECTION
div2.p:
2 items, ca. 1847
The manuscript reminiscences of this Monticello slave once owned by Thomas Jefferson as told to Charles Campbell, printed as Memoirs of a Monticello Slave (Charlottesville: University of Virginia Press, 1951), and a daguerreotype of Isaac Jefferson.
(McGregor Library Acc. 2041)

div2.head: 413a. JEFFERSON OPERA HOUSE PHOTOGRAPH
div2.p:
1 item, 1908
Photograph of this Charlottesville building in ruins after a fire. Shown are bystanders in front of the building including a number of African Americans.
(Acc. 7037)

div2.head: 414. THOMAS JEFFERSON PAPERS
div2.p:
ca. 3,300 items, 1732-1826
The Jefferson Papers contain many references to slaves and slavery. A published calendar to the collection is available: The Jefferson Papers of the University of Virginia, compiled by Constance E. Thurlow et al. (Charlottesville: University Press of Virginia, 1973).
Guide available at http://ead.lib.virginia.edu/vivaead/published/uva-sc/vivadoc.pl?file=viu00007.xml

div2.head: 414a. JAMES WELDON JOHNSON COLLECTION
div2.p:
1 item, ca. 1920
Signed sepia photograph of James Weldon Johnson (1871-1938), African-American writer and one of the founders of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored Persons (NAACP) and its secretary from 1916 to 1930. Johnson is shown sitting against a wooden post. Signed on the bottom margin in blue ink "James Weldon Johnson."
(Barrett Library Acc. 11072)

div2.head: 414b. JOSEPH W. JOHNSON DIARY
div2.p:
1 item, 1878-79
Farm diary and other accounts of this Belmont, Spotsylvania, Co., Va. resident containing entries and hiring records for freedmen.
(Acc. 4696)

div2.head: 414c. JOHNSTON FAMILY PAPERS
div2.p:
170 items, 1781-1876
Financial and legal papers and family correspondence of the Johnston Family, of Rockbridge County, Virginia. Topics of interest include regret over the sale of a slave and the necessity of keeping a young family member away from the influence of slave children, 1851; a contested will involving three plantations and thirty five slaves, 1853; and slave hiring, 1854.
(Acc. 11295)
Guide available at http://ead.lib.virginia.edu/vivaead/published/uva-sc/vivadoc.pl?file=viu01364.xml

div2.head: 414d. JAMES D. JOHNSTON PAPERS
div2.p:
ca. 500 items, 1811-1911
Personal and legal correspondence, business and financial records of this lawyer and Virginia state delegate of Pearisburg, Giles County, Va. Included is a brief mention of slave sales in 1856.
(Acc. 11234)
Guide available at http://ead.lib.virginia.edu/vivaead/published/uva-sc/vivadoc.pl?file=viu01302.xml

div2.head: 415. JOHNSTON-WRIGHT FAMILY PAPERS
div2.p:
625 items, 1858-1900
The collection consists chiefly of personal account books, daybooks, journals, ledgers, business correspondence, and other papers of James Johnston, postmaster at Hardware, ca. 1885-90, general merchant, and owner of the Green Mountain Mill, Albemarle. An 1891 letter from Thomas E. Locke, a minister, about his services and salary and an 1885 letter from William Garland to Joshua Martin about a "Yankee carpetbagger" causing trouble among African Americans are of note.
(Acc. 38-8)
Guide available at http://ead.lib.virginia.edu/vivaead/published/uva-sc/vivadoc.pl?file=viu00769.xml

div2.head: 416. JONES FAMILY PAPERS
div2.p:
53 items, 1790-1820
A collection of bills, receipts, and legal documents of Isaac and Thomas Jones, merchants of Fredericksburg. Included is a November 2, 1795, bill of sale for a slave belonging to William True.
(Acc. 2428-a)
Guide available at http://ead.lib.virginia.edu/vivaead/published/uva-sc/viu03067.xml.frame

div2.head: 417. LEROI JONES COLLECTION
div2.p:
27 items, 1960-63
Letters and postcards of this contemporary African American author to Diane Di Prima.
(Barrett Library Acc. 7884)

div2.head: 417a. LOUIS D. JONES PAPERS
div2.p:
835 items, 1830-1946
Business and personal papers pertaining to the Jones and LeGrand families of Buckingham and Prince Edward Counties, Va. including correspondence concerning the jailing of three hired slaves for stealing, December 24, 1860, and slave hiring.
(Acc. 11431)
Guide available at http://ead.lib.virginia.edu/vivaead/published/uva-sc/vivadoc.pl?file=viu01224.xml

div2.head: 417b. JORDAN FAMILY COLLECTION
div2.p:
25 items, 1875-1966
The Jordan family were Quakers residing in James City, Isle of Wight, Nansemond, and Halifax counties. The papers consist of correspondence, family histories, a genealogical chart, and Bible records containing birth and death dates for both family and slaves. Most of the material pertains to the descendants of 1609 immigrants Samuel and Cicely Jourdan (Jordan), and particularly to the family of Dr. Clement Hobson Jordan.
(Acc. 10617-e)
Guide available at http://ead.lib.virginia.edu/vivaead/published/uva-sc/vivadoc.pl?file=viu01765.xml

div2.head: 417c. SAMUEL MAY JOSEPH COLLECTION
div2.p:
3 items, 1822-1871
Contains a letter Samuel Joseph May to Daniel Webster 1842 March 28 ALS, 2 p. [Letter has a copy of the resolution passed at a meeting of Plymouth County abolitionists on March 25, 1842 which demands that Edward Everett, American minister to the Court of St. James, disobey Secretary of State Webster's instruction requesting that the British surrender the slaves on the Creole (Creole Slave Case 1841).]
(Acc. 7202)

div2.head: 417d. KEELING, ROWE AND FARISH FAMILY PAPERS
div2.p:
3 items, 1765-1877
Papers of the families of Virginia [Spotsylvania county?] including a copy of The Book of Common Prayer, with 11 pages documenting births (including slave births).
(Acc. 11144)
Guide available at http://ead.lib.virginia.edu/vivaead/published/uva-sc/vivadoc.pl?file=viu01410.xml

div2.head: 418. C. BRIAN KELLY PAPERS
div2.p:
ca. 2,500 items, 1959-78
Staff writer for the Washington Star, Kelly covered Virginia politics, particularly election campaigns, and activities of the General Assembly. Politically related topics in the collection include the desegregation of Prince Edward County schools.
(Acc. 10566)
Guide available at http://ead.lib.virginia.edu/vivaead/published/uva-sc/vivadoc.pl?file=viu03887.xml

div2.head: 419. KELLY-NORRIS PAPERS
div2.p:
16 items, 1812-38
Letters primarily from John Kelly, a retail merchant in Charlottesville, to Opie Norris, a commission merchant in Richmond. A March 19, 1813, letter from Kelly to Norris mentions a slave who seemed to be an habitual runaway.
(Acc. 3928-a)

div2.head: 419a. JAMES LAWSON KEMPER PAPERS
div2.p:
ca. 11,800 items, 1823-95
Correspondence and the financial, legal, and political papers of James Lawson Kemper, lawyer, Confederate general, and governor of Virginia (1874-1877). Some correspondence during his governorship concerns his veto of the Petersburg charter, which would have removed political power from African Americans.
(Acc. 4098)
Guide available at http://ead.lib.virginia.edu/vivaead/published/uva-sc/viu03342.xml.frame

div2.head: 420. KENNON PAPERS
div2.p:
ca. 950 items, 1808-1903
Personal and business papers of William Henry Kennon and his son, William Upshur Kennon, of Norwood, Powhatan County. A two-volume journal, 1808-83, of Beverly Randolph's Powhatan County plantation contains slave records. The voluminous general correspondence probably contains reference to slaves and slavery.
(Acc. 38-95)
Guide available at http://ead.lib.virginia.edu/vivaead/published/uva-sc/vivadoc.pl?file=viu03020.xml

div2.head: 421. KENTUCKY SLAVE CONTRACT
div2.p:
1 item, October 3, 1814, photocopy
Bill of sale, original at the University of Kentucky Library, between W. Crawford and James Pipen of Nicholas County, Kentucky, authorizing the sale of a female slave for $350 from Pipen to Crawford.
(Acc. 4679)

div2.head: 421a. KENTUCKY STUD BOOK
div2.p:
5 items, 1860-1886
Kept by Duncan Gibson of Woodford County, Kentucky, 1860-1866, for four estates, Hartland, Oakland, Magnolia, and Ridgeland, belonging to the Gibson family. Records for two of the estates also list slave holdings.
(Acc. 11280)
Guide available at http://ead.lib.virginia.edu/vivaead/published/uva-sc/vivadoc.pl?file=viu01353.xml

div2.head: 422. KENT FAMILY PAPERS
div2.p:
7 items, 1760-1912 photocopies
Contains business papers and Bible records of the Kent, Meux, and McGavock families of Bedford County. An indenture, October 17, 1805, signs over slaves and other property of Jane Quirk of Montgomery County to Joseph Kent of Wythe County.
(Acc. 8994)

div2.head: 423. KENT-HUNTER FAMILY PAPERS
div2.p:
ca. 350 items, 1823-1919, microfilm (M-608)
Papers of Robert M. Kent of Louisa Court House and the Hunter, Thompson, and Lane families of Louisa County. Three letters, 1851 and 1853, to Robert M. Kent from William H. Starr of the American Colonization Society discuss the emigration of ex-slaves to Liberia. Among the correspondence of the Thompson family, 1823-51, are letters describing the selling of slaves.
(Acc. 4165)

div2.head: 424. JAMES J. KILPATRICK PAPERS
div2.p:
ca. 40,000 items, ca. 1940
Business and personal papers of James J. Kilpatrick, newspaper editor and syndicated columnist. There is much correspondence concerning Virginia's position on integration of the public school system during the 1950s and 1960s.
(Acc. 6626)
Guide available at http://ead.lib.virginia.edu/vivaead/published/uva-sc/vivadoc.pl?file=viu02948.xml and http://ead.lib.virginia.edu/vivaead/published/uva-sc/vivadoc.pl?file=viu02949.xml

div2.head: 425. SIGISMUNDA STRIBLING KIMBALL JOURNAL
div2.p:
1 item, 1860-63
Journal of this woman from Mount Jackson in the Shenandoah Valley recording daily farm business. There are frequent references to slaves ("hands") and a detailed account concerning the return of runaway slaves with Union troops to rescue their wives and families.
(Acc. 2534)

div2.head: 426. KING AND QUEEN COUNTY TAX BOOKS
div2.p:
4 items, 1819-21
Three tax books and a fee book which record taxes on slaves and the taxation of free African Americans.
(Acc. 4414)

div2.head: 426a. KING FAMILY PAPERS
div2.p:
125 items, 1811-90
Consists mainly of letters, 1861-64, of William King of Lynchburg, with the Confederate artillery, to his wife Annie K. Leftwitch King, regarding camp life around Manassas and Fairfax, Va., and the Battle of Bull Run. In the family legal and business papers is a document dividing the estate of William King III which includes the names and values of eight slaves.
(Acc. 6682)

div2.head: 427. KLIPSTEIN FAMILY PAPERS
div2.p:
330 items, 1899-1984
Chiefly correspondence of Dr. Philip Klipstein of Fauquier County. Included are receipts for the hire of African American women, discussion of a court case involving the ownership of slaves taken from Virginia to Kentucky, and material on the Baltimore Colonization Society.
(Acc. 2234)

div2.head: 427a. WILLIAM HENRY LAIRD PAPERS
div2.p:
ca 1400 items, 1940-47
Chiefly personal correspondence of Reverend William H. Laird, pastor of St. Paul's Episcopal Church, Charlottesville, while serving as Chaplain of the 8th Evacuation Hospital Unit which was composed of University of Virginia medical personnel. Letters from Italy in 1944 December 10 and x1945 January 5 discuss the issue of blood donations to the Red Cross Blood Bank and whether it was kept separate according to the race of the donor.
(Acc. 999-a)
Guide available at http://ead.lib.virginia.edu/vivaead/published/uva-sc/viu03182.xml.frame

div2.head: 427b. LANGHORNE FAMILY PAPERS
div2.p:
55 items, 1823-68
Pertaining chiefly to the family of Chiswell Dabney Langhorne including Irene (Mrs. Charles Dana Gibson) and (Mrs. Robert Gould Shaw, later Lady Astor, wife of Waldorf Astor) of Albemarle County Virginia. Included are letters to Nancy Lancaster (formerly Nancy Keene Perkins Tree) from "Mirador" Servants 1930-1957 and photographs of servants of the Langhorne family at "Mirador." (Acc. 10758)
Guide available at http://ead.lib.virginia.edu/vivaead/published/uva-sc/vivadoc.pl?file=viu01725.xml

div2.head: 427c. ELIZABETH COLES LANGHORNE PAPERS
div2.p:
43 items, 1975-86
Includes a Hemings family genealogy tracing descendants of Betty Hemings and several versions of her article "The Black Family at Monticello."
(Acc 7942-e)
Guide available at http://ead.lib.virginia.edu/vivaead/published/uva-sc/viu02336.xml.frame

div2.head: 428. ROBERT LARIMER PAPERS
div2.p:
12 items, 1863-65
A small group of letters, documents, and diaries of this Union soldier in the Ohio Volunteer Infantry who was in Virginia during the Civil War. The diaries have occasional references to freed slaves and African American troops.
(Acc. 38-219)

div2.head: 429. LEWIS LATANE DAYBOOK
div2.p:
1 item, 1707-94, microfilm (M-622)
A daybook of Lewis Latane, a Huguenot immigrant who lived in Manakin, Goochland County. It contains many names and birth dates of slaves.
(Acc. 4348)

div2.head: 430. LATANE FAMILY PAPERS
div2.p:
ca. 710 items, 1650-1898
Personal, legal, military, and business correspondence and accounts of this family of Essex County. A number of letters and documents refer to individual slaves and slavery in general, including a December 10, 1772, letter from Samuel Peachey to William Latane asking that a young male slave be sent to him to learn the blacksmith trade; a 1794 circular referring to the transportation of slaves from Africa to the West Indies; and several slave inventories and bills of sale.
(Acc. 6490)
Guide available at http://ead.lib.virginia.edu/vivaead/published/uva-sc/vivadoc.pl?file=viu01046.xml

div2.head: 431. THOMAS LAW PAPERS
div2.p:
49 items, 1808-34
Correspondence of this Englishman who immigrated to the United States and became prominent in Washington society. In a November 1, 1824, letter he discussed emigration of American slaves to Haiti, and on October 1, 1828, he wrote of the emancipation of slaves.
(McGregor Library Acc. 2801)
Guide available at http://ead.lib.virginia.edu/vivaead/published/uva-sc/vivadoc.pl?file=viu03292.xml

div2.head: 431a. LEBANON PRESBYTERIAN CHURCH PAPERS
div2.p:
15 items, 1755-1903, microfilm (M-232)
Papers of this Albemarle County church include proceedings, 1755-1786, of the Hanover Presbytery, pertaining to church affairs. Also included is a session book, 1824-1870, of the Lebanon and Mountain Plains Church, concerning collection and distribution of financial resources, church services, and church members' conduct, including list of church members, with notation of African-American members, and list of baptized children.
(Acc. 2625, -a, -b, & 832)

div2.head: 431b. CHARLES LEE LETTER
div2.p:
1 item, May 2, 1813
Letter from Charles Lee, Alexandria, to William Broadfoot, with legal advice concerning compensation for the seizure of a ship apparently used as a slave trader.
(Acc. 38-112-C)

div2.head: 431c. FRANCIS LIGHTFOOT LEE LETTER
div2.p:
1 item, December 8, 1816
In a letter to James H. Hove, Lee, writing from "Sully," sets the price and terms for the sale of his estate, and lists the property including "seven likely male slaves, two young women...." On the second page the male slaves are valued at $500 each and the females at $350 each.
(Acc. 6446)

div2.head: 432. RICHARD BLAND LEE LETTER
div2.p:
7 items, 1798, 1903-23
A letter from Richard Bland Lee to Edmund Jennings Lee; five letters from Jean Jules Jusserand to Frederic A. Delano; and a pamphlet, Patronage National des Blesses. The December 13, 1798, Lee letter concerns an apparent confusion over the sale and expected emancipation of a slave, Caroline.
(Acc. 9971-a)

div2.head: 432a. RICHARD BLAND LEE LETTER
div2.p:
1 item, February 16, 1829
Lee wrote this letter to Philip R. Fendall concerning the correct legal procedure that would allow him to purchase the slaves belonging to a Mr. Gale. Lee wrote this letter while serving garrison duty at the United States Army Arsenal near Pikesville, Maryland.
(Acc. 10851)
Guide available at http://ead.lib.virginia.edu/vivaead/published/uva-sc/vivadoc.pl?file=viu01625.xml

div2.head: 433. LEESBURG FAMILY PAPERS
div2.p:
ca. 10,000 items, ca. 1650-1960
Business, legal, and personal papers of five interrelated Loudoun County families: the Fendall, Harrison, Miller, Murray, and Jones families. Included are lists and descriptions, 1823-30, of slaves belonging to Miss McCall, whose estate was settled by Walter Jones. The diary of Sterling Murray, 1812-16, includes a fine description of a trip to Havana, Cuba, by the slaves on a sugar plantation. Also mentioned are the slave trade in Havana and an incident in which an African chief boarded a slave ship and removed all the slaves in retaliation for the abduction of some of his warriors.
(Acc. 8557-a)

div2.head: 434. GENERAL JOEL LEFTWICH PAPERS
div2.p:
ca. 2,500 items, 1780-1890
Correspondence, financial and legal papers, printed material, and miscellaneous related papers of this Bedford County businessman and farmer. Tax statements for the year 1802 depict Joel Leftwich as the owner of seven slaves for which he paid a tax of $13.90 (the tax for Pilgrim was ten dollars). Other documents pertain to the hiring of his slaves and the legal dispensations of them for the payment of debts, 1796-1826. Among these legal documents is a complaint against a slave named Bill who was owned by Jesse Leftwich; the slave had shot a dog belonging to his owner's brother Augustine, and Joel Leftwich, as justice of the peace, issued a warrant for his arrest.
(Acc. 38-32)
Guide available at http://ead.lib.virginia.edu/vivaead/published/uva-sc/vivadoc.pl?file=viu00666.xml

div2.head: 434a. FRANK LEMOYNE COLLECTION
div2.p:
7 items, 1836-65
Electrostatic copies of five letters, 1862-1865, of Frank LeMoyne, a Union Army physician stationed in Virginia during the Civil War, as an assistant surgeon in the 9th Pennsylvania Reserves Corps. Also included is a subscription list of pledges for anti-slavery publications.
(Acc. 11136)
Guide available at http://ead.lib.virginia.edu/vivaead/published/uva-sc/vivadoc.pl?file=viu01402.xml

div2.head: 435. JOHN LEVERING CIVIL WAR MEMOIRS
div2.p:
2 items, 1887-91
Memoirs of the Civil War experiences of this former officer of the 2d Brigade of the Indiana Volunteer Militia. He made scattered references to African American troops and on pages 489-90 described Cherokee Union troops at Fort Gibson, Florida, who brought their African American slaves into the ranks with them.
(Acc. 10113)

div2.head: 436. LEWIS FAMILY PAPERS
div2.p:
ca. 200 items, ca. 1800-1860
Mainly business papers of this Essex County family. The many slave entries include a May 18, 1810, letter from Erasmus Jones to Vernon Lewis describing the sale and swap of a slave, Esther, who wanted to remain with her husband and an inventory of the slaves of the estate of Dr. John Lewis.
(Acc. 1525)
Guide available at http://ead.lib.virginia.edu/vivaead/published/uva-sc/vivadoc.pl?file=viu00026.xml

div2.head: 436a. LEWIS FAMILY PAPERS
div2.p:
12 items, ca. 1770-1864
Letters of this Albemarle County family which includes an 1864 December 2 letter from Thomas Fielding Lewis to his father, John M. Lewis, noting among other subjects illnesses among family slaves.
(Acc. 11253)
Guide available at http://ead.lib.virginia.edu/vivaead/published/uva-sc/vivadoc.pl?file=viu01342.xml

div2.head: 437. LEWIS, ANDERSON, AND MARKS FAMILY PAPERS
div2.p:
ca. 800 items, ca. 1770-1900
Personal, business, and legal correspondence of these Albemarle County residents. Included are an April 6, 1778, letter from an elderly slave to Lucy Marks and numerous documents and letters concerning slavery, as well as a series of letters in 1827-28 from Sidney Reese, a member of Congress, to Reuben Lewis describing the payment of a debt to Reese in the form of slaves.
(Acc. 9041)

div2.head: 438. JAMES H. LEWIS PAPERS
div2.p:
30 items, ca. 1840-65
Business papers of this Albemarle County resident. There appears to be only one reference to slavery, a document in which the births of slaves are recorded.
(Acc. 9946)

div2.head: 439. JUDSON A. LEWIS PAPERS
div2.p:
8 items, 1883-95
Letterbooks and scrapbooks of Judson A. Lewis, U.S. consul to Sierra Leone in West Africa, and a diary kept by his wife which mentions Stanley (William Stanley?). The letterbooks and the diary are filled with commentary about Africans.
(Acc. 7665)

div2.head: 439a. LAWRENCE LEWIS LETTER
div2.p:
1 item, 1803
A letter from William Kercheval, overseer for the Frederick County plantation to Lewis relating details on the success of a machine for wheat, illness among the plantation slaves, and the need for nails for weatherboarding.
(Acc. 9096-ad)

div2.head: 440. PHILIP LIGHTFOOT ACCOUNT BOOKS
div2.p:
Include ledgers, 1781-1865, kept by Philip Lightfoot (d. 1786), Philip Lightfoot (1784-1865), and John B. Lightfoot (b. 1814), providing records of personal finances and finances of plantations near Cedar Creek and Port Royal, Caroline County, Va.; daybooks, 1816-1865, containing information for financing of specific agricultural operations and plantation management; and a slave record book, ca. 1850-1872, recording distribution of shoes and clothing, and freedmen's wages.
(Acc. 592)

div2.head: 440a. WILLIAM M. LIGHTSEY PAPERS
div2.p:
30 items, 1959-60
The collection contains some correspondence, executive board minutes, a budget Jan.-Mar. 1959 and a financial report, Sept. 1959, of the executive secretary of the Virginia Committee for Public Schools. Also included is an account by Francis Pickens Miller of the reaction in Charlottesville to the court order striking down massive resistance.
(Acc. 9145, -a)

div2.head: 440b. THOMAS J. LINNEKIN LETTERBOOK
div2.p:
1 item, 1862-63
Captain's letter copy book from the U.S. Steamer Currituck. The volume contains copies of Linnekin's routine correspondence and reports from his station on the Rappahannock to superior officers including Commodore Andrew Allen Harwood and Navy Secretary Gideon Welles. Of interest are entries mentioning deserters, deaths in the crew, contrabands as informants, and capture of Confederate vessels.
(Acc. 15134)

div2.head: 441. GEORGE LONG COLLECTION
div2.p:
2 items, 1862 and 1868
In an August 27, 1868, letter to George Tutwiler, Long expressed hope that European peasants would emigrate to the United States and eliminate the need for African American labor.
(Acc. 1230)

div2.head: 442. LONGDALE IRON CO. PHOTOGRAPHS
div2.p:
3 items, 1889-1914
Photograph of African American laborers constructing the Longdale Furnace in Alleghany County in 1889.
(Acc. 9515-a)

div2.head: 442a. GENERAL STORE AT FREDERICKS HALL, LOUISA COUNTY, VIRGINIA RECORDS
div2.p:
4 items, 1736-1859
Bound manuscript volumes that recorded the transactions of patrons of a general store located at Fredericks Hall, Louisa County, Virginia. Page 328 in the first ledger is entitled Negroes.
(Acc. 4201)
Guide available at http://ead.lib.virginia.edu/vivaead/published/uva-sc/viu03366.xml.frame

div2.head: 443. LOUTHAN AND SEAY FAMILY PAPERS
div2.p:
ca. 1,500 items, 1830-60
Mainly legal and business papers of these and other families chiefly from Caroline County. There are infrequent slavery references, such as an 1849 doctor's account which notes a visit to a sick "Negro woman"; a January 1, 1819, receipt for hire of a slave; an 1856-57 journal of John Hackett containing many entries on sales of slaves and expenditures for hiring out slaves; and an 1856 account sheet noting payment for medical treatment of slaves.
(Acc. 1800)

div2.head: 443a. MARS AND JESSE LUCAS LETTERS FROM LIBERIA
div2.p:
8 items, 1820-1836
Electrostatic copies of letters, 1822, 1830-1831, and 1836, between the Heaton Family, Loudoun County, Virginia, and Mars and Jesse Lucas, emancipated slaves living in Liberia, Africa. One of the letters from Mars Lucas, Caldwell, Liberia, describes the voyage of the fifty-eight immigrants, who all arrived in good health, from Hampton Roads to Liberia.
(Acc. 11180)
Guide available at http://ead.lib.virginia.edu/vivaead/published/uva-sc/vivadoc.pl?file=viu01377.xml

div2.head: 444. LUNENBURG COUNTY DOCUMENT
div2.p:
1 item, 1814
A list of free blacks.
(Acc. 2376)

div2.head: LYBROOK FAMILY LETTERS
div2.p:
5 items, 1833-43
Letters of Philip and Sally Lybrook of Giles County, to their brother, Henry C. Lybrook, Cassopolis, Cass County, Michigan, regarding sales of slaves and estates, slave children as workers, an 1843 smallpox outbreak, and family news.
(Acc. 11087)
Guide available at http://ead.lib.virginia.edu/vivaead/published/uva-sc/vivadoc.pl?file=viu01488.xml

div2.head: 445. LYNCHBURG COMMON COUNCIL LEDGER
div2.p:
2 items, 1787-1838, microfilm (M-567)
The ledger of the Proceedings of the Trustees of the Town of Lynchburg and the ledger of the Proceedings of the Mayor, Aldermen, and Common Council of the Corporation of Lynchburg. A few entries concern slavery, such as the amount of revenue in 1837 attributable to slaves and a series of entries in the Common Council proceedings in 1827-28 about a slave named Joe who was apparently purchased by the corporation and eventually sold to a New Orleans merchant.
(Acc. 4033)

div2.head: 445a. LYNCHBURG SLAVE SMALLPOX DOCUMENT
div2.p:
