1 item, November 13, 1836
Issued by Lynchburg mayor Pleaseants Labby under authority of the town council, this document orders a male slave (property of a resident named Reynolds) infected with smallpox be taken to the house of M. Davis [Dr. Micajah Davis, Jr.?] for treatment. The document is directed to town sergeant Henry Dunnington for enforcement; it also attests the slave's medical expenses will be paid by the town.
(Acc. 11294)
Guide available at http://ead.lib.virginia.edu/vivaead/published/uva-sc/vivadoc.pl?file=viu01363.xml

div2.head: 446. WILLIAM GORDON McCABE PAPERS
div2.p:
1,016 items, 1757-1920
Correspondence with prominent scholars, U.S. and British literary figures, and Civil War veterans. Topics include the Civil War, the Confederacy, World War I, and African American suffrage.
(Acc. 10568)
Guide available at http://ead.lib.virginia.edu/vivaead/published/uva-sc/vivadoc.pl?file=viu01808.xml

div2.head: 446a. TRACY W. MCGREGOR AUTOGRAPH COLLECTION
div2.p:
1,725 items, ca. 1599-1947
The miscellaneous autograph additions to the Tracy W. McGregor Library of both literary and historical documents, letters, autographs, and bound volumes including references to slavery such as from the legal papers of the Eskridge-Gerard families concerning property in Westmoreland County and Northumberland County, a bill of sale for slaves (1738); account Sales of the Estate of William Flood, 1775, Westmoreland County, Virginia, including slaves; Thomas Jefferson Randolph to Nahum Capen discussing the deep fear of a slave insurrection caused by the raid of John Brown upon its citizens (1873 Apr 11) and Alexander Wilson, to Daniel H. Miller, a Philadelphia ironmonger, Dec 24, 1808 describes part of his canvassing tour from Maine to Georgia to get subscribers for his American Ornithology, focusing on Maryland and Washington, D.C., where he mentions the variety of characters he encountered, the wretched condition of slaves along his journey.
(Acc. 10547)
Guide available at http://ead.lib.virginia.edu/vivaead/published/uva-sc/viu01142.xml.frame

div2.head: 447. ALEXANDER MacKAY-SMITH PAPERS
div2.p:
104 items, 1928-58
Included in the papers of this musician are several concert programs. Among them is one for the performance of the Fisk Jubilee Singers, Fisk University, Nashville, Tennessee, May 5, 1925, in Paris, France. The program included "Steal Away," "Go Down Moses," and "Swing Low."
(Acc. 2515-b)

div2.head: 447a. HENRY MCWANE STATEMENT
div2.p:
1 item, 1960?
Statement to an inter-racial commission in Lynchburg by McWane, Lynchburg Foundry Company president and chairman of "the first group of white and black citizens ever set up in Lynchburg to discuss common racial problems." He reminds the commission that their mission is one of reconciliation in which they are to
1. "re-establish and strengthen communication between people of the Negro and Caucasian races"
2. "provide an officially constituted hearing place...to which any citizen may refer problems in the area of race relations..."
3. "deal realistically with...specific civic situations which may arise" and avoid taking issues to court.
(Acc. 6434)

div2.head: 448. MADDEN FAMILY PAPERS
div2.p:
ca. 200 items, ca. 1760-1870, microfilm (M-589)
Correspondence, business papers, legal documents, etc., of a free black family from Culpeper and Rappahanock counties. Included are genealogical data, deeds of land, and correspondence attesting to the character of the Maddens.
(Acc. 4120)
Guide available at http://ead.lib.virginia.edu/vivaead/published/uva-sc/vivadoc.pl?file=viu02941.xml

div2.head: 449. MADISON FAMILY DOCUMENT
div2.p:
1 item, December 6, 1848
Sales records from the estate of William Madison containing records of the value of his slaves.
(Acc. 8607-a)

div2.head: 450. JAMES MADISON PAPERS
div2.p:
305 items, ca. 1765-1836
Personal correspondence including a letter from Madison to Jedidiah Morse answering a series of questions (not included) on slavery.
(Acc. 8347)
Guide available at http://ead.lib.virginia.edu/vivaead/published/uva-sc/vivadoc.pl?file=viu03171.xml

div2.head: 451. MALLORY FAMILY PAPERS
div2.p:
ca. 200 items, 1728-1835
A small collection of the business papers of Nathan and John Mallory, small planters, of Orange County. Included are a February 2, 1758, bill of sale for a African American woman; a September 1767 letter offering payment of debt in slaves; and a June 16, 1774, letter from Colonel Aylett forbidding the sale of slaves to satisfy estate settlement.
(Acc. 38-140)

div2.head: 452. MANUSCRIPT COLLECTION
div2.p:
10 items, 1824- 1921
Contains, among other diverse documents, an 1824 list of slaves hired out to Urial Hillman of Orange County by George Wallis and an 1851 letter from C. S. Morgan to Duff Green about the purchase of a slave.
(Acc. 8979-s)

div2.head: 453. MANUSCRIPT COLLECTION
div2.p:
3 items, 1827-62
Includes an 1827 will, recorded in 1850, of Francis Harriss of Buckingham County mentioning slaves previously given to heirs.
(Acc. 10644)

div2.head: 454. MANUSCRIPT COLLECTION
div2.p:
31 items, 1853-1927
Contains two Chesterfield County tax receipts, 1853 and 1857, including one for a freedman, and a photograph, ca. 1927, of the gas station and cafe of Mathew Jackson of Disputanta, the first African American- owned Greyhound bus stop.
(Acc. 8979-r)

div2.head: 455. MANUSCRIPT COLLECTION
div2.p:
9 items, 1861-63
Letters of seven Union and two Confederate soldiers mentioning Federal occupation of Winchester, the 1862 Chambersburg raid, the 1863 bombardment of Charleston, camp life including picket duty and the guarding of African American homes, the duty of men to enlist and save the Union, and the Elmira prison.
(Acc. 10694)
Guide available at http://ead.lib.virginia.edu/vivaead/published/uva-sc/vivadoc.pl?file=viu03803.xml

div2.head: 456. MANUSCRIPT COLLECTION
div2.p:
7 items, 1839-1935
Collection relates chiefly to Richmond African Americans and includes a minute book for the Clocks Social Club detailing the regular and business meetings of the club and recording dues and attendance. Also included are a list of sewing instructions, a February 1935 letter to the Clocks urging them to buy tickets to hear the Eva Jessye Choir at the Ebenezer Baptist Church, a copy of the Reverend John Jasper's sermon "De sun do move," and a photograph of Jasper. A February 11, 1839, letter from Sarah McPhail of Franklin, Tennessee, to her brother, Thomas Glass of Winchester, gives family and farm news and mentions the loss of a Negro woman.
(Acc. 8979-u)

div2.head: 457. MANUSCRIPT COLLECTION
div2.p:
50 items, 1826-1950
Collection includes miscellaneous letters, University of Virginia student notebooks of Archer and Joseph R. J. Anderson, account books and ledgers from various Virginia businesses, a genealogical record of the Withrow family of Rockbridge County, and 1875-76 letters from Mrs. J. H. Fultz to Washington May about money for Leanna, a freedwoman, and her child.
(Acc. 8850)

div2.head: 458. MANUSCRIPT COLLECTION
div2.p:
2 items, ca. 1812
Collection includes two sets of depositions taken in Botetourt County for the Superior Court of Chancery, Lewisburg, Greenbrier County, concerning the sale by John B. Douglas of a slave, Sucky, to Elisha Williams.
(Acc. 8977-aa)

div2.head: 459. MANUSCRIPT COLLECTION
div2.p:
5 items, 1856-82
Included is a letter from John Francis Heath, Petersburg, December 19, 1856, discussing a slave, William.
(Acc. 10590)

div2.head: 459a. MANUSCRIPT COLLECTION
div2.p:
24 items, 1829-1905
The collection contains an account, 1830 of a Virginia doctor with Edward O. Goodwyn of Albemarle Co. for treatment of two female slaves.
(Acc. 8979-j)

div2.head: 459b. MANUSCRIPT COLLECTION
div2.p:
3 items, 1856-61
Last wills and testaments of Elizabeth W. Morton, Charlotte Co., Samuel D. Morton, Charlotte Co. and William Venable, Prince Edward Co. in which slaves are noted.
(Acc. 8979-p)

div2.head: 460. HENRY MARSHALL DIARY
div2.p:
1 item, 1824
Diary written on a walking trip from Philadelphia, to his home in Society Hill, South Carolina. Marshall made a few observations on African Americans, such as an entry on November 1, 1824, in which he compared the differences between African Americans on either side of the Blue Ridge; he believed those African Americans on the eastern side were more deferential. On November 7, 1824, he wrote of slaves near the Dan River who he believed "do as they please."
(Acc. 9655-a)

div2.head: 461. CAPTAIN JOHN MARSHALL JOURNAL
div2.p:
2 items, 1856-57, microfilm (M-192)
Farm journals of 1856-57 kept by Captain Marshall at the Hermitage in Prince Edward County, with frequent references to slaves and slave problems. The March 16 entry notes that his slaves disciplined a hired slave from another plantation by whipping him.
(Acc. 2425)

div2.head: 461a. JOHN MARSHALL LETTERS
div2.p:
3 items, 1830-33
Letters to Edward Carrington Marshall, his youngest son, of Fauquier County, 1830 May 22, 1832 November 7, and 1833 July 26 concerning financial matters including a brief mention of sale of slaves.
(Acc. 4873-a)

div2.head: 462. JOHN H. MARTIN PAPERS
div2.p:
ca. 50 items, 1842-98
Mainly business papers and ledgers of this Caroline County resident. Included in a ledger is a page entitled "Ages of Negro Children."
(Acc. 4224)

div2.head: 462a. HUDSON MARTIN PAPERS
div2.p:
20 items, 1857-80, microfilm (M-668)
The collection contains correspondence of Hudson Martin, merchant of Martin's Mill, Nelson County, with Richmond firms including Clarkson Anderson & Co.; Davis "Dev Pree," slave dealers.
(Acc. 4874)

div2.head: 463. MARX FAMILY PAPERS
div2.p:
8 items, 1828-76
Business ledgers of this family of Richmond and Falls Plantation in Chesterfield County. Two of the ledgers have occasional entries on sales and hiring of slaves.
(Acc. 1213)

div2.head: 464. MASON FAMILY PAPERS
div2.p:
73 items, 1776-1899
A small collection of business and legal papers of this Sussex County family. Documents pertaining to slavery, i.e., sales, tax lists, etc., are included.
(Acc. 1228)

div2.head: 465. COTTON MATHER PAPERS
div2.p:
1 item, 1704
List of marriages performed by this Massachusetts minister including an African American couple.
(McGregor Library Acc. 4860)

div2.head: 466. MATHEWS FAMILY PAPERS
div2.p:
100 items, 1792-1900
The collection contains saddlers accounts and memoranda and estate accounts of Joseph Mathews and diaries, 1864, kept by Joseph William Mathews, while serving in Reynold's Brigade during the Atlanta Campaign, as well as his personal accounts, 1873-1884; and correspondence, ca. 1861-1900, of members of the Mathews family. Also included is a citation from Governor Joseph Brown of Georgia for the use of slave labor in aiding of the war effort, 1861.
(Acc. 5240)

div2.head: 466a. MATHEWS-DUNDORE PAPERS
div2.p:
3 items, [April] 16, 1856
A letter of William Mathews, Charlottesville, to "Grand Pa" in which he wrote of a slave, Maria, who was in jail where she had been beaten repeatedly and had a chain around her neck.
(Acc. 10274)

div2.head: 466b. MASON O. MATHEWS & CHARLES GARDINER MATHEWS COLLECTION
div2.p:
108 items, 1884-87
Mason, a student at Bethel Classical and Military Academy, Fauquier County and Charles, a student at Hanover Academy, Taylorsville write home about their studies and extracurricular activities, including drills, clubs, sports, and trips to Washington, D.C. Of interest are Mason's description of harrassment of local African Americans.
(Acc. 9096-bj)

div2.head: 467. RICHARD SNOW MAUPIN PAPERS
div2.p:
60 items, 1816-57
The papers of this Rockingham County physician contain receipts, accounts, a slave bill of sale, a bond, and two physician's licenses issued to Dr. Maupin.
(Acc. 10737)
Guide available at http://ead.lib.virginia.edu/vivaead/published/uva-sc/vivadoc.pl?file=viu03787.xml

div2.head: 468. SOCRATES MAUPIN PAPERS
div2.p:
200 items, ca. 1830-50
Correspondence between Maupin in Richmond and his brother in Charlottesville. There is a good deal of material on domestic slaves. A May 31, 1847, letter states that flogging a slave might bring him in line and describes him as a "true Negro" because he was always doing "poorly"; one of December 21, 1847, offers a personal servant for sale or for hire; one of June 27, 1849, discusses a African American man's attack of cholera; one of December 23, 1849, discusses selling a slave, Garland, whom Maupin had trouble handling; and another of December 28, 1849, raises the possibility of turning Garland over to an "agent" to "handle"; and a November 30, 1856, letter describes smallpox in Richmond mainly in the African American population.
(Acc. 2769-a)

div2.head: 469. MAURY FAMILY PAPERS
div2.p:
ca. 600 items, ca. 1770-1915
Private and business correspondence of this Albemarle County family, mainly of James Maury. The correspondence is predominantly about business, but the letters of Matthew Maury to his brother James do contain much family material and consequently information on family slaves such as a December 1797 letter telling James of the selling of an estate and the disposition of the slaves.
(Acc. 3888)

div2.head: 470. ANN FONTAINE MAURY DIARY
div2.p:
1 item, 1827-32
A diary containing references to the debates on slavery in the Virginia General Assembly.
(Acc. 949)

div2.head: 470a. REUBEN MAURY PAPERS
div2.p:
12 items, 1807-72
Chiefly letters of this Albemarle County, Va., resident who lived at "Piedmont." Of specific interest is an 1833 letter regarding the sale of two slaves and concern that a trader will take them out of state.
(Acc. 16)
Guide available at http://ead.lib.virginia.edu/vivaead/published/uva-sc/vivadoc.pl?file=viu00004.xml

div2.head: 470b. WILBUR EARNEST MACCLENNY PAPERS
div2.p:
5000 items, 1900-49
Correspondence and diaries of MacClenny together with his topical files on the history and genealogy of Suffolk and Nansemond County, Va., and Gates County, N.C. Included is manuscript and typescript material on the history of African Americans in Nansemond County.
(Acc. 3615)
Guide available at http://ead.lib.virginia.edu/vivaead/published/uva-sc/viu02997.xml.frame

div2.head: 471. McCUE FAMILY PAPERS
div2.p:
ca. 5,000 items, 1777-1920
Correspondence, legal and business papers, accounts, and Confederate army quartermaster records from the personal papers of the Reverend John McCue of Augusta County, Judge John Howard McCue of Nelson County, and William T. McCue of Staunton. Among the papers are the policies and rates of the Lynchburg Hose and Fire Insurance Company, which include rates for insuring slaves; attempts to purchase the husband, George, of the cook, Judy from William A. Staples (James A. Forbes, 1861 Jan 26, Mar 1); conveyance by trust of two slaves, Winny & Nelson (G. Thomas 1843) disagreement over hire of a slave woman, Becky (Reese, 1850); emancipation (Alex Fitzpatrick 1853 Aug 31); emancipation papers of Griffen Harris and subsequent length of stay in the South (P. Schmucker, 1852 Dec 28); hiring (W.C. Carrington, 1853 Dec 24); hiring of William a blacksmith (John Marshall McCue, 1853 Dec 31); hiring of Henry (Tittosan Janney, 1856 Mar 11); inquiry re the hiring of blacksmith Jim (W.J.D. Bell, 1860 Apr 2, 1861 Feb 18); lawsuit over the hiring of a slave for a canal boat (A.S. Lee, 1866 Apr 21, 25, Jul 12); request of Tom to be with his wife (George H. Crawford, 1850 Dec 31); runaway boy, "Squire" (F.A. McChesney, 185[5] Jan 26; John Howard McCue, 1855 Jan 31) sale of Eveline (William B. Dorman, 1856 Aug 10); and a slave in jail (Thomas W. Gilmer, 1837 Jan 19).
(Acc. 4406)
Guide available at http://ead.lib.virginia.edu/vivaead/published/uva-sc/vivadoc.pl?file=viu01216.xml

div2.head: 472. McDOWELL FAMILY PAPERS
div2.p:
ca. 600 items, 1792-1852
Largely the papers of Colonel James McDowell of Rockbridge County. These are mainly political in nature, but there are references to slavery, such as a letter from Preston to James McDowell discussing the possibility of selling his slaves and undated lists enumerating prices of slaves. There are many examples of hiring out slaves, e.g., two in 1808.
(Acc. 1707)
Guide available at http://ead.lib.virginia.edu/vivaead/published/uva-sc/vivadoc.pl?file=viu03254.xml

div2.head: 473. McGAHEY FAMILY PAPERS
div2.p:
ca. 60 items, 1759-1892, microfilm (M-649)
Business, personal papers, and account books of this Rockingham County family. A genealogy of this family contains slave births and death dates.
(Acc. 4543)

div2.head: 474. DORSEY McPHERSON PAPERS
div2.p:
ca. 400 items, ca. 1865-1935
Collection consists mainly of letters from this army surgeon while on duty in the American Southwest, 1878-80. He vividly described attempts to capture renegade Apaches under the leadership of Victoria. One of the units pursuing Victoria was the North Cavalry, a African American troop, which McPherson mentioned in letters of May 25 and October 8, 1879, and March 13, 1880.
(Acc. 6144)

div2.head: 475. MEADE FAMILY PAPERS
div2.p:
28 items, 1775-1850
Primarily consists of family correspondence of Richard Everard Meade, originally of Amelia County. Scattered references to slavery include a November 12, 1824, letter from Hadijah Meade to R. L. Meade cautioning him that buying slaves might not be a worthwhile venture because they were "lazy and vicious." Letters to Hodijah Meade include one letter, April 3, 1837, mentioning a poisoning attempt by a servant girl.
(Acc. 10126-a,-b)
Guide to 10126-c available at http://ead.lib.virginia.edu/vivaead/published/uva-sc/vivadoc.pl?file=viu00997.xml

div2.head: 476. MEADE-FUNSTEN PAPERS
div2.p:
ca. 400 items, 1792-1906
Correspondence and business letters of these Clarke County families. An 1852 letter describes a medical exam of a slave, and a legal deposition deals with a slave woman and child.
(Acc. 3039)

div2.head: 476a. MEADE, VALENTINE AND WALKER FAMILY PAPERS
div2.p:
ca. 500 items, 1873-1980
The collection contains photographs, clippings, financial and legal papers, scrapbooks and some correspondence pertinent to the Meade, Valentine and Walker families of Virginia. Letters of note include one from John Barbee Minor against violation of the Sabbath and one from James L. Cabell to Valentine, as president of a local streetcar company concerning an incident between two ladies and a "negro man." Also included is a photograph of baby girl VWM Valentine with her African American mammy, identified as one Sally Williams, ca. 1909. (Acc. 11777)

div2.head: 477. MEIKLEHAM FAMILY PAPERS
div2.p:
ca. 100 items, ca. 1790-1915
Personal papers of David Scott Meikleham and his wife Septimia Randolph Meikleham. A letter from P. Turnbull in Havana discusses the stories about the shipwreck of the slave ship Aquila in Havana.
(Acc. 6065)

div2.head: 478. SEPTIMIA RANDOLPH MEIKLEHAM PAPERS
div2.p:
ca. 60 items, ca. 1700-1870
Personal and family letters of a granddaughter of Thomas Jefferson. Included is an 1821 Monticello slave bread list in Jefferson's hand and a letter from a slave, John Hemmings, to Septimia, August 28, 1825.
(Acc. 4726-a)

div2.head: 479. CALLOHILL MENNIS PAPERS
div2.p:
ca. 550 items, ca. 1765-1850
Business, personal, and legal papers of this Bedford County lawyer. A letter of January 17, 1820, from John Mays to Mennis asks about two runaway slaves; a March 1827 letter from Thomas Preston concerns the purchase of a slave whose leg had been withered by disease; and various other letters and legal memoranda discuss hiring out and other slavery activities.
(Acc. 1993)

div2.head: 479a. THOMAS JOHNSON MICHIE PAPERS
div2.p:
ca. 800 items, 1943-61
Political, legal and personal papers of this Charlottesville lawyer and United States District Judge of the Western District of Virginia. Included is correspondence on civic improvement, annexation and zoning, school desegregation and public housing when he was a member of the Charlottesville city council.
(Acc. 9891)

div2.head: 479b. MILL CREEK BAPTIST CHURCH COLLECTION
div2.p:
2 items, 1904
The collection contains a history of Mill Creek Baptist Church, Botetourt County, Virginia, from its founding in 1804 to 1904 August 1, written by Mrs. Bernie B. Crist; and a biographical sketch of the Rev. Absalom Cornelius Dempsey, pastor of the church from 1821 to 1867. The biography notes that "The negroes were granted the use of the church once a month to have preaching & church meeting & the pastor of Mill Creek to be their pastor, Henry Zimmerman, colored, was permitted to preach, their deacons were Camma, Sam & Zacn!"
(Acc. 5933)

div2.head: 479c. JOHN S. MILLER LETTERS
div2.p:
74 items, 1841-46
Letters from John S. Miller, a merchant from Winchester, Virginia, to Jane F. Schmidt from York, Pennsylvania, who became his wife in December 1843. In one letter, September 28, 1846, John Miller writes, "would it not be best for me to bring a girl along with me to take charge of Sis on the road home if you think so I will try and get one, she must be a free one as a slave cannot be taken to your state."
(Acc. 11702)
Guide available at http://ead.lib.virginia.edu/vivaead/published/uva-sc/vivadoc.pl?file=viu02002.xml

div2.head: 479d. DABNEY MINOR NOTEBOOK
div2.p:
1 item, 1808-20
Contains notes on vaccination procedures and registers of Negro births, 1738-1820.
(Acc. 7849)

div2.head: 480. LOUISA H. A. MINOR DIARY
div2.p:
1 item, September 1, 1855-December 29, 1865
Personal diary of this woman who lived at "Pant-Ops" in Albemarle County. Of special interest are comments about freed slaves emigrating to Liberia in December 1856, talk of insurrection among the slaves in the same month, and general disparaging comments about freed slaves in December 1865.
(Acc. 10685)
Guide available at http://ead.lib.virginia.edu/vivaead/published/uva-sc/vivadoc.pl?file=viu00099.xml

div2.head: 481. MINOR FAMILY PAPERS
div2.p:
ca. 6,000 items, 1764-1936
Mainly business, legal, and educational papers of John B. Minor, a University of Virginia law professor, and the Minor family of Albemarle County. There appears to be very little material relating to slavery; however, a letter to Minor in 1860 refers to the American Colonization Society.
(Acc. 38-602)
Guide available at http://ead.lib.virginia.edu/vivaead/published/uva-sc/vivadoc.pl?file=viu03719.xml

div2.head: 482. MINOR FAMILY PAPERS
div2.p:
26 items, 1857-65
Letters from former slaves of the Minor family of Albemarle County written from Liberia. The slaves were freed under the terms of the will of their owner, Dr. James Hunter Terrell, and were transported to
Africa through the offices of the American Colonization Society.
(Acc. 10460)
Guide available at http://ead.lib.virginia.edu/vivaead/published/uva-sc/vivadoc.pl?file=viu01228.xml

div2.head: 483. MINOR FAMILY PAPERS
div2.p:
ca. 200 items, 1838-1944
Business and personal papers of Launcelot Minor and his family of Pedlar Mills, Amherst County. An 1838-87 farm ledger has information on slaves, especially birth dates, and on sharecropping by freedmen after the war. Bible records note slave births and deaths, and there is a daguerreotype of a female slave.
(Acc. 6055)

div2.head: 484. MINOR FAMILY PAPERS
div2.p:
ca. 50 items, ca. 1830-1910
Personal correspondence of this family of Edgewood in Albemarle County. A statement by Bishop William Meade attests to the fact that his wife before her death wished part of her estate to be used for "The Welfare of The African race" and a November 22, 1884, letter from C. L. C. Minor at Winchester comments on the trial of two blacks for killing a white man and the mood of the community for a lynching if the verdict was not death.
(Acc. 6907)

div2.head: 484a. MINOR, SOUTHALL AND VENABLE FAMILY PHOTOGRAPHS
div2.p:
44 items, ca 1860-1900
Pictured with family members are relatives, friends and two African American servants including Sally Cottrell Coles, the former slave of Ellen Wayles Randolph Coolidge at Monticello, later sold to Professor Thomas H. Key.
(Acc. 10100-d)
Image available at http://www.lib.virginia.edu/harrison/exhibits/journeys/lg-html/MSS10100d_SallyColePic.html

div2.head: 484b. MISCELLANEOUS VIRGINIA LETTERS
div2.p:
11 items, 1827-67
From various Virginia individuals and families concerning family matters, agriculture, politics, and historical events, including the Civil War. An 1846 October 3 letter from Philip Vinsel, Hoysville, Loudoun County, Virginia, to William Anthony and Susannah Slater, c/o Harvey Cogsil, Carrollton, Ohio notes the death of their mother and discussing the specifics of her illness. He comments on family and friends; wheat, corn, and grain crops; and, the sale of the Case property and slaves in November.
(Acc. 11176)
Guide available at http://ead.lib.virginia.edu/vivaead/published/uva-sc/vivadoc.pl?file=viu01378.xml

div2.head: 485. MISSISSIPPI SLAVE TRADE DOCUMENT
div2.p:
1 item, ca. 1837
Unidentified fragment which discusses Mississippi and the regulation of the slave trade.
(Acc. 3226)

div2.head: 486. MITCHELL-GARNETT LEDGERS
div2.p:
20 items, 1821-63
Account books, ledgers, journals, and daybooks from the plantations of James Mercer Garnett, Muscoe Russell Hunter Garnett, and Robert Mercer Taliaferro Hunter. Interwoven in all of these records are slave accounts.
(Acc. 38-45)
Guide available at http://ead.lib.virginia.edu/vivaead/published/uva-sc/vivadoc.pl?file=viu03019.xml

div2.head: 487. HOPIE WRIGHT MOATS PAPERS
div2.p:
ca. 140 items, 1889-1915
Personal correspondence of a African American family living in Highland County.
(Acc. 5113)

div2.head: 488. JAMES MONROE COLLECTION
div2.p:
ca. 500 items, 1783-1831
Included are letters in which Monroe discussed slavery and the buying and selling of slaves, such as an April 7, 1788, letter on the sale of a slave; a February 25, 1817, letter to William Noland on the alleged mistreatment of one of his slaves; an August 12, 1822, letter to his overseer on the health of a slave; a June 6, 1830, letter to [Egbert Watson] on the possibility of selling some of his slaves; and a letter of July 5, 1830, to Watson again discussing the sale of a slave, Nancy.
Guide available at http://ead.lib.virginia.edu/vivaead/published/uva-sc/vivadoc.pl?file=viu03476.xml

div2.head: 488a. MORGAN FAMILY PAPERS
div2.p:
22 items, 1843-93
Consists of the correspondence, 1843-1864, of John Morgan of Shenandoah County, Va. and later, West Virginia, chiefly concern slavery, secession, and the Civil War service of James B. Morgan and William S. Morgan. Topics include the 1843 sale of a slave without his prior knowledge to prevent his running away and the purchase of a man and wife.
(Acc. 11421)
Guide available at http://ead.lib.virginia.edu/vivaead/published/uva-sc/vivadoc.pl?file=viu01223.xml

div2.head: 488b. MORRIS FAMILY PAPERS
div2.p:
ca. 4100 items, 1727-1931
Consisting mostly of business and legal documents belonging to three generations of the family in Hanover and Louisa Counties, Virginia. There is a large amount of valuable slavery material, including annual lists of all taxable property owned by the family. These documents list all slaves on the plantation by name. For example: Bill of sale for woman, 1769 June 1; Bill of sale, 1769 Dec 29; Release of a mortgaged slave, >1770 July 6; Appraisal of Negro man, 1772 June 6 and a portrait of Harry Holmes, after 1859. Inscribed on back: Slave to Major James Watson. http://www.lib.virginia.edu/harrison/exhibits/journeys/lg-html/MSS38_79_HarryHolmesPic.html
(Acc. 38-79)
Guide available at http://ead.lib.virginia.edu/vivaead/published/uva-sc/vivadoc.pl?file=viu00993.xml

div2.head: 489. MORTON FAMILY PAPERS
div2.p:
ca. 6,000 items, ca. 1725-1975
Correspondence, financial and legal papers, account books, and miscellaneous papers of this family of Orange County. There is a considerable amount of material on slavery including hiring out of slaves, slave trade, and medical attention. A May 17, 1845, letter was written by Lewis Tappan on behalf of an ex-slave who needed his "free papers."
(Acc. 9755-a)

div2.head: 490. MORTON-HALSEY FAMILY PAPERS
div2.p:
ca. 10,000 items, 1840-80
Correspondence and other papers of Colonel Jeremiah Morton, Jackson Morton, and Joseph J. Halsey of Culpeper County. Included is material on Colonel Morton's participation in a slave trade centered in Virginia and Mobile, Alabama. Morton's personal account book for 1836-47 and an 1861 slave account book reflect this interest. There is also correspondence to Halsey from Northern family and friends commenting on their reaction to slavery.
(Acc. 3995)
Guide available at http://ead.lib.virginia.edu/vivaead/published/uva-sc/vivadoc.pl?file=viu00494.xml

div2.head: 490a. JACOB W. MORTON CORRESPONDENCE
div2.p:
103 items, 1822-1866
Correspondence of Morton with his brother, Samuel D. Morton, of Petersburg, Va., and Joseph E. Venable, of Farmville, who were his partners, with merchants of Virginia, New York, and Raleigh, N.C., and with various members of the Morton family. Subjects include the sale of slaves.
(Acc. 4553)

div2.head: 491. JOHN SINGLETON MOSBY SCRAPBOOKS
div2.p:
6 items, 1869-1915
These scrapbooks, compiled by Mosby and his daughter, Mary Virginia Mosby Campbell, contain newspaper articles relating to Mosby's life and career as well as miscellaneous poetry, correspondence, photographs, and memorabilia. Topics include Mosby's Civil War slave, Aaron Burton.
(Acc. 7872-a)
Guide available at http://ead.lib.virginia.edu/vivaead/published/uva-sc/vivadoc.pl?file=viu00185.xml

div2.head: 491a. JOHN SINGLETON MOSBY LETTERS
div2.p:
2 items, 1858 and 1897
A letter, 1858 March 17, to "Mr. Martin" concerns five slaves Mosby is selling to James Surget.
(Acc. 10804)

div2.head: 491b. JOHN MOTTRAM DIARY
div2.p:
1 item, 1865 January 1-July 3.
A Private in Co. K, 13th New Hampshire Volunteers, Mottrams diary begins during the siege of Petersburg, and continues through the capture and occupation of Richmond, the end of the war, his mustering out and return home. He discusses routine camp life, desertions from both sides, the entry into Richmond, African American troops and civilians, and paroled Confederates and starving civilians in Richmond.
(Acc. 10988)

div2.head: 492. MOUNT EDD BAPTIST CHURCH REGISTER
div2.p:
1 item, 1823-44
The minute book of this Batesville church contains lists of names of African American church members.
(Acc. 3673)

div2.head: 492a. MOUNTAIN PLAIN BAPTIST CHURCH RECORDS
div2.p:
2 items, 1833-1949, microfilm (M-1262 & 1369)
The records include the church covenant, constitution, minutes and membership lists of white and black members.
(Acc. 5496)

div2.head: 492b. MARY MUNROE LETTER
div2.p:
1 item, 1849
Munroe from Annapolis, Md., writes to Thomas Munroe, Rushville, Ill., concerning cholera and a small pox epidemic attributing its start to Dutch (German?) immigrants who also "learn the negroes to steal"; its spread among the lower classes and their problems.
(Acc. 8973)

div2.head: 492c. MURRELL FAMILY PAPERS
div2.p:
ca. 1000 items, 1816-58
Business correspondence and records of the mercantile firm of John D. Murrell and Hardin Murrell of Lynchburg who were also engaged in farming in Virginia and Lousiana. Correspondence concerns merchandise, tobacco, slaves and agriculture.
(Acc. 6740)

div2.head: 493. NANSEMOND COUNTY COLLECTION
div2.p:
31 items, n.d., microfilm (M-517)
Included is a five-page typescript article, "The Negro in Nansemond County" by W. E. MacClenny.

div2.head: 494. "THE NEGRO AND CONFEDERATE MORALE"
div2.p:
1 item, 1951
Typescript master's thesis by Carl I. Olson, University of Mississippi,1951.
(Acc. 5820)

div2.head: 495. NELSON COUNTY BUSINESS LEDGERS
div2.p:
85 items, 1812-1928
Account books, daybooks, journals, and ledgers of Nelson County businesses owned and/or operated by William Faber, Hudson Martin, T. W. Martin, Martin Thurmond, etc. A "Negro Book," 1858-62, details general store and work transactions with area slaves.
(Acc. 5640)

div2.head: 496. NELSON FAMILY PAPERS
div2.p:
57 items, 1848-94
The papers consist chiefly of thirty-five letters, 1856-61, from Thomas Frederick Nelson to his parents, Robert Carter Burwell Nelson and Susan Price Nelson, about life at the school run by his great-aunts at their Clarke County home, Rosney. The collection contains the 1855 will of John M. Price of Fincastle mentioning slaves.
(Acc. 10605)

div2.head: 497. NELSON AND KINLOCH FAMILY PAPERS
div2.p:
20 items, 1779-1836
Legal and business papers of Hugh Nelson of Belvoir, Albemarle County, dealing primarily with the estate of his father-in-law, Francis Kinloch. Included are various legal documents and papers on transfers, prices, and the inheritance of slaves.
(Acc. 2831)

div2.head: 498. NELSON AND PAGE FAMILY PAPERS
div2.p:
ca. 2,400 items, ca. 1750-1910
Business, legal, and personal correspondence of these families of Richmond and Yorktown. Included is a July 9, 1809, letter from Thomas Nelson to Francis Page asking him to be on the lookout for his runaway slave, Bristol, and a receipt signed by Sarah Chisholm for money received for midwifery services performed for a slave of Francis Page, October 20, 1811.
(Acc. 9014)

div2.head: 499. GEORGE NEVILLE COLLECTION
div2.p:
8 items, 1834-63
Primarily the Civil War letters of this James City County resident. An 1834 marriage indenture conveys the dower right to eight slaves.
(Acc. 1291)

div2.head: 499a. NEW KENT DISTRICT SUNDAY SCHOOL CONVENTION MINUTES
div2.p:
1 item, 1938-55
The minutes of the New Kent District Baptist Sunday School meetings from 1938-1955 which include the names of officers, financial reports, and the agenda for each meeting. The New Kent District of Hanover County, Virginia was comprised of the following African American churches: Mount Zion, Lebanon, Second Liberty, New Branch, and New Elam.
(Acc. 8979-y)
Guide available at http://ead.lib.virginia.edu/vivaead/published/uva-sc/vivadoc.pl?file=viu02247.xml

div2.head: 499b. FRANCES NEWMAN LETTERS
div2.p:
3 items, 1926-27
Letters of this southern writer to Scott Cunningham. In one letter from Richmond, Virginia, Jan 16 [1927] she comments on Carl Van Vechtens noted racially mixed parties in New York City. She states that she had never been asked to a Van Vechten mixed party. Of course, I dont know and new Negroes, but Im far from disliking Negroes, in fact, I suffer torture over their sorrows, because I dont [ ] what can one about them.
(Barrett Lilbrary Acc. 8294)

div2.head: 500. WILSON CARY NICHOLAS PAPERS
div2.p:
ca. 3,000 items, 1751-1850
Business and personal papers of this governor of Virginia concentrating in the years of the War of1812. There is a slave Tax Book of 1815.
(Acc. 2343)

div2.head: 501. WILSON CARY NICHOLAS PAPERS
div2.p:
ca. 1,150 items, ca. 1725-1830
Mostly personal correspondence of the Randolph family of Edgehill and of Nicholas. The documents concerning slavery include a June 1802-June 1803 list of the sale of slaves; a December 21, 1808, letter of Peggy Nicholas to Wilson Cary Nicholas about a massacre plotted by slaves; and several undated items: a note by Nicholas about slaves and land, a note on the sale of Edmund Randolph's slaves, and a petition for educating slaves before freeing them.
(Acc. 5533)

div2.head: 501a. NOLAND FAMILY PAPERS
div2.p:
ca. 4000 items, 1813-99
The collection contains the papers of the Noland family of Airwell, Hanover County, particularly those of Callender St. George Noland. Included are slave lists and accounts from Airwell and Dewberry, Hanover County including a sermon and a slave insurance policy, Berkeley and Noland family accounts, school essays and exams, diaries, carpenter's and builder's time and memoranda book, and photographs.
(Acc. 6463, etc.)
Guide available at http://ead.lib.virginia.edu/vivaead/published/uva-sc/viu03505.xml.frame

div2.head: 502. LAWRENCE O'BRYAN BRANCH PAPERS
div2.p:
ca. 650 items, ca. 1840-80 microfilm (M-2296)
Personal, political, and military correspondence of this North Carolina citizen. The correspondence between Branch and his wife contains some comment on family slaves. A March 8, 1862, letter from J. Robert Jeffreys in Pacific, North Carolina, answering a request from Branch, replies that Jeffreys "drafted" fifty-six free blacks and sent them to the chief engineer at New Bern, North Carolina.
(Acc. 10057)

div2.head: 503. SILAS AND R. H. OMOHUNDRO BUSINESS LEDGER
div2.p:
1 item, 1857-63
The volume contains names, prices, purchasers, and profits of slaves sold by this firm.
(Acc. 4122)

div2.head: 504. THE BRIG OTHELLO ACCOUNT BOOK
div2.p:
6 items, 1772-97
Entries in September and March 1772 record paying "blacks" for burying a sailor and for bringing back a "runaway" sailor.
(Acc. 9183)

div2.head: 505. OVERTON FAMILY PAPERS
div2.p:
ca. 7,000 items, ca. 1740-1935
Legal, business, and personal papers of this family of Prospect Hill, Louisa County. The early plantation records contain slavery material, such as a July 1835 sale of a slave, Katy, to Mr. Overton and an 1837 deed of sale of a slave to William Overton.
(Acc. 8929)

div2.head: 506. THOMAS NELSON PAGE DOCUMENT
div2.p:
1 item, 1853-1922
Printing block belonging to this American novelist and diplomat. The block contains a photoengraving of an old African American man and a relief metal engraving of the manuscript of the first page of Page's story Marse Chan.
(Acc. 9109)

div2.head: 506a. NEW MARKET VIRGINIA TOWN MINUTES
div2.p:
4 items, 1806-1887
The minute books of the Trustees of the town of New Market, Vols. I, II, III, V. There are several references to slave passes, patrols, hirings, and occasional individual slaves by name.
(Acc. 11000)
Guide available at http://ead.lib.virginia.edu/vivaead/published/uva-sc/vivadoc.pl?file=viu01470.xml

div2.head: 507. PAGE-WALKER FAMILY PAPERS
div2.p:
ca. 300 items, 1742-1886
This collection consists of the papers of these families of Castle Hill and Keswick in Albemarle County. Among the items are bills of sale for slaves in 1785 and 1786, an 1803 rental of a slave wagon driver, and a 1868 letter from a former slave.
(Acc. 3098)

div2.head: 508. GEORGE W. PALMORE PAPERS
div2.p:
ca. 1,500 items, 1858-96
Business and legal papers of this Cumberland County businessman. Included are registration lists for African American voters of Madison Township in Farmville.
(Acc. 38-55)
Guide available at http://ead.lib.virginia.edu/vivaead/published/uva-sc/vivadoc.pl?file=viu00910.xml

div2.head: 509. JOSEPH PALMORE PAPERS
div2.p:
ca. 1,000 items, 1781-1883
Interspersed throughout this collection of a Cumberland County farmer are documents and letters relating to slavery, such as an 1830 deed of sale for a slave. In the 1830s there are a few notes promising payment for the hiring out of slaves, and there are letters to Joseph Palmore from his brother in Mississippi mentioning the selling and trading of slaves.
(Acc. 38-149)
Guide available at http://ead.lib.virginia.edu/vivaead/published/uva-sc/vivadoc.pl?file=viu03845.xml

div2.head: 510. SAMUEL PANNILL PAPERS
div2.p:
765 items, 1847-1938
Letters, indentures, accounts, receipts, promissory notes, and tax receipts of this Pittsylvania County plantation owner. Many concern tobacco, grist mill accounts, railroad shipments, and the hiring of laborers. Of interest are 1858 and 1862 accounts for medical treatment of slaves, receipts for slaves impressed to work on Confederate fortifications, an 1867 list of wages paid to sharecroppers, and a Freedman's Bureau apprenticeship indenture.
(Acc. 10721)
Guide available at http://ead.lib.virginia.edu/vivaead/published/uva-sc/vivadoc.pl?file=viu01770.xml

div2.head: 511. THEODORE PARKER COLLECTION
div2.p:
4 items, 1835-55
A manuscript by this noted American antislavery clergyman entitled "Aspect of the Slave Power in America in the Beginning of 1854." Also included is a draft of a letter to the pope appealing for support against slave owners.
(Barrett Library Acc. 8119)

div2.head: 512. STEPHEN D. PARRISH PAPERS
div2.p:
ca. 1,000 items, 1857-1941
Papers of this Richmond, Kentucky, attorney. Included is correspondence with several socialist and religious organizations, among them the United Colored Socialists of America. There is also correspondence in 1902 from Milo Shanks, Senator J. C. S. Blackburn, and Congressman G. C. Gilbert about Theodore Roosevelt's dinner invitation to Booker T. Washington.
(Acc. 4227)

div2.head: 513. JOHN PATTERSON LETTER
div2.p:
1 item, October 17, 1808
A letter from John Patterson, Alexandria, Virginia, to Peter Carr, requesting information from his brother Dabney Carr on Virginia legislature concerning the crossing of the state line into Virginia with one's slaves. Patterson had been informed that persons crossing into Virginia to reside can bring their slaves with an affidavit that they are for their own use and not to be sold, and would now like to have an opinion concerning this matter.
(Acc. 11248)
Guide available at http://ead.lib.virginia.edu/vivaead/published/uva-sc/vivadoc.pl?file=viu01340.xml

div2.head: 513a. SARAH P. PATTERSON PAPERS
div2.p:
ca. 30 items, 1930-50
Business, educational, and religious records of this African American teacher in Buckingham County, consisting mainly of school papers of a one-room black school in Buckingham and records of African American churches in Buckingham County.
(Acc. 10154)

div2.head: 514. PAYNE FAMILY PAPERS
div2.p:
ca. 60 items, 1849-62
Personal correspondence of Bettie V. Jones Payne and William J. Payne of Fluvanna County. A November 23, 1853, letter from James M. Payne in Arkansas to his brother William mentions that he had recently purchased a woman as a slave but she had run away the next day.
(Acc. 10530)

div2.head: 514a. SARAH PANNILL MILLER PAYNE LETTERS
div2.p:
ca. 30 items, 1865-1910
Letters written by this Campbell County resident to her cousin Mary Miller of Philadelphia and Cecil Co., Md., describing the problems of adjusting to farm life without slaves.
(Acc. 8668)

div2.head: 515. WILLIAM PENDLETON LETTERS
div2.p:
3 items, 1849-53
Letters to William Pendleton of Louisa County. A May 5, 1849, letter from W. Barret of Richmond discusses the health of slaves.
(Acc. 9096)

div2.head: 515a. JOHN J. PERSHING LETTER
div2.p:
1 item, October 24, 1919
Pershing responds to an enquiry about the lack of "colored troops" in World War I victory parades in Washington, D. C. and New York. (Acc. 13554)

div2.head: 515b. MOSBY GARLAND PERROW JR. PAPERS
div2.p:
2600 items, 1940-62
Papers of the Lynchburg, Virginia state senator and chairman of the Virginia School "Perrow" Commission to study school desegregation. Legislative papers pertain chiefly to the Perrow Commission, 1958-1959, whose final report advocated freedom of choice, or local option, to end "Massive Resistance" to court ordered integration and the consequent public school closings.
(Acc. 11014)
Guide available at http://ead.lib.virginia.edu/vivaead/published/uva-sc/vivadoc.pl?file=viu01474.xml

div2.head: 516. PERRY FAMILY PAPERS
div2.p:
ca. 850 items, ca. 1830-1915
Consists primarily of the legal, financial, and medical records of W. H. Perry of Lunenberg County. There is a large number of medical receipts dated 1834, many containing entries on treatment of slaves.
(Acc. 9960)

div2.head: 517. PERRY, MARTIN, AND McCUE FAMILY PAPERS
div2.p:
ca. 625 items, ca. 1805-1930
Business and personal papers of these related northern Virginia families. There are infrequent references to slavery, such as a December 29, 1856, letter from Lexington mentioning a good deal of "excitement about some fears lest there should be a Negro riot." A July 17, 1864, letter from a Confederate soldier requests that his uncle trade a slave for a good horse for him.
(Acc. 6806-b)

div2.head: 518. PERSONAL ACCOUNT BOOK
div2.p:
1 item, 1755-56
Very small personal account book of an unknown man. Included are two memoranda discussing the disposition of slaves among family members.
(Acc. 1613)

div2.head: 519. PETER FAMILY PAPERS
div2.p:
ca. 2,000 items, ca. 1700-1900
Business, legal, and personal papers of this family of Georgetown, D.C., and of Frederick and Montgomery counties, Maryland. The frequent references to slavery include a series of letters in 1836-45 mentioning the buying and selling of slaves in Georgetown; an 1850 letter from John Denning to L. W. Candler discussing the current market in slaves; and an undated letter from John Candler to George Peter about seventy-five runaway slaves from Charles County heading through Rockville County to Pennsylvania.
(Acc. 7605-a)
Guide available at http://ead.lib.virginia.edu/vivaead/published/uva-sc/vivadoc.pl?file=viu03504.xml

div2.head: 520. PETERSBURG ACCOUNT BOOKS
div2.p:
18 items, 1795-1900
Account books from various Petersburg businesses and merchants. The 1836-39 daybooks and ledgers of the Blandford Mill Company include records of wages paid to hired hands and entries such as "Negro Expenses."
(Acc. 2135)
Guide available at http://ead.lib.virginia.edu/vivaead/published/uva-sc/vivadoc.pl?file=viu00595.xml

div2.head: 521. JOHN W. PEYTON PAPERS
div2.p:
51 items, 1862-1913, microfilm (M-687)
This small collection of a Rapidan citizen includes a diary with occasional mention of runaway slaves during the Civil War and incidents of Federal troops taking slaves on raids.
(Acc. 4944)

div2.head: 521a. PHOTOGRAPH
div2.p:
1 item, ca. late 1862
Photograph of post office building at Surry Court House, showing a group of men including two Union cavalrymen and an unidentified African American man; identified persons are Dr. Corbell and his partner, Peyton A. Cocke.
(Acc. 11077)
Guide available at http://ead.lib.virginia.edu/vivaead/published/uva-sc/vivadoc.pl?file=viu01492.xml

div2.head: 522. GEORGE PICKETT LETTER
div2.p:
3 items, 1790-1829 photocopies
A 1797 document (original held by donor) authorizes the sale of some of the slaves of George Pickett.
(Acc. 8845)

div2.head: 522a. PIEDMONT HOSPITAL RECORDS
div2.p:
35 items, 1888-96
Included are records of this Charlottesville Virginia hospital consisting of minutes of the Board of Lady Managers; reports of inspecting physicians; financial reports; correspondence and a scrapbook containing newsclippings about the hospital which operated chiefly as a charity hospital until 1896. African Americans and segregated services for them are noted.
(Acc. 8438)

div2.head: 523. PITTSYLVANIA COUNTY RESOLUTION
div2.p:
1 item, 1861
Apparently adopted at a public meeting, this resolution calls for Virginia to retaliate by any means against states who refuse to cooperate with the Fugitive Slave Law.
(Acc. 6458)

div2.head: 524. JAMES PLEASANTS LETTER
div2.p:
1 item, January 25, 1825
A letter from this Virginia governor to Littleton W. Tazewell giving his feelings on the slavery question. Pleasants contended that the problem would be comparatively small, "if the unfortunate beings were white."
(Acc. 10063)

div2.head: 525. POCKET PLANTATION PAPERS
div2.p:
The business and personal papers of the Pittsylvania County plantation of about 713 acres formed in a bend of the Staunton River in the south central tobacco region of Virginia near North Carolina run by the Smith and Clement families. These records are filled with references to slavery, including items such as account books and slave records of the Smith family and slave account books and a medical record book of the Clement family. .
(McGregor Library Acc. 2027)

div2.head: 526. WILLIAM POLLARD DOCUMENT
div2.p:
1 item, August 29, 1797
Legal document signed by David Bullock of Hanover Court House empowering him to purchase and sell slaves to settle estate claims and detailing the individual slaves sold.
(Acc. 8875)

div2.head: 527. JOHN POWELL PAPERS
div2.p:
ca. 30,000 items, ca. 1885-1965
Personal correspondence, pamphlets, and miscellaneous material of John Powell, noted composer from Richmond. One box of material covers Powell's association with the Anglo-Saxon Clubs, an organization dedicated to belief in the racial superiority of the white race over the African American race.
(Acc. 7284)
Guide available at http://ead.lib.virginia.edu/vivaead/published/uva-sc/vivadoc.pl?file=viu02573.xml

div2.head: 528. PRESTON-DAVIS FAMILY PAPERS
div2.p:
ca. 2,000 items, ca. 1840-1930
Personal and business correspondence of these Albemarle County families. Included are January 26, 1854, and July 8, 1859, letters about the religious instruction of slaves.
(Acc. 4951)

div2.head: 528a. PRIEST POMEROY, SILMAN AND WOOD FAMILY BIBLE RECORDS
div2.p:
5 items, ca. 1857-1922
Included in these records of Rappanhannock and Warren County, Va., families is a receipt from George S. Payne to Mrs. Susan E. Priest for the woman Hannah, warranted sound and healthy in body and mind, 1857 August 4.
(Acc. 4675)

div2.head: 528b. ANNE AUGUSTA BANISTER PRYOR MANUSCRIPT
div2.p:
1 item, 1864-1865, ante 1941
Incidents in the life of a Civil War child, Recollections of Mrs. Pryor describe the death of her father fighting Kautz's raiders; roles played by slaves in defense of the city demonstrating that they loved their masters "more than freedom.
(Acc. 4792)

div2.head: 529. PUBLIC HEALTH POSTERS
div2.p:
6 items, ca. 1940
Used in antisyphilis program for African Americans.
(Acc. 851)

div2.head: 529a. QUINBY, TEACKLE, AND UPSHUR FAMILY PAPERS
div2.p:
1300 items, 1759-1968
Papers of these families of Somerset County, Maryland, and Accomack and Northampton Counties, Virginia. Included is a handwritten psalter by Richard Walter beginning in 1759 that lists births of Negroes from 1774 to 1797. (Acc. 2338)

div2.head: 530. JOHN ANTHONY QUITMAN PAPERS
div2.p:
80 items, 1798-1858
Personal and business papers of Major General Quitman. An 1855 letter refers to efforts to keep slaves safe in Texas.
(Acc. 38-343)

div2.head: 531. RACE RELATIONS PAPERS
div2.p:
30 items, 1943-58
Form letters and appeals for contributions from such organizations as the Virginia Commission on Interracial Cooperation, Virginia Council of Churches, The Southern Regional Council, Southern Conference for Human Welfare, etc. Also a memorandum from the Conference of Graduate Education for Negroes, Durham, N.C., 1945 July, form letters from Lillian Smith regarding the "South Today" and a campaign to free Tee Davis; an offprint from Harper's Magazine "Race riots can be prevented" by Ernest A. Gray, Jr.; and literature regarding Pacificana, a program to promote appreciation of Asian nations.
(Acc. 6374)

div2.head: 531a. RACE RELATIONS SCRAPBOOK
div2.p:
1 item, 1942-57
A scrapbook mainly of clippings from the Chicago Tribune kept by Monroe F. Cockrell.
(Acc. 5276-a)

div2.head: 532. RAINEY FAMILY PAPERS
div2.p:
4 items, 1836-54
Letters of this Boydton family. One letter concerns the sale of a slave in 1836, and another refers to the whipping of a slave.
(Acc. 2734)

div2.head: 533. RANDALL FAMILY PAPERS
div2.p:
98 items, ca. 1830-70
Letters of Burton Randall, an army surgeon from Annapolis, Maryland, who was stationed in the West and Southwest. They contain references to slaves and slavery, such as an 1827 letter from Randall to Alexander Randall asking him to procure slaves from markets on the Eastern Shore.
(Acc. 9564)

div2.head: 534. RANDOLPH FAMILY PAPERS
div2.p:
ca. 6,000 items, ca. 1760-1930
Personal correspondence and business papers of the Randolph, Page, and Taylor families of Albemarle County (descendants of Thomas Jefferson), including many of the papers of Thomas Jefferson Randolph. There are many references to slaves and their treatment, e.g., a January 11, 1827, letter from P. H. Leuba to [Thomas Jefferson
Randolph] mentioning that the slave named Jeanette he recently bought from Randolph had been severely burned by Randolph's overseer and thrown into a fire twice and that he could not return her because she feared for her life but that he believed her value was much less than the sale price; an account of the sales of Thomas Jefferson's slaves in 1829; and a list of slaves, possibly belonging to Thomas Jefferson Randolph.
(Acc. 8937, etc.)

div2.head: 535. RANDOLPH FAMILY PAPERS
div2.p:
35 items, ca. 1820-80
Included in this small Randolph collection is a manuscript written by John F. Watson in 1818 entitled a "Scheme for Colonizing the Island of St. Domingo with American Blacks" and a death notice of an Edgehill slave dated October 30, 1822.
(Acc. 5385-f)

div2.head: 536. JOHN RANDOLPH OF ROANOKE LETTER
div2.p:
1 item, June 11, 1821
Written to Walter Coles discussing his refusal to sell one of his slaves.
(Acc. 5076)
Guide available at http://ead.lib.virginia.edu/vivaead/published/uva-sc/viu00199.xml.frame

div2.head: 536-a. RICHARD RANDOLPH'S WILL
div2.p:
1 item, February 18, 1796
A copy of the last will of Richard Randolph of Bizarre in Cumberland County wherein he explained why he was emancipating his slaves and declared his opposition to slavery.
(Acc. 3882)

div2.head: 536a. RICHARD KIDDER RANDOLPH PAPERS
div2.p:
707 items, 1791-1932
Correspondence of Richard Kidder Randolph, a Virginian relocated in Rhode Island, and his wife Anne Maria Lyman Randolph. Documents of Richard Kidder Randolph's business travels along the East coast and Anne Maria (Lyman) Randolph's domestic life. include a 10 Dec 1810 letter about liquidation of their Virginia plantation and all holdings, including slaves. In a group of letters from Peyton Randolph to Richard Kidder Randolph from 1812 to 1844, there are many comments about slaves and slave sales.
(Acc. 5408)
Guide available at http://ead.lib.virginia.edu/vivaead/published/uva-sc/viu00057.xml.frame

div2.head: 537. VIRGINIA RANDOLPH BRIEF ESSAY
div2.p:
1 item, ca. 1949
This brief essay traces the educational career of this African American educator.
(Acc. 6625)

div2.head: 538. RANDOLPH-MACON COLLEGE NOTEBOOKS
div2.p:
2 items, 1855
One volume contains notes by Joseph Walker on Dr. Smith's proslavery lectures.
(Acc. 5042-a)

div2.head: 539. JOHN RANSDELL DIARY AND COMMONPLACE BOOK
div2.p:
1 item, 1840-65
Diary and commonplace book kept in Louisiana. There are very few references to African Americans except for a couple of pages about the disruption of the slaves when the Federal troops arrived.
(Acc. 2607)

div2.head: 540. "RECOLLECTIONS OF PIEDMONT"
div2.p:
1 item, ca. 1940
A typescript copy of Jane Maury Maverick's remembrances of Piedmont, the Albemarle County home of the Maurys. She wrote of moving to the University of Virginia after the Civil War because of fear of "roving negroes."
(Acc. 2129)

div2.head: 541. WILLIAM HENRY REDMAN PAPERS
div2.p:
880 items, 1860-1900
Civil War letters of a Union soldier from Illinois. Included are comments on African Americans, such as a May 8, 1864, letter telling of burning and sacking plantations in Louisiana and how many slaves followed the Union troops. A November 5, 1865, letter expresses Redman's violent opposition to suffrage for African Americans.
(Acc. 7415; -a)

div2.head: 542. REGISTER OF FREE BLACKS, WASHINGTON COUNTY
div2.p:
1 item, 1838-63
Includes descriptions of 144 free blacks including age, physical appearance, occupation, and manner in which freedom was obtained.
(Acc. 41-a)

div2.head: 542a. REID PAPERS
div2.p:
ca. 3300 items, 1767-1918
A miscellaneous collection of documents pertaining to the history of southside Virginia. Included are two volumes (1790-1814, 1814-1832) of the Church minutes of the County Line Baptist Church in Pittsylvania County which include information on African American members. These minute books are available only on microfilm (M-618). Also included are miscellaneous documents, such as bills of sale, authorization to form a company of "Patrollers" (1806), rental agreements, wills, runway notices, etc., pertaining to the history of slavery.
(Acc. 550)

div2.head: 543. REPUBLICAN PARTY (CHARLOTTESVILLE) PAPERS
div2.p:
3 items, 1900- 1922
Correspondence of the Charlottesville Republican party. Included are a list of the "colored" vote in 1900 and a 1911 form letter urging the recipient to help in the voter registration drive, signed by R. M. Flanagan.
(Acc. 9077)

div2.head: 543a. ROBERT RICH, EARL OF WARWICK PAPERS
div2.p:
91 items, 1607-24
Letters and documents assembled or copied by Warwick and his cousin Nathaniel Rich as evidence against the mismanagement of affairs in Virginia by the Virginia Company. The majority of the collection consists of petitions, inquiries, charges and counter-charges. Topics of interest include living conditions in the colony, relations with the Indians especially after the great massacre of 1622, the tobacco business, and the introduction of slavery (noted in a letter from William Capps, [Virginia], to John Ferrar, [England], 31 March and 1 April 1623).
(Acc. 9202)

div2.head: 544. DAVID RICHARDSON PAPERS
div2.p:
408 items, 1792-1839
Miscellaneous papers of this Louisa County resident. Included are a 1792 document emancipating some slaves and an 1839 warrant for the arrest of David Richardson and his slave Warner for allowing a slave to be at large contrary to law.
(Acc. 5616)

div2.head: 545. RICHMOND POLICE DAYBOOK
div2.p:
1 item, 1834-43
Contains entries on runaway slaves, etc. All entries differentiate subjects by race.
(Acc. 1481)

div2.head: 546. RIDDICK FAMILY PAPERS
div2.p:
ca. 70 items, 1739-1890
Mainly legal papers of this Nansemond County family. Included is a copy of an 1820 document exempting the Riddick estate from taxation on two slaves.
(Acc. 2227)

div2.head: 547. WILLIAM CABELL RIVES PAPERS
div2.p:
55 items, 1860-82
Papers of this Albemarle County and Boston, Massachusetts, lawyer. Chiefly letters from J. D. Osbourne, Paris; John C. Rutherfoord, Rock Castle; and Charles Morris, Hanover. Topics include the Civil War, Reconstruction, sharecropping, and the education of freedmen.
(Acc. 10596-a)
Guide available at http://ead.lib.virginia.edu/vivaead/published/uva-sc/vivadoc.pl?file=viu02130.xml

div2.head: 547a. WILLIAM CABELL RIVES PAPERS
div2.p:
ca. 190 items, 1824-42
Papers of this Representative and Senator from Virginia, born at "Oak Ridge," Nelson County, Virginia. Included beginning in 1842, correspondents write concerning the articles of the Webster-Ashburton Treaty dealing with the slave trade, and R.R. Greeley's invitation to hear Zion Harris, a resident of Liberia for the last twelve years, speak at the Colonization Society (1842 Jun 11).
(Acc. 11375)
Guide available at http://ead.lib.virginia.edu/vivaead/published/uva-sc/vivadoc.pl?file=viu01257.xml

div2.head: 548. RIVES FAMILY PAPERS
div2.p:
ca. 100 items, 1832-82
Personal and business papers of this family of Albemarle County, chiefly of Robert Rives, Jr., of Oakland near Warren. A February 23, 1850, letter from P. Rives to her brother Robert discusses the sale of slaves. Also, a January 18, 1850, letter from R. Pollard to Robert Rives mentions that male slaves were selling in Georgia and Florida at $1,000 to $1,200.
(Acc. 4289)

div2.head: 549. RIVES FAMILY PAPERS
div2.p:
5 items, ca. 1830-60
Included in this small collection is a May 29, 1838, letter from R. Pollard to Robert Rives of Nelson County complaining that the slaves on Pollard's plantation were mistreating his children in his absence and asking Rives to look into it.
(Acc. 6094)

div2.head: 550. RIVES FAMILY PAPERS
div2.p:
130 items, ca. 1832-82
Chiefly correspondence among members of the Rives family of Castle Hill, Cobham. Judith Page Walker Rives's letters discuss news of her family and friends and, during 1865-67, express her opinions concerning the effects of the Civil War on African Americans. On November 6, 1865, she mentioned a "free negro settlement" in Cobham to whom Dr. Eastham had offered work. On January 15, 1866, she wrote of the conditions and work relationships with African Americans after the war. And, in her letters of March 9 and 19 and June 15, 1867, she expressed her displeasure that African Americans had received the right to vote while her husband and son, Alfred Landon, had been disfranchised.
(Acc. 10596-c)
Guide available at http://ead.lib.virginia.edu/vivaead/published/uva-sc/vivadoc.pl?file=viu01014.xml

div2.head: 551. RIVES, SEARS, AND RHINELANDER FAMILY PAPERS
div2.p:
278 items, 1829-1953
Correspondence, business and legal papers, genealogical papers, diary, photographs, clippings, and memorabilia of the Rives family, especially
William Cabell Rives, Sr., Judith Page Walker Rives, William Cabell Rives, Jr., Grace Winthrop Sears Rives, and William Cabell Rives III. An 1845 letter describes a plantation on a Louisiana bayou and a slave-pulled towboat.
(Acc. 10596)
Guide available at http://ead.lib.virginia.edu/vivaead/published/uva-sc/vivadoc.pl?file=viu01013.xml

div2.head: 552. MANGUS ROBINSON PAPERS
div2.p:
11 items, 1894-99
A small collection of the personal and business correspondence of this editor of a African American newspaper, the Alexandria Leader.
(Acc. 1499)

div2.head: 553. THOMAS ROBINSON DOCUMENT
div2.p:
1 item, July 2, 1850
A list of Robinson's slaves sold by his estate in [Orange County].
(Acc. 6008)

div2.head: 554. JOHN CARR ROGERS PAPERS
div2.p:
2 items, 1971-72
In a June 9, 1972, letter Murrell Edmunds discussed his novel Behold, Thy Brother, about the coming of African Americans to the major leagues, and commented on Mark Twain's Letters from the Earth, which Edmunds was sending to Rogers.
(Acc. 6803-p)

div2.head: 555. RORER FAMILY PAPERS
div2.p:
ca. 500 items, ca. 1770-1935, microfilm (M-1385)
Business, legal, and personal papers of this family of Pittsylvania County. A diary entry for February 24, 1848, mentions that a slave named Margaret murdered a white female baby of the family of John Jones and Angeline Rorer Jones in Wentworth, North Carolina. In a journal is a "Register of Blacks, 1835-1865" with birth dates and mothers' names of family slaves.
(Acc. 7901)

div2.head: 555a. ROSSER FAMILY PAPERS
div2.p:
ca. 6000 items, ca. 1845-1940
Military, personal and professional papers of Confederate General Thomas L. Rosser, his family, and the Gordon and Winston families, all from Charlottesville, Virginia. Included in the financial and legal papers is a July 25, 1843 receipt for the purchase of a slave named George. Other documents of interest are African Americans in Reconstruction Montgomery, Ala., 1889; African American soldiers in the Spanish-American War; and an African American political meeting in Charlottesville Va., 1901.
(Acc. 1171-g, -h, -j)
Guide available at http://ead.lib.virginia.edu/vivaead/published/uva-sc/vivadoc.pl?file=viu03118.xml

div2.head: 556. RUST FAMILY PAPERS
div2.p:
ca. 1,500 items, 1820-95
Business and legal papers of this family of Loudoun County and Baltimore, Maryland, mainly those of Armistead Thomson Mason Rust and George T. Rust. A series of 1848-57 documents detail a number of slave purchases by George Rust and the hiring of slaves by A. T. M. Rust.
(Acc. 9706)

div2.head: 557. SABINE HALL PAPERS
div2.p:
ca. 500 items, 1659-1780
Business, legal, and personal papers of Landon Carter of Sabine Hall, Richmond County. Two of the personal letters mention slaves: a January 1, 1764, letter from Landon Carter, Jr., to Landon Carter mentioning a runaway slave and a 1770 letter from Charles Carter to Landon Carter complaining of runaways. A published guide is available: Walter Ray Wineman, The Landon Carter Papers in the University of Virginia Library (Charlottesville: University of Virginia Press, 1962).
(Acc. 1959)
Guide available at http://ead.lib.virginia.edu/vivaead/published/uva-sc/vivadoc.pl?file=viu03245.xml

div2.head: 557a. SIMON SALLARD LETTERS
div2.p:
5 items, 1732-37
Letters of the Nomini Hall overseer including 1732 Oct. 9 & Dec. 20 to Landon Carter regarding, 1736/7 Feb. 25 to Robert Chapman, Corotoman, regarding slaves, and 1737 April 15 & Aug. 22 to John Carter regarding drought, crops & slaves.
(Acc. 6488)

div2.head: 558. ROBERT ADDISON SCHOOLFIELD PAPERS
div2.p:
ca. 700 items, 1855-1973
Business correspondence and writings of one of the founders of the Riverside and Dan River Cotton Mills of Danville. In one of his manuscript histories of Dan River Mills, Schoolfield wrote of the riot of 1883 in Danville and the importing of North Carolina labor to "break negro rule."
(Acc. 10325)

div2.head: 558a. GEORGE SAMUEL SCHUYLER COLLECTION
div2.p:
3 items, ca. 1932, 1934, ca. 1966
Manuscript by African-American writer and journalist George Samuel Schuyler (1895-1977), on Dr. Robert Weaver (b. 1907) and the creation of the Department of Housing and Urban Development. Weaver was the first African American to serve in the cabinet of a US president. Also present is a small memorandum book, 1932, containing Schuyler's notes on cannibalism and lycanthropy, "When Man Eats Man," and a blank memorandum book "Plots / Articles, Sketches,"1934.
(Barrett Library Acc. 11071)

div2.head: 558b. "SECRET TWELVE CLUB" LEDGER
div2.p:
1 item,1935, 1949-55
Ledger of The Secret Twelve Club, an all male African-American social club in Charlottesville. Most entries were made between January 10, 1950, and February 22, 1955, and consist of minutes, membership lists, dues and assessments, "Rules and Regulations," initiation rituals, and donations of funds to various individuals and organizations such as the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People (NAACP).
(Acc. 11089)
Guide available at http://ead.lib.virginia.edu/vivaead/published/uva-sc/vivadoc.pl?file=viu01484.xml

div2.head: 559. SEWARD FAMILY PAPERS
div2.p:
ca. 300 items, 1857-88
Business and personal papers of William Seward of Isle of Wight County. The Seward farm journal, 1857-88, includes vital statistics for slaves.
(Acc. 38-60)

div2.head: 559a. ALEXIS J. SEYMOUR LETTER
div2.p:
1 item, 1861 July 15
Seymour was a soldier in the 4th Connecticut Infantry. Of interest in the letter are his discussions of the 40-50 "contraband" in camp whose appearance and behavior belie the stereotype.
(Acc. 15084)

div2.head: 560. DAVID SHAVER COLLECTION
div2.p:
1 item, ca. 1831
Memorial to the city of Lynchburg protesting the suppression of the African Baptist Church following the Nat Turner revolt.
(Acc. 1122)

div2.head: 561. SHEPHERD FAMILY PAPERS
div2.p:
ca. 2,000 items, 1817-83
Business and personal papers of this Fluvanna County family. Some interesting letters of 1870-71 concern the hiring out of African American people in Fluvanna County to work in the sugar refineries in Louisiana.
(Acc. 4241)

div2.head: 561a. SHEPHERD AND ALLIED FAMILY PAPERS
div2.p:
1 item, 1945
Genealogy of this family whose earliest antecedent was William Sheppard who settled in Henrico County, Va. in 1713. Appendices include transcripts from Henrico County, Va., Deed Books listing personal property including a slave. There is also an anecdote about Captain Benjamin Sheppard, a state tobacco inspector in Richmond and a free black named Aaron Johnson. (Acc. 4846-a)

div2.head: 561b. SHEPERDSTOWN COLLECTION
div2.p:
ca. 1500 items, 1748-1880
Collections from the Sheperdstown, Virginia (now West Virginia), and northern Shenandoah Valley area including sermons, ledgers, correspondence, receipts, and diaries of James Markell, merchant and slave trader, and John Hargrave, Presbyterian circuit rider, and various medical records of Dr. John Briscoe and Dr. John Quigley.
(Acc. 11104)
Guide available at http://ead.lib.virginia.edu/vivaead/published/uva-sc/vivadoc.pl?file=viu01287.xml

div2.head: 562. FRANCIS TROWBRIDGE SHERMAN PAPERS
div2.p:
1 item, microfilm, 1863-65
Diaries of this Union Army officer, 88th Illinois Cavalry, which give brief accounts of his participation in the Chattanooga, Atlanta, Shenandoah Valley, and Appomattox campaigns. He discussed camp life, prison conditions, rumors of the death of General Grant, and Confederate desertions and gave an account of several days spent in Charlottesville during which it was rumored that African Americans were plundering the town with the encouragement of the townspeople.
(Acc. 10735)

div2.head: 563. JERRY SHOWALTER COLLECTION
div2.p:
4 items, 1900-1912
Photographs of "Westcairns", Albemarle County. Westcairns on Ivy Road was for many years the McElroy residence; it is now the site of the Children's Rehabilitation Center. Photographs show both its construction and interior and exterior views of the completed house. An inscription on one indicates the house was "built by H B Boone and Kenneth Brown with negro 'hands' ranging from $2 a day to 25 cents. Average $1 or less. R E Shaw architect."
(Acc. 9732-g)
Guide available at http://ead.lib.virginia.edu/vivaead/published/uva-sc/vivadoc.pl?file=viu03955.xml

div2.head: 564. PHILIP SLAUGHTER DIARY
div2.p:
6 items, 1796-1878, microfilm (M-1934 vols. 1-3)
A diary kept by this Culpeper County farmer contains many entries on slaves, including information on slave births and deaths.
(Acc. 6556, -a, -b, -c)

div2.head: 565. SLAVE ACCOUNT LEDGER
div2.p:
1 item, 1817-27
Accounts of expenditures for slaves, 1817-27, near Warrenton, Virginia, perhaps contemporary copies from an old ledger. The origin of the ledger is unknown.
(Acc. 38-692)

div2.head: 566. SLAVE BILL OF SALE
div2.p:
1 item, January 25, 1845
Bill of sale by Joseph Dinwiddie for the sale of a female slave, Sarah, to William Dinwiddie for $700.
(Acc. 3194-h)

div2.head: 567. SLAVE BILL OF SALE
div2.p:
1 item, January 4, 1811
Bill of sale for a slave named Moses sold by William Morton of Louisa County to George Adams of Louisa County.
(Acc. 6159)

div2.head: 568. SLAVE DOCUMENTS
div2.p:
24 items, 1796, microfilm (M-1207)
These items are copies of material in Hampton University. They consist mainly of individual unrelated documents such as bills of sale, inventories, and manumission papers.
(Acc. 6428)

div2.head: 569. SLAVE DOCUMENTS
div2.p:
3 items, 1787-1827
Three miscellaneous documents, two of them slave bills of sale: one from Wickes County, Georgia, 1820, and the other an 1827 document conveying a number of slaves bought by Lewis Berkeley.
(Acc. 9661)

div2.head: 569a. SLAVE DOCUMENTS
div2.p:
2 items, 1816, 1861
Consists of a slave bill of sale, 1816 December 26, Andrew Squair, Albemarle County, Va., to Agnes Katherine Hamner, for a girl named Harriet; and a letter, 1861 September 20, C.J. Phillips, Walnut Grove, to John Collins, on behalf of Capt. J.W. Taylor, requesting advice on a slave who has made threats.
(Acc. 11147)

div2.head: 570. SLAVE PASS
div2.p:
1 item, April 24, 1864
Engineering Department slave pass from Richmond.
(Acc. 38-436-b)

div2.head: 570a. LIST OF SLAVE PRISONERS IN EASTERN DISTRICT MILITARY PRISON, RICHMOND, VA
div2.p:
1 item, 1864 November 30
Contains the names of 29 recaptured slaves from Virginia, Maryland, Tennessee, North Carolina, Kentucky, Missouri and Mississippi together with information on their color, age, date of commitment, place of arrest, and owner or residence.
(Acc. 11339)
Guide available at http://ead.lib.virginia.edu/vivaead/published/uva-sc/vivadoc.pl?file=viu01258.xml

div2.head: 571. SLAVE RECEIPT
div2.p:
1 item, September 30, 1824
Receipt for the sale of a slave woman and child.
(Acc 4400)

div2.head: 572. SLAVE SALE
div2.p:
1 item, December 27, 1841
A document authorizing the sale of the slave Reuben by Jeremiah Morton of Orange County to William W. Hume.
(Acc. 3383)

div2.head: 573. "SLAVES AT THE UNIVERSITY OF VIRGINIA"
div2.p:
1 item, 1965
An eight-page typescript by James J. Thomas.
(Acc. 8103)

div2.head: 574. SMITH FAMILY PAPERS
div2.p:
16 items, 1811-65, microfilm (M-609)
Correspondence, business, and legal papers of Nathaniel A. Smith and Mrs. Lavinia C. Smith of Louisa County and William O. Smith of Somerset, Orange County. Of special interest are slave evaluations made in 1840 by John C. Collins.
(Acc. 4186)

div2.head: 575. ELIZABETH OAKES SMITH PAPERS
div2.p:
ca. 4,000 items, 1820-95
Correspondence, diaries, literary manuscripts, essays, and newspaper columns of this nineteenth-century literary figure who was born in Maine and lived in South Carolina and New York. A diary she kept during the Civil War contains a lengthy description of the New York draft and race riot in 1863 involving attacks on African Americans.
(Acc. 38-707)
Guide available at http://ead.lib.virginia.edu/vivaead/published/uva-sc/vivadoc.pl?file=viu03614.xml

div2.head: 576. GERRIT SMITH COLLECTION
div2.p:
6 items, 1841-71
Five letters and one engraving of this noted American abolitionist and philanthropist. A September 22, 1841, letter to Pauline Wright was written on a pamphlet entitled Some of the Duties of an Abolitionist. Also included is a letter from Smith to Frederick Douglass, August 12, 1867 reminding Douglass of his promise to write a letter supporting Smith's efforts to present to the public "the purposes of our old friend J.B. [John Brown].
(Barrett Library Acc. 7210)
Guide available at http://ead.lib.virginia.edu/vivaead/published/uva-sc/viu02559.xml.frame

div2.head: 577. HOWARD W. SMITH PAPERS
div2.p:
ca. 30,000 items, 1933-60
Files and working papers of this Virginia congressman who represented the Eighth Congressional District for thirty-five years. Smith became a powerful figure as chairman of the Rules Committee and was a strong opponent of civil rights legislation. Included in the collection is much material related to civil rights legislation and segregation.
(Acc. 8731)
Guide available at http://ead.lib.virginia.edu/vivaead/published/uva-sc/vivadoc.pl?file=viu03824.xml

div2.head: 578. MARY WATSON SMITH PAPERS
div2.p:
90 items, 1814-84
Chiefly letters written by Mrs. Smith of Charlottesville to her sister. Her letters include comments on slavery.
(Acc. 1624)

div2.head: 579. R. B. SMITH ACCOUNT BOOK
div2.p:
1 item, 1855-62
Account book kept by an Amelia County merchant. Included are many entries on two hired-out slaves, Henry and Phoenix.
(Acc. 5800)

div2.head: 579a. SNOW FAMILY PAPERS
div2.p:
33 items, 1754-1935
Papers of the Snow family of Bedford County, Va. and the related Thompson family. Items include a bond for the use of an African American blacksmith and a transcript of the 1842 will of Clement Jordan mentioning three slaves to remain unsold.
(Acc. 4739)

div2.head: 580. SOCIETY FOR THE PREVENTION OF ABDUCTION AND ABSCONDING OF SLAVES MINUTES
div2.p:
1 item, 1833-49
This Richmond and Henrico County society offered rewards for information leading to, or the actual return of, runaway slaves.
(Acc. 9272)

div2.head: 580a. SOUTHERN ELECTIONS FUNDS PAPERS
div2.p:
ca. 5,500 items, ca. 1968-1975
Papers of the Southern Elections Fund including professional and personal correspondence of Julian Bond, the fund's chairman. Included are correspondence, mailing lists, newsletters, printed material, photographs, slides, videotapes, and miscellany produced by the various officers and trustees of the organization. The fund was established to funnel campaign funds and technical assistance to progressive southern political candidates. Support from the fund was instrumental in the election of many southern Afro-American candidates. Among the correspondents are Robert Struass, Lawrence F. O'Brien, Anne Wexler, Hubert Humphrey, William Brown, John Lewis, John Conyers, Andrew Young, Ralph David Abernathy, and Walter Mondale.
(Acc. 10907)
Guide available at http://ead.lib.virginia.edu/vivaead/published/uva-sc/vivadoc.pl?file=viu01511.xml

div2.head: 580b. SOUTHERN STUDENT ORGANIZING COMMITTEE PAPERS
div2.p:
ca. 3,600 items, ca. 1960-80
A series of collections consisting of the papers of the Southern Student Organizing Committee, 1964-1968, "an association of young, concerned Southerners dedicated to social change" formed in the spring of 1964. There is considerable correspondence and material concerning civil rights and race relations in Southern educational institutions. Included are the papers of members Archie Allen and Thomas Gardner.
(Acc. 11192, a-f)
Guide for 11192 available at http://ead.lib.virginia.edu/vivaead/published/uva-sc/vivadoc.pl?file=viu01447.xml
Guide for 11192-a available at http://ead.lib.virginia.edu/vivaead/published/uva-sc/vivadoc.pl?file=viu01448.xml
Guide for 11192-b,c,d available at http://ead.lib.virginia.edu/vivaead/published/uva-sc/vivadoc.pl?file=viu01449.xml
Guide for 11192-e available at http://ead.lib.virginia.edu/vivaead/published/uva-sc/vivadoc.pl?file=viu01450.xml
Guide for 11192-f available at http://ead.lib.virginia.edu/vivaead/published/uva-sc/vivadoc.pl?file=viu01451.xml

div2.head: 581. SOUTHSIDE VIRGINIA FAMILY PAPERS
div2.p:
ca. 2,500 items, 1770-1920
Included are quite a few scattered references to slavery, such as doctor's bills for treating slaves, acknowledgment of pay for keeping a family of slaves for a year, bill of hire for a slave child, and an agreement for transporting and sale of slaves. A letter from the sheriff of Marion reports the capture of a runaway slave who had been traveling with a white woman; the slave had been dressed as a woman and his accomplice as a man.
(Acc. 550)

div2.head: 582. SPAULDING PAPERS
div2.p:
22 items, 1859-65
The personal letters and diary of Henry S. Spaulding, captain in the 38th Company, New Jersey Volunteers. A March 25, 1865, letter from Spaulding to Lieutenant E. G. Smith describes a disturbance in camp caused by the "Colored Cavalry."
(Acc. 38-156)
Guide available at http://ead.lib.virginia.edu/vivaead/published/uva-sc/vivadoc.pl?file=viu03846.xml

div2.head: 582a. WILLIAM B. SPONG PAPERS
div2.p:
ca. 291,000 items, 1965-74
Contains papers pertaining to the political career of William B. Spong, Jr. of Portsmouth, Virginia, in the United States Senate. Of interest are legislative files on civil rights issues from the Judiciary Committee.
(Acc. 9838)
Guide available at http://ead.lib.virginia.edu/vivaead/published/uva-sc/vivadoc.pl?file=viu02199.xml

div2.head: 583. ALEXANDER SPOTSWOOD MANUSCRIPT
div2.p:
1 item, 1739
This Virginia colonial governor prepared a manuscript entitled "Proposals for Leasing My Ironworks at Tuball" in which he included a good description of how slaves were to be leased. In 1716 Spotswood created the first iron foundry in the colony and the first to use an almost exclusive slave labor force.

div2.head: 583a. SPOTSYLVANIA COUNTY INDENTURE
div2.p:
1 item, July 7, 1834
An agreement between Lewis L. Holladay, John [Jerdone?], and Jessee H. Stubbs, of Spotsylvania County, Virginia, conveying the slaves Betsy, Ellen, and Albert, and numerous items of personal property.
(Acc. 11287)
Guide available at http://ead.lib.virginia.edu/vivaead/published/uva-sc/vivadoc.pl?file=viu01357.xml

div2.head: 583b. STANLEY-CLARKE FAMILY COLLECTION
div2.p:
26 items, 1925-92
Papers and miscellaneous related items pertaining to the civic, social, and professional activities of a Charlottesville, African-American family: Mary C. Stanley (1901-91) and her brother, George Albert Clarke (1910-92), a World War II veteran. Items include Mary's beautician diploma and various materials regarding her membership in Blue Ridge Temple 67 (Daughters of the Improved, Benevolent, Protective Order of Elks of the World); military ribbons and insignia and a letter to George from a fellow soldier while stationed in France, May 1945; and a photographic china plate: "Future Home For The Need--Richmond, Virginia / Purchased by Virginia State Baptist Deacon's Convention and Women's Auxiliary, Inc."
(Acc. 10396-B)

div2.head: 584. STEWART FAMILY PAPERS
div2.p:
ca. 900 items, 1829-41
Business, legal, and personal correspondence of a Richmond family, much of it involving the tobacco business. The frequent references to the buying and selling of slaves include a January 4, 1836, letter from Bryce Stewart to Daniel Stewart commenting on the price of slaves and noting that it was cheaper to buy slaves than hire them.
(Acc. 7786-t)
Guide available at http://ead.lib.virginia.edu/vivaead/published/uva-sc/vivadoc.pl?file=viu03513.xml

div2.head: 585. WILLIAM STOKES CIVIL WAR DIARY
div2.p:
1 item, 1862-65
Brief diary of William Stokes, lieutenant colonel in the 4th South Carolina Cavalry, CSA.
