There are two entries on African Americans: a September 14, 1863, description of a skirmish with a African American outfit, the 1st South Carolina Negro Regiment, at Green Pond, South Carolina; and an engagement on June 28-29, 1864, near Stormy Creek in central Virginia where some 500 or 600 African Americans were recaptured from Federal troops.
(Acc. 7896)

div2.head: 585a. KATHYRN H. STONE PAPERS
div2.p:
ca. 13,500 items, 1881-1988
Papers pertaining to her service in the General Assembly of Virginia, her involvement in the League of Women Voters, her work in the planning of Reston, Virginia, and various topics of interest or concern including civil rights, desegregation, education, health, and women's issues. Material on African American issues may be found under various headings such as "Desegregation," "J. Lindsay Almond, Jr.: Massive Resistance," "Leon Dure," "Gray Commission," and "National Association for the Advancement of Colored People," among others.
(Acc. 10555-a)
Guide available at http://ead.lib.virginia.edu/vivaead/published/uva-sc/vivadoc.pl?file=viu01009.xml

div2.head: 586. HARRIET BEECHER STOWE COLLECTION
div2.p:
110 items, ca. 1825-95
Letters and manuscripts of the author of Uncle Tom's Cabin. Many of the letters discuss Stowe's and others' attitudes on slavery and mention individual slaves and episodes of slavery.
(Barrett Library Acc. 6318)

div2.head: 586a. STROTHER FAMILY GENEALOGY
div2.p:
1 item, 1983
Printed genealogy of Strother family by Carol L. Merrill. Of special interest because it pertains to an African-American family with origins in Charlottesville.
(Acc. 10953)

div2.head: 586b. DAVID HUNTER STROTHER DRAWNGS
div2.p:
2 items, ca. 1857
David Hunter Strother, illustrator drew pencil and ink sketches under the pseudonym Porte Crayon for Harpers Monthly. These are two sketches of African Americans.
(Acc. 6491)

div2.head: 587. STUART FAMILY PAPERS
div2.p:
ca. 600 items, ca. 1650-1900
Business, legal, and personal papers of this family of Stafford and King George counties. The few slave references include a 1798 slave contract; a series of papers, 1835-52, including slave bills of sale; a group of papers from the trust estate of George Turberville of Fairfax County including lists of slaves and expenses for their clothes and their hires per year; letters, 1860-61, between Richard H. Stuart and his son-in-law Sholto Turbervillie Stuart concerning the sale of slaves to Samuel R. Walker [a slave dealer?] and an 1862 deed of manumission.
(Acc. 6406)

div2.head: 588. ALEXANDER H. H. STUART PAPERS
div2.p:
ca. 500 items, 1791-1895
Personal correspondence of this prominent lawyer and politician of Staunton. Included are such items as a slave sale in 1814, a will providing for transference of slaves, and a mounted clipping on the Virginia Secession Convention. There is a copy of the Report of the Joint Committee of the General Assembly on the Harpers Ferry Outrages, most of its twenty-four pages constituting a defense of slavery and an attack on the treatment of African Americans in the North.
(Acc. 345)
Guide available at http://ead.lib.virginia.edu/vivaead/published/uva-sc/vivadoc.pl?file=viu03232.xml

div2.head: 589. STUART-BALDWIN PAPERS
div2.p:
ca. 15,000 items, ca. 1780-1850
A large collection consisting almost solely of the legal, financial, and personal correspondence of Archibald Stuart and Briscoe Baldwin, lawyers from Staunton, and their related family letters. There are very few references to slavery, e.g., the June 6, 1820, sale of a slave and letters of April 10 and May 2, 1823, from P. H. Leuba to Miss Mary Jane Lewis discussing the health of slaves.
(Acc. 228)
Guide available at http://ead.lib.virginia.edu/vivaead/published/uva-sc/vivadoc.pl?file=viu00193.xml

div2.head: 589a. LEWIS PRESTON SUMMERS PAPERS
div2.p:
ca. 20,500 items, 1814-1947
Papers of Lewis Preston Summers, a lawyer, genealogist, member of the Republican Party, and author of Abingdon, Virginia, containing correspondence concerning genealogy, the history of Southwest Virginia, and politics, especially local politics of the ninth Virginia district. Included are lists of voters for the ninth district many that show the names African American voters.
(Acc. 2781)
Guide available at http://ead.lib.virginia.edu/vivaead/published/uva-sc/vivadoc.pl?file=viu01394.xml

div2.head: 589b. SURRY COURT HOUSE POST OFFICE PHOTOGRAPH
div2.p:
1 item, 1865-70
Wet-plate albumen sepia photograph of the post office building at Surry Court House, Virginia, taken during Reconstruction, shows a group of men including two Union cavalrymen and an African American man posed in front of the building.
(Acc. 11077)
Guide available at http://ead.lib.virginia.edu/vivaead/published/uva-sc/vivadoc.pl?file=viu01492.xml

div2.head: 590. SYDNOR AND CARTER FAMILY PAPERS
div2.p:
ca. 50 items, ca. 1780-1905
Business and legal papers of William Sydnor of Christ Church Parish, Lancaster County, and the Carter family of Frederick County. Included are legal papers mainly involving the purchase and sale of slaves by William A. Carter.
(Acc. 6405)

div2.head: 590a. TABB FAMILY LETTERS
div2.p:
4 items, 147-61
Adam Foster, "Auburn," Mathews County to "Cynthia." Foster discusses the house and grounds of "Auburn," and the plantation of his son-in-law, Dr. Henry Wythe Tabb. Foster describes the living conditions of slaves as well as lumbering, oyster fishing, the Dismal Swamp and Christmas festivities in Mathews County. (Acc. 8972)

div2.head: 590b. TALBOT FAMILY BIBLE RECORDS
div2.p:
1 item, 1739
Copies of bible records [of the Bedford County, Family?] taken from the family Bible (Baskett Bible, Oxford, 1739) that contain births of slaves.
(Acc. 5742)

div2.head: 591. GENERAL WILLIAM BOOTH TALIAFERRO PAPERS
div2.p:
ca. 15 items, 1823-1939
A small collection of papers of this Confederate general from Gloucester County. Included is an 1862 slave list.
(Acc. 4536)

div2.head: 592. TAYLOE FAMILY PAPERS
div2.p:
4 items, 1708-1890
Business ledgers of Henry A., Benjamin Ogle, and Edward Thornton Tayloe of King George County. A farm journal for 1850-69 contains annual slave inventories, a reference to runaways, etc. The 1708-10 Lloyd brothers' store journal includes an "Account of sales of a Cargo of Slaves Imported in the Leopard . . . from Guinea Virginia July 4, 1710."
(Acc. 38-62)
Guide available at http://ead.lib.virginia.edu/vivaead/published/uva-sc/vivadoc.pl?file=viu00963.xml

div2.head: 593. TAYLOE FAMILY PAPERS
div2.p:
ca. 300 items, 1830-93
A group of business and family letters. Much of the correspondence is between Henry A. Tayloe in Alabama and his brother Benjamin Ogle Tayloe in Virginia and centers around the business of getting Virginia slaves to Alabama. There are many accounts of sales and prices. Other references to slaves and African American farmhands after the war fill these letters.
(Acc. 38-630, 5854)
Guide available at http://ead.lib.virginia.edu/vivaead/published/uva-sc/vivadoc.pl?file=viu01020.xml

div2.head: 594. TAYLOR FAMILY PAPERS
div2.p:
ca. 500 items, ca. 1800-1890, microfilm (M-2109)
Personal, legal, and business correspondence of this family of Westmoreland County. References to slavery include a December 31, 1863, letter from Henry Taylor refusing to hire out his slave to Thomas Watson because the slave was previously returned from Watson without the usual clothes provided and a June 5, 1865 letter of William Robertson in Charlottesville to Henry Taylor discussing and outlining the results of a meeting of "Masters" about how they would handle emancipation.
(Acc. 9653)

div2.head: 595. TAYLOR FAMILY PAPERS
div2.p:
ca. 470 items, ca. 1760-1910
Personal and military papers of John Cowdery Taylor and Dr. Harry Taylor, Sr., of Norfolk. Included is a diary of the siege of Vicksburg in 1863. There are numerous references to slaves leaving masters or being taken by Federal troops.
(Acc. 9965)

div2.head: 595a. JOHN TAYLOR OF CAROLINE LETTERS
div2.p:
2 items, 1804-1809
Letter from Taylor to Benjamin Oliver [Junior], 1809 July 10, on financial matters. He also notes that both he and his sons have blacksmiths and he "would not give more for one, unless his character was very good, than for a field negro."
(Acc. 5734)

div2.head: 595b. CHARLES ELISHA TAYLOR PAPERS
div2.p:
ca. 550 items, 1849-74
Chiefly letters concerning the Civil War service of Charles Elisha Taylor with his family in Richmond and numerous friends from around the country. During the Civil War, Taylor was a member of Company F of Richmond and served under General Lee in the West Virginia campaign and with General Stonewall Jackson until the Battle of Kernstown, where he was wounded. In a letter from Richmond date April 5, 1866 his wife Mary describes a church fair where there was a large turnout of Negroes "who love the Southern people. The Negroes, she says, are sending circulars throughout the city telling their friends they were not going to celebrate the fall of the Confederacy-only their freedom.
(Acc. 3091 & 5186)
Guide available at http://ead.lib.virginia.edu/vivaead/published/uva-sc/viu03018.xml.frame

div2.head: 595c. ALFRED GEORGE TEBAULT PAPERS
div2.p:
ca. 50 items, 1836-91
Tebault, a physician in Norfolk and London Bridge, Princess Anne Co., kept case books on various fevers. He had a special interest in statistics and compiled tables of age, sex, race, and complications suffered by his patients. In volume 5 of the medical notebooks is a page entitled Synopsis of cases among Blacks in 1836 and in volume 6, pages 35 & 36 are entitled Bilious Fever in the Negro.
(Acc. 9926)

div2.head: 596. TEMPLEMAN AND GOODWIN LEDGER
div2.p:
1 item, 1849-1851
A bound manuscript, account book of H. N. Templeman and W. H. Goodwin. Contains entries on their business of trading slaves listing date, name of slave, age, price paid, date of sale, name of buyer, and price received.
(Acc. 11036)
Guide available at http://ead.lib.virginia.edu/vivaead/published/uva-sc/vivadoc.pl?file=viu01522.xml

div2.head: 596a. VIRGINIUS BRAY THORNTON LETTER
div2.p:
1 item, 1961
Thornton, an African American graduate student at the University of Virginia, writes "To Whom It May Concern" and answers an unsigned note calling him a "Black Animal."
(Acc. 8168)

div2.head: 597. THRIFT FAMILY PAPERS
div2.p:
20 items, 1825-75
Consists mainly of the private correspondence of Dr. George N. Thrift of Madison County. One letter of December 15, 1846, from Thrift to an unknown correspondent concerns a runaway slave named Adam.
(Acc. 9153)

div2.head: 597a. FRANCIS LEE THURMAN LETTERS
div2.p:
2 items, 1827, 1860
Includes a letter, 1860, from Elizabeth C. Blaetterman, Maysville, Ky., concerning teaching, family news, the manumission of her slaves in Virginia, and their current employment. (Acc. 799)

div2.head: 598. THURMOND FAMILY PAPERS
div2.p:
23 items, 1820-1900
Included is an 1842-93 plantation account book with a few slave entries and a slave bill of sale of November 29, 1820.
(Acc. 1490)

div2.head: 599. TIMBERLAKE FAMILY PAPERS
div2.p:
4 items, 1780-1855
Family Bible records containing a few slave entries.
(Acc. 9769)

div2.head: 600. TOOLE FAMILY PAPERS
div2.p:
ca. 700 items, 1860-1901
Correspondence of this Albemarle County family, mainly of John Toole. Included is a May 8, 1901, letter from a former slave to "old Mistress" (Jane Toole).
(Acc. 4876-e)
Guide available at http://ead.lib.virginia.edu/vivaead/published/uva-sc/vivadoc.pl?file=viu03361.xml

div2.head: 601. KELLY WALKER TRIMBLE PAPERS
div2.p:
ca. 5,000 items, ca. 1770-1950, microfilm (M-791-93)
Consists of personal and business papers of the Trimble, Wilson, and Love families of Augusta County. There are scattered slavery documents such as deeds of sale in the Wilson papers dated January 13 and August 11, 1810, August 1, 1861, and January 1, 1863. Also includes letters, 1858-1870, to John Wilson and Robert Love from William S. Love (with 9th Louisiana Vols.), S.J. Love, and Love family members, about many topics including slaves in Natchez during the war.
(Acc. 7792)

div2.head: 602. TRIST, BURKE, AND RANDOLPH FAMILY PAPERS
div2.p:
ca. 1,500 items, 1721-1969
Mainly personal and legal papers of Nicholas Philip Trist and the related families of Albemarle County. There is very little mention of slavery in the personal correspondence except for a few scattered letters such as one of November 22, 1818, from Thomas Mann Randolph to Nicholas Trist mentioning an incident at a neighboring Albemarle plantation owned by the Higginbothams involving the hanging suicide of a male slave who apparently took his own life because of punishment inflicted by a new overseer.
(Acc. 10487)

div2.head: 603. TUCKER FAMILY PAPERS
div2.p:
6 items, 1797-1843
Business ledgers of this family of Brunswick County. One of the volumes contains overseers' records for the period 1821-26.
(Acc. 3483)

div2.head: 604. TUCKER, HARRISON, AND SMlTH FAMILY PAPERS
div2.p:
ca. 22,500 items, ca. 1790-1940
Business, legal, and personal correspondence of these three Virginia families, much of it involving the University of Virginia. Scattered references to slavery include a March 14, 1861, letter from Gessner Harrison to Eliza Tucker Harrison threatening to whip a "malingering" slave and an August 27, 1862, letter on the cost of winter clothing for slaves.
(Acc. 3847)
Guide available at http://ead.lib.virginia.edu/vivaead/published/uva-sc/vivadoc.pl?file=viu03310.xml

div2.head: 605. NATHANIEL BEVERLY TUCKER PAPERS
div2.p:
ca. 100 items, 1857-61
Letters between Tucker and his relatives while he was serving as consul in Liverpool, England, in 1851-61. The letters from Virginia were mainly from relatives at Tucker's home in Jefferson County. Many of them contain news of the slaves: on January 30, 1853, the slave Mammy requested that she be taken to her grave in a hearse, and a March 28, 1856, letter mentions typhoid among slaves.
(Acc. 10321)

div2.head: 606. HENRY TUTWILER PAPERS
div2.p:
19 items, ca. 1835-1950
Papers of Tutwiler and family of Virginia and Greene Springs, Alabama. Included are the alleged recollections of Le Grand Tutwiler, former slave of Tutwiler.
(Acc. 10156-a)

div2.head: 607. TWYMAN FAMILY PAPERS
div2.p:
300 items, ca. 1790-1890
Business, legal, and personal papers of this Albemarle County family. Slavery material includes a February 15, 1838, letter from George Twyman to his brother and mother in which he mentioned hearing that they had lost a female slave and her baby; he was "very sorry to hear of your losses in your black's." Two daybooks have frequent entries on the hiring of slaves. Also included are a transcript of will, 1733, of George Twyman; slave bill of sale, 1799, Albemarle County; another slave bill of sale, 1827, Albemarle County, with names of slaves; and correspondence and legal papers, 1842-1855, pertaining to settlement of Richard H. Johnson's estate.
(Acc. 7808)

div2.head: 607a. TWYMAN FAMILY PAPERS
div2.p:
190 items, ca. 1835-65
Papers of the Twyman family of Albemarle County. Included is a June 30, 1839 letter discussing specifics of the sale of Albert, a slave, for $700 and Albert's poor health lowered his selling price.
(Acc. 11549)
Guide available at http://ead.lib.virginia.edu/vivaead/published/uva-sc/vivadoc.pl?file=viu01231.xml

div2.head: 608. JOHN TYLER LETTER
div2.p:
11 items, 1798-1868, microfilm (M-517)
Included in these letters is an 1857 letter by Tyler in which he commented on the African slave trade.
(Acc. 3402)

div2.head: 608a. GEORGE B. AND ROBERT H. TYLER FARM ACCOUNT BOOK
div2.p:
1 item, 1851-88
An account book for "The Shelter," Prince William County, Va., contains accounts for the sale of wheat, corn, oats and cattle and the hire of servants. (Acc. 11304) Guide available at http://ead.lib.virginia.edu/vivaead/published/uva-sc/vivadoc.pl?file=viu01293.xml

div2.head: 608b. TYLER AND RELATED FAMILIES PAPERS
div2.p:
ca. 1350 items, 1765-1986
Family papers of the Tyler and Martin families of Bedford and Amherst counties, Va. Included are a tax receipt to Howard Martin for "1 Negro" (1821); and a "Negro" hire for James D. Martin (1860), and among the legal and financial papers of William H. Tyler are tax receipts for slaves (1859).
(Acc. 11250, a, b, c)
Guide available at http://ead.lib.virginia.edu/vivaead/published/uva-sc/vivadoc.pl?file=viu01303.xml

div2.head: 608c. UNITED STATES ARMY 27TH COLORED INFANTRY REGIMENT
div2.p:
1 item, 1864
Muster and payroll of Company G, 1864 April 30 to June 30. It contains major column headings for name, mustered into service, last paid, remarks, received payment, witness.
(Acc. 11402)
Guide available at http://ead.lib.virginia.edu/vivaead/published/uva-sc/vivadoc.pl?file=viu01242.xml

div2.head: 609. UNIVERSITY OF VIRGINIA ARCHIVES
div2.p:
ca. 2,000,000 items, 1818-
Many of the early records contain information on slavery at the university, e.g., the faculty minutes, proctor's papers, and the board of visitors minutes. The president's papers are a good source for material on integration in the South and at the university in the 1950s and 1960s.

div2.head: 609a. JACOB VAN LEAR COLLECTION
div2.p:
14 items, 1812-35
Letters of Jacob Van Lear, Christian's Creek, Augusta, Co., Va., consisting chiefly of letters concerning family, health, deaths, financial matters, religion, slaves, and crops.
(Acc. 11303)
Guide available at http://ead.lib.virginia.edu/vivaead/published/uva-sc/vivadoc.pl?file=viu01292.xml

div2.head: 610. VIRGINIA COLONIAL RECORDS PROJECT
div2.p:
ca. 80,000 items, ca. 1580-1780, 960 reels of microfilm
This project was established in the 1950s by the Virginia Historical Society, Colonial Williamsburg Foundation, University of Virginia Library, and the Virginia State Library to reconstitute the archive of Virginia's colonial history through a systematic survey of records in public and private collections in England and to a much lesser extent in Scotland, France, and Spain and by ordering microfilm of many of the original documents. There is much on slavery and the slave trade. The two-volume work by Charles M. Andrews, A Guide to the Materials for American History, to 1783, in the Public Record Office of Great Britain, is a good guide to the British records and thus to the project. The 14,000 + Survey Reports are available at all four participating institutions, and the microfilm may be borrowed from the University of Virginia. Preparation of a personal-name index to the Survey Reports is under way for eventual publication.
Guide on instructions to access VCRP available at http://www.lva.lib.va.us/whatwehave/notes/rn7_colrecords.pdf

div2.head: 611. VIRGINIA COMMITTEE FOR PUBLIC SCHOOLS PAPERS
div2.p:
ca. 1,500 items, 1958-60
Personal papers of J. L. B. Buck as president of the Virginia Committee for Public Schools. Organized to keep Virginia public schools intact, this committee opposed the policy of "massive resistance" to school integration.
(Acc. 7783,-a)
Guide available at http://ead.lib.virginia.edu/vivaead/published/uva-sc/vivadoc.pl?file=viu03516.xml

div2.head: 612. VIRGINIA LETTERS COLLECTION
div2.p:
440 items, 1776-1930
Included is an 1831 estate account of Lawrence Washington containing a list of slaves hired out.
(Acc. 5736)

div2.head: 612a. LETTERS PERTAINING TO VIRGINIA
div2.p:
9 items, 1821-67
The collection contains nine letters from various Virginia families. Three letters (1829-1849) deal with slavery in Virginia and Tennessee. The December 5, 1829 letter from L. Smithson, Jr., Lynchburg, Virginia, is chiefly about hiring workmen, but he mentions a runaway named "Joe" who had been gone for some time. The March 1, 1846 letter from C.S. Palmore of Spring Hill, Fayette County, Tennessee, to Edward S. Brown, an attorney in Ballsville, Virginia, mentions the sale of negroes and one in particular named "George". A letter from H.W. Fry, Richmond, Virginia to [A.N. Montgomery of Lynchburg], April 20, 1849 mentions in the postscript the bond for a slave's hire.
(Acc. 11006)
Guide available at http://ead.lib.virginia.edu/vivaead/published/uva-sc/vivadoc.pl?file=viu01541.xml

div2.head: 613. MISCELLANEOUS VIRGINIA LETTERS
div2.p:
ca. 50 items, 1803-81
Letters and legal and business documents by and about Virginians collected by Charles Affleck. Included are a number of slave documents, such as purchase and hiring agreements including a court order for a summons for a female slave for burning a barn of John Kemp, 1806 April 24.
(Acc. 7083)
Guide available at http://ead.lib.virginia.edu/vivaead/published/uva-sc/viu03903.xml.frame

div2.head: 613a. VIRGINIA PHOTOGRAPH COLLECTION
div2.p:
6 items, 1860-1901
Included is an undated photograph of Patsy Harden, an ex-slave from Staunton, Virginia.
(Acc. 11157)
Guide available at http://ead.lib.virginia.edu/vivaead/published/uva-sc/vivadoc.pl?file=viu01418.xml

div2.head: 613b. VIRGINIA SLAVE PRICE LETTER
div2.p:
1 item, February 2, 1857
Partial letter, Farmville, Va., to Peter B. Boaz, Murray, Ky., describing the current prices for slaves in Virginia.
(Acc. 11410)
Guide available at http://ead.lib.virginia.edu/vivaead/published/uva-sc/vivadoc.pl?file=viu02089.xml

div2.head: 613c. VIRGINIA 19TH CENTURY VOLUMES
div2.p:
3 items, 1851-1871
Included is a memorandum book, 1861-1866, kept by Edward S. Brown of Cumberland County, recording medical and legal fees, travel expenses, and slave hires.
(Acc. 9096-ai)

div2.head: 613d. GEORGE E. WAGNER COLLECTION
div2.p:
71 items, 1861-1904
Papers of Lieutenant Colonel George Emil Williams of Philadelphia County, Pennsylvania, an officer of United States Colored Troops during the Civil War. Letters, military commissions, quartermaster returns, special orders and miscellaneous documents pertain to his career and service with the 88th Pennsylvania Volunteer Infantry and the 6th, 8th and 9th regiments of United States Colored Troops, chiefly with the 88th Pennsylvania and the 8th USCT. Wagner participated in the training of African-American Union soldiers at Camp Penn, the site of a specialized facility, the "Free Military School for Applicants for Command of Colored Troops" [December 1863 to September 1864] for the instruction of white Union officers designated for command of African American troops.)
(Acc. 11174)
Guide available at http://ead.lib.virginia.edu/vivaead/published/uva-sc/vivadoc.pl?file=viu01369.xml

div2.head: 614. WALKER FAMILY PAPERS
div2.p:
ca. 1,300 items, ca. 1780-1880
Mostly family letters of the Walker family of Rockbridge County. In the business and legal papers are a few scattered slave items, such as an 1825 letter referring to the sale of slaves to provide cash, an 1837 letter listing high slave prices in Missouri, and an 1837 letter discussing the need for slaves for rent in Missouri, at double the Virginia rates.
(Acc. 1532)
Guide available at http://ead.lib.virginia.edu/vivaead/published/uva-sc/vivadoc.pl?file=viu03509.xml

div2.head: 615. MARY BALL WALL PAPERS
div2.p:
ca. 250 items, ca. 1850-1910
Mostly letters sent to this resident of Winchester. One letter dated May 1, 1864, discusses the deployment of African American Union soldiers in that city. Several other letters contain general references to African Americans.
(Acc. 10482)

div2.head: 616. WALLACE FAMILY PAPERS
div2.p:
210 items, 1799-1880
Family correspondence and legal documents of this family of Albemarle County and the related Rogers family of Albemarle and Carter and Woodson families of Goochland County. An 1837-43 account book of Michael Wallace contains entries on the sale and hiring of slaves.
(Acc. 2689)

div2.head: 617. WALLACE FAMILY PAPERS
div2.p:
ca. 115 items, 1750-1864
Primarily the papers of Dr. Michael Wallace and his six sons of King George County. Of special interest are the letters of his son Michael concerning a suit involving counterclaims on a female slave.
(Acc. 38-150)

div2.head: 618. WALLACE FAMILY PAPERS
div2.p:
ca. 2,500 items, ca. 1790-1900
Business correspondence and documents and personal correspondence of Michael Wallace of Madison County. There are scattered references to slavery, such as a May 12, 1833, note of sale of a family of slaves to H. H. Wallace with the understanding that the family would be kept together; an 1837 list of the slaves on Michael Wallace's estate; and an April 22, 1833, letter discussing the price of slaves and stating: "The cholera has thinned the Negros much on the coast and the South generally and they are then said to be selling very high."
(Acc. 10241)

div2.head: 619. WASHINGTON FAMILY PAPERS
div2.p:
ca. 500 items, ca. 1800-1875
Receipts, account books, deeds, and some correspondence of this Caroline County family. An 1830-47 notebook of accounts of John Washington with George Buckner contains notations on the hiring of slaves and the repairing of slaves' shoes. Laid in a farm account book of John Washington is a page detailing the birth dates of slaves for 1794-1838.
(Acc. 3683)

div2.head: 619a. WASHINGTON FAMILY PAPERS
div2.p:
49 items, 1770-1883
Correspondence and documents related to the Washington family residing near Winchester, Virginia. Included is a letter from W. H. Washington to Bushrod Washington 1794 Mar 22 discussing ownership of Dick, a slave who belonged to Philip Alexander and a letter, 29 December 1837, from F.W. Pickens to his father, regarding Southern politics, family matters, and the health of his slaves.
(Acc. 317)

div2.head: 619b. GEORGE WASHINGTON ESTATE PAPERS
div2.p:
98 items, 1784-1870
Letters and documents pertaining to the settlement of the estate of George Washington and the business concerns of the Washington family. Most of the correspondence is addressed to Bushrod Washington and Lawrence Lewis, executors of George Washington's estate. A letter of William Bright to Lawrence Lewis 1828 Sep 27 discusses the payment by the United States Treasury to recompense him for his slave taken away by the British.
(Acc. 7797 f, -g)
Guide available at http://ead.lib.virginia.edu/vivaead/published/uva-sc/viu02365.xml.frame

div2.head: 620. WASHINGTON, LEWIS, AND MADISON FAMILY PAPERS
div2.p:
153 items, 1768-1866
Consists mainly of the personal and political correspondence of these important Virginia families. In the Madison collection is an 1844 deed for slaves and a January 22, 1853, letter from John Tyler to Thomas Ritchie concerning the emancipation of slaves etc. In the Lewis collection are documents relating to free blacks, 1814-18.
(McGregor Library Acc. 2988)
Guide available at http://ead.lib.virginia.edu/vivaead/published/uva-sc/vivadoc.pl?file=viu03024.xml

div2.head: 621. BOOKER T. WASHINGTON COLLECTION
div2.p:
4 items, 1901-4
Letters and one autograph of this African American leader and educator.
(Barrett Library Acc. 8337)

div2.head: 622. WATSON FAMILY PAPERS
div2.p:
ca. 10,000 items, ca. 1760-1890
Correspondence, business and personal, ledger books, bank books, farm account books, and sundry memorandum books of this Louisa County family. This collection is rich in slave material and may prove useful for quantitative approaches to slavery. Many of the journals and the private correspondence refer to slavery and particular slaves. Examples are a May 3, 1768, letter outlining medical treatment for a young male slave; an 1824-50 farm diary describing the division of slaves among the family members and the work performed; an 1858 account book in which pages 32-60 are devoted to a description of the work done by each slave; and an 1866 account book labeled "Freedman Accounts."
(Acc. 530)

div2.head: 622a. JOSEPH WATKINS PAPERS
div2.p:
ca. 300 items, ca. 1763-1852
Business and financial letters and documents of Joseph Watkins of "Janetoe," Goochland, Va. Topics mentioned in Watkins' correspondence include slaves and slave hires; a letter from Thomas Rutherfoord about selling his plantation because of "repugnance to owning Negroes; and a "Slave Song" about a runaway who has escaped to the British during the War of 1812.
(Acc. 11433)
Guide available at http://ead.lib.virginia.edu/vivaead/published/uva-sc/vivadoc.pl?file=viu01225.xml

div2.head: 622b. JOHN WAYLAND CORRESPONDENCE WITH HARRY CLEMONS
div2.p:
2 items, 1954
Wayland, Professor of History at Madison College, Harrisonburg, discusses his own work in the University of Virginia Library, particularly on the Hertz Collection and the papers of Dr. J. L. M. Curry. He reminisces about various professors and librarians including President Alderman, and Bennett Green, and gives his impressions about Harry [Henry] Martin, African American bell-ringer for the University of Virginia, of whom he writes "I came to the conclusion that he was a white man, whatever blood may have run through his veins.
(Acc. 4911)

div2.head: 623. WEAVER-BRADY IRON WORKS AND GRIST MILL PAPERS
div2.p:
ca. 1,500 items, 1824-78
Business papers of William Weaver concerning his mines, furnaces, and forges in Rockbridge, Rockingham, and Botetourt counties. The journal volume for 1830-41 is devoted to accounts for African American workers. The volume for 1859-66 has a record of African Americans vaccinated. A five- volume "Negro Book" for 1839-59 has such items as a "list of boys who came in sick." These volumes present a detailed picture of the use of slave labor in the manufacture of pig and forged iron. The accounts reveal a system of overtime work and compensation for the slave employees. There is brief mention of slave hire in the bound journals and daybooks, and the letterbooks and incoming loose correspondence provide additional detail. Among the loose papers is an 1863 inventory of William Weaver's estate which identifies the slaves owned by him. See also a bound ledger, 1865-72, with contracts and accounts of African Americans who stayed on in various jobs after the Civil War.
(Acc. 38-98)
Guide available at http://ead.lib.virginia.edu/vivaead/published/uva-sc/vivadoc.pl?file=viu00587.xml

div2.head: 624. WEBB-PRENTIS PAPERS
div2.p:
ca. 14,000 items, ca. 1770-1920
Correspondence, notebooks, journals, and manuscripts of these and allied families of the Tidewater area of Virginia. Material on African Americans is generally sparse, but there are intermittent slave sales and wills, such as a valuation and division of slaves belonging to the estate of
Archibald Allen, December 27, 1860, and a 1771 will of John Blair distributing his slaves. There is also a legal memorandum on petit larceny cases for slaves, and a public record lists names and ages of Virginia slaves belonging to the Prentis family.
(Acc. 4136, etc.)
Guide available at http://ead.lib.virginia.edu/vivaead/published/uva-sc/vivadoc.pl?file=viu00272.xml

div2.head: 625. CHARLES C. WELLFORD LETTER
div2.p:
1 item, May 24, 1861
Letter requesting the exemption of plantation overseers from military service.
(Acc. 1663-a)

div2.head: 625a. J. B. WELSH LETTER
div2.p:
1 item, January 18, 1856
Welsh, from Talladega, Alabama, writes to his mother in Madison County, Virginia, describing clearing land with the aid of slaves.
(Acc. 4731)

div2.head: 625b. LOUISE O. WENSEL PAPERS
div2.p:
ca. 335 items, 1958-93
Papers relating to Dr. Louise Wensel's 1958 Virginia senatorial campaign as an independent candidate against Senator Harry F. Byrd. Evident in the papers are Dr. Wensel's opinions concerning the "Byrd machine," massive resistance and the closing of public schools. Dr. Wensel has compiled an account of her candidacy, entitled "Virginia Candidate for the United States Senate in 1958: Defeating Harry Byrd>'s 'Massive Resistance' School-Closing Policy," which includes copies of newspaper articles and typed text written by Wensel. Letters from constituents concern Wensel's platform and their own views on massive resistance and segregation vs. integration in public schools.
(Acc. 11108)
Guide available at http://ead.lib.virginia.edu/vivaead/published/uva-sc/vivadoc.pl?file=viu01379.xml

div2.head: 626. WERTENBAKER FAMILY PAPERS
div2.p:
50 items, 1878-1916
Correspondence, legal papers, genealogical material, photographs, memorabilia, an account book, Masonic bylaws, and an obituary, chiefly pertaining to Dr. Charles P. Wertenbaker, graduate of the University of Virginia Medical School. An August 1, 1891, letter from George Wertenbaker to his brother tells of the drowning of a African American boy in the old university reservoir (August 1, 1891).
(Acc. 10619-a)
Guide available at http://ead.lib.virginia.edu/vivaead/published/uva-sc/vivadoc.pl?file=viu03797.xml

div2.head: 627. CHARLES P. WERTENBAKER PAPERS
div2.p:
ca. 1,000 items, ca. 1890-1915
Business and personal correspondence of this Charlottesville native while he was in the U.S. Public Health Service. Included is correspondence concerning tuberculosis among southern African Americans.
(Acc. 3619)

div2.head: 628. WEST INDIAN TRAVEL JOURNAL
div2.p:
1 item, 1800- 1801
A narrative by a Virginian, Robert Fisher, of his attempt to establish an ice market in the West Indies. There are a few references to African Americans, including his description of a African American man who piloted the vessel into Kingston and his general discussion of the loose morals of Jamaican white men and how they took mulatto women for concubines.
(McGregor Library Acc. 3863)

div2.head: 629. SAMUEL WHITCOMB DOCUMENT
div2.p:
1 item, 1824
An interview with Thomas Jefferson on slavery and other subjects.
(Acc. 2816)

div2.head: 630. WHITE FAMILY PAPERS
div2.p:
1,190 items, 1794-1921
Correspondence and financial and legal papers of the White and related Robertson families of Abingdon. The collection contains the business papers, 1807-38, of James White, lessor and operator of the King saltworks, Saltville, Washington County. There are also papers about cotton shipments and from the settlement of White's estate, 1838-78, including slave and land inventories and a record of property divisions.
(Acc. 9372-b)
Guide available at http://ead.lib.virginia.edu/vivaead/published/uva-sc/vivadoc.pl?file=viu00730.xml

div2.head: 631. FLOYD L. WHITEHEAD PAPERS
div2.p:
48 items, 1820-1900
Personal and business papers of this Nelson County resident. A temperance petition to the Nelson County court protests the selling of liquor and attributes unrest and rebellion among slaves to liquor. There is a March 14, 1837, letter from Milo Morris, apparently a slave of the Whiteheads who had the authority to buy and sell slaves, to "My Dear Master" (Floyd Whitehead). A May 15, 1839, letter from Robert Rives to Whitehead asks that Morris be kept away from Rives's slaves.
(Acc. 8712, a-d)

div2.head: 631a. ROBERT WHITEHEAD PAPERS
div2.p:
ca. 20,000 items, 1942-60
Papers of Robert Whitehead, Member of the Virginia House of Delegates representing Amherst and Nelson Counties, includes discussion of education legislation, Virginia state finances, the Democratic party, and civil rights, among other topics. There are folders entitled Negro Suffrage, Negro-Richmond voting, Negro Education and Civil Rights.
(Acc. 6409)
Guide available at http://ead.lib.virginia.edu/vivaead/published/uva-sc/viu03507.xml.frame

div2.head: 632. JOHN S. WHITTLE PAPERS
div2.p:
2 items, 1838-41
Diary kept by Whittle, a Virginian, of an expedition to the Pacific islands in 1838 which mentions the sighting of a British slave ship. His comments on the natives of the various island groups reflect his racial attitudes.
(Acc. 3227)

div2.head: 632a. J. WILDER LETTER
div2.p:
1 item, June 14, 1891
J. Wilder? to T. H. Canfield?, Bristol, re the lynching of a African American man in the city and his own experience with mob justice. He discusses in detail his belief that the local government is corrupt.
(Acc. 10961)

div2.head: 633. WILL OF MANUMISSION
div2.p:
1 item, September 3, 1846
The will of Mrs. Elizabeth Carter of King George County emancipating her three slaves Jack, Winnie, and Payne.
(Acc. 5678)

div2.head: 634. JAMES PETER WILLIAMS PAPERS
div2.p:
ca. 700 items, 1854-89
Primarily the personal Civil War letters of this Confederate soldier, who infrequently mentioned African Americans. A May 8, 1861, letter to his sister discusses African Americans throwing up breastworks.
(Acc. 490)

div2.head: 634a. WILLIAMS FAMILY PAPERS
div2.p:
ca. 12,000 items, 1798-1987
Correspondence, financial and legal papers, photographs, newsclippings, genealogical material, miscellaneous writings and related materials chiefly concerning the Williams family of Orange County and other Virginia locales, especially Lewis Catlett Williams, a Richmond lawyer and his son, Murat Willis Williams, United States ambassador to El Salvador. Included in the early correspondence is material on slaves and slavery such as an April 23, 1805 letter briefly discussing mortgaging slaves.
(Acc. 10724)
Guide available at http://ead.lib.virginia.edu/vivaead/published/uva-sc/vivadoc.pl?file=viu01738.xml

div2.head: 635. WILLIS FAMILY PAPERS
div2.p:
ca. 180 items, ca. 1760-1890, microfilm (M-2107)
Personal and business papers of this Wilkes County, Georgia, family. Included are a number of slavery documents, such as bills of sale; an August 27, 1830, power of attorney for the purpose of catching and returning a runaway slave; and a January 1861 list of slaves; a deed, 1773, for Gloucester County slaves and land; a 1789 court decision settled partially through transfer of slaves; and a 1791 case involving a runaway slave.
(Acc. 8304-a)

div2.head: 636. WILSON, WHITEHEAD, AND HOUSTON FAMILY PAPERS
div2.p:
21 items, 1831-65
Personal, business, and legal papers of these Rockbridge County families. An 1840 letter from Jesse Scott to Thomas Wilson complains that the slaves had not milked the cows clean; a September 11, 1856, letter from James Whitehead in the Kansas territory states that "we met the pro-slavery army"; and a May 6, 1861, letter from N. [Willson] of Troy, N.Y., to E[liza Wilson] of Rockbridge County, expresses the author's views on slavery and the danger from bands of African Americans during the war.
(Acc. 38-490)

div2.head: 637. SUSAN COLSTON WILSON PAPERS
div2.p:
ca. 1,000 items, 1895-1960
Personal, financial, and legal correspondence of the Minor family of Charlottesville and the Wilson family of New Jersey. Included are photographs of Afro-Americans who were servants for the Minor family.
(Acc. 10489)

div2.head: 638. WILLIAM WILSON PAPERS
div2.p:
7 items, 1791-93
Seven letters written by this Fredericksburg resident to Benjamin James in Charleston, South Carolina. In a January 18, 1793, letter, Wilson told of selling a slave to alleviate financial distress.
(Acc. 9994)

div2.head: 638a. WINFIELD-BAILEY-MASON-JARRATT FAMILIES PAPERS
div2.p:
100 items, 1782-1950
This collection contains promissory notes, receipts, licenses to work a still, bill of sale for slaves, wills, deeds, and letters of these families in Sussex County, Virginia. The principal family members are: William Winfield, Edward P. Bailey, John T. J. Mason, William H. Mason, John A. Winfield, William Wren, Anthony Mason, George W. Bailey, Edmund Bailey, and W. N. Jarratt.
(Acc. 4102)

div2.head: 639. ROBERT N. WINDSOR PAPERS
div2.p:
3 items, 1839-45
Two of the letters concern Windsor's 1839 shipment of slaves for another individual.
(Acc. 2867)

div2.head: 640. WINFIELD FAMILY PAPERS
div2.p:
7 items, 1797-1894
Business and legal documents of a Sussex County family. Included are a bill of sale for a young male slave and an 1862 estate inventory listing slaves and their valuation.
(Acc. 8509)

div2.head: 641. WINSTON AND DICKINSON FAMILY PAPERS
div2.p:
4 items, 1830-50
Bible records of these Louisa County families, including slave birth and death records. There is a copy of an 1851 letter to W. Winston from a member of the American Colonization Society about the shipping of manumitted slaves to Liberia.
(Acc. 4762)

div2.head: 641a. THEODORE WINTHROP COLLECTION
div2.p:
10 items, 1856-1877
Letters and documents of this American author and aide de camp to General Benjamin F. Butler. Included is a letter dated May 31, 1861 from Winthrop to Laura Winthrop Johnson writing of an incident in Washington while he was visiting General Butler and they were met by a Virginia slave owner who demanded the return of his runway slaves.
(Barrett Library acc. 8551)

div2.head: 641b. WISE COUNTY PHOTOGRAPH ALBUMS
div2.p:
2 items, 1890-1998
Two bound photograph albums containing 96 sepia-tone albumen prints (19 x 24 cm), ca. 1890, of scenes in Wise County, Virginia, primarily in the immediate vicinity of Big Stone Gap and Stonega. Included are a number of photographs of people, both individuals and groups, and including African-Americans.
(Acc. 11074)
Guide available at http://ead.lib.virginia.edu/vivaead/published/uva-sc/vivadoc.pl?file=viu01491.xml

div2.head: 642. WISE FAMILY PAPERS
div2.p:
ca. 200 items, ca. 1740-1890, microfilm (M-1313)
Business and personal letters of John Wise of Bath County. Some references to slavery are included, such as a November 23, 1835, letter of John Wise to his son Henry, in which he related the necessity of selling a slave, Jane, and her subsequent attempt to burn down the place, and a deed of sale for a slave named Fleming in December 24, 1835.
(Acc. 6741)

div2.head: 643. HENRY ALEXANDER WISE LETTER
div2.p:
1 item, October 31, 1846
A letter concerning the possibility that the ship Frederica was engaged in the slave trade.
(Acc. 7939)

div2.head: 643a. HARRY WOODING PAPERS
div2.p:
ca. 2000 items, 1892-1938
Personal papers of the Mayor of Danville, Va., from 1892-1938 including newspaper clippings, speeches, materials on his service with the Confederate Army. Included is a petition, ca. 1917, from "the colored citizenry" of Danville protesting a production of Birth of a Nation in town.
(Acc. 598)

div2.head: 644. MICAJAH WOODS PAPERS
div2.p:
ca. 750 items, 1836-1926
Personal correspondence of this Albemarle County resident and his family. Much of the correspondence was during the Civil War years and contains many references to slaves. A December 17, 1864, letter mentions that Edmonia had run away to the Yankees with household goods; a July 2, 1863, letter mentions the effect of the escape of a slave named Henry on the rest of the slaves; a letter of July 2, 1863, describes Henry's capture and the resolve to sell him south.
(Acc. 10279)
Guide available at http://ead.lib.virginia.edu/vivaead/published/uva-sc/vivadoc.pl?file=viu00001.xml

div2.head: 645. WORKS PROJECTS ADMINISTRATION FOLKLORE COLLECTION
div2.p:
ca. 6,500 items, 1930-40
Copies of the records kept by workers in the WPA Folklore project. Of special interest are the ex-slave narratives and many interviews concerning African American folklore. Readers should consult the published guide to the collection, An Annotated Listing of Folklore Collected by Workers of the Virginia Writers' Project, Works Project Administration: Held in the Manuscripts Department at Alderman Library of the University of Virginia (Norwood Pa.: Norwood Editions, 1979), compiled and edited by Charles L. Perdue, Jr., Thomas E. Barden, and Robert K. Phillips.
(Acc. 1547)

div2.head: 645a. WORLD WAR II PHOTOGRAPH COLLECTION
div2.p:
ca. 8000 items, ca. 1941-44
World War II photographs from the Office of War Information and its predecessor Office for Emergency Management. The photographs chiefly record activities on the home front. Virginia scenes include the Shenandoah Valley, Forts Story, Belvoir, Monroe and Meyer; Langley Air Field; day care in Alexandria and youth in Roanoke. Of interest are photographs of African-American Workers labelled "Negro Aircraft Propeller Workers," "Negro Arsenal Workers," "Negro Bomber Plant Workers," "Negro Navy Yard/Shipyard Workers," "Negro Steel Workers," and "Miscellaneous Jobs--barber, lab tech, postman, lawyer, sculpture student--in New York."
(Acc. 8654)
Guide available at http://ead.lib.virginia.edu/vivaead/published/uva-sc/vivadoc.pl?file=viu02221.xml

div2.head: 646. RALPH WORMELEY LETTERBOOK
div2.p:
1 item, 1763-1802
Contains 200 business, legal, and personal letters of Ralph Wormeley of Rosegill, Middlesex County, mainly with merchants and political leaders. There are a few remarks about buying and selling slaves.
(Acc 1939)

div2.head: 647. WRIGHT FAMILY PAPERS
div2.p:
16 items, 1839-89
A small collection of personal papers of Dr. William Wright of Amherst County. A letter of December 1845 from Macon County, N.C., to William Wright informs him that the writer was quite happy with a slave [Jourdin?] received from him and that Jourdin sent his regards to all, "both white and black." Also a letter of November 10, 1847, from Sheldon Wright to Dr. William Wright notes that Sheldon had sold his slave Nancy and her children for $740; he could have received a higher price if he had separated them, but he chose not to.
(Acc. 3824)

div2.head: 647a. JOHN COOK WYLIE RESEARCH PAPERS
div2.p:
1000 items, 1777-1967
Research files compiled by John Cook Wyllie former Librarian of the University of Virginia. Of particular interest is his research on the Hemings family connection with Thomas Jefferson which includes an extract from the Virginia "Recorder" 1801 September 2 containing James Callender's accusation; a copy of the autobiography of Madison Hemings from the Pike County "Republican" 1873 March 13; a mimeograph copy of Douglass Adair's "The Jefferson Scandals"; an obituary for Cornelia Durnley Garrett, former Albemarle County slave; and genealogical charts of Jefferson family slaves.
(Acc. 8880-n)

div2.head: 647b. YANCEY FAMILY PAPERS
div2.p:
ca. 1000 items, ca. 1899-1953
Papers relating to the Esmont Colored School, Benjamin Franklin Yancey d. 1915 and to the Yancey family of Albemarle County, Virginia, ca. 1899, 1904-1953. These papers include letters, photographs, school registers and records, and news clippings. Benjamin Franklin Yancey was the founder and principal of a one-room school for African-American children called the Esmont Colored School, Scottsville, Virginia. His daughter, May Yancey, also taught there in the decades following her father's death and her graduation from college.
(Acc. 11599)
Guide available at http://ead.lib.virginia.edu/vivaead/published/uva-sc/vivadoc.pl?file=viu01220.xml
Transcriptions of letters available at http://jefferson.village.virginia.edu:8065/saxon/servlet/SaxonServlet?source=/vcdh/xml_docs/yancey/all.xml&style=/vcdh/xml_docs/yancey/all.xsl&level=intro

div2.head: 648. YANCY FAMILY PAPERS
div2.p:
ca. 50 items, ca. 1780-1860
Legal and financial papers of this Culpeper County family. Included are an 1855 slave bill of sale, an 1848 will mentioning disposition of slaves, and an 1824 doctor's bill which includes treatment of slaves in Culpeper County.
(Acc. 10094)

div2.head: 649. YANKEE SCHOOL MARMS IN CHARLOTTESVILLE
div2.p:
1 item, 1952
A monograph read before the Albemarle County Historical Society by Joseph Vance discusses work among the freedmen by Anna Gardner and Philena Carkin, whom he mistakenly calls Philenae Caskie. Vance credits Gardner and Carkin with "creating race antagonism in Albemarle, where little if any had previously existed."
(Acc. 4513)

div1.head: THE VALENTINE MUSEUM

address.addrLine:
The Valentine Museum
1015 East Clay Street
Richmond, VA 23219
804-649-0711
Fax: 804-643-3510

div1.p: A special collecting interest of the Valentine Museum has been in the photographic field. Two works detail a major part of the photographic collections: Shadows in Silver (New York: Charles Scribner's Sons, 1954) and "Don't Grieve after Me": The Black Experience in Virginia 1619-1986 (Hampton University, 1986).

div2.head: 650. JOHN JASPER LETTER
div2.p:
1 item, 1869
A letter from this Afro-American preacher to an unknown recipient concerning the preaching of Jasper's sermon about the rotation of the sun.
(Acc. V 86.60.1)

div2.head: 651. LAWSON NUNNALLY PAPERS
div2.p:
95 items, 1765-1923
Correspondence, accounts, and other legal and financial documents of this Richmond banker, primarily concerning his position as trustee for various estates. Several letters and documents pertain to the hire and sale of slaves.
(Acc. MS. C 56)

div2.head: 652. "PRECINCT RECORD OF COLORED VOTERS"
div2.p:
1 item, May 12, 1891-November 1891
A ledger with entries for voters' name, address, and occupation. It is tentatively identified as a Henrico County document.
(Acc. MS. FB 83)

div2.head: 653. PRINTS AND PHOTOGRAPHS COLLECTION
div2.p:
ca. 1,000 items,mid-nineteenth century to present
Many photographs and prints of Afro-Americans and Afro-American scenes are included in subject files under "People" (subheadings, "Negroes" and "Children"), "Agriculture," "Business-tobacco, "Cabins," and "Transportation." Prints and photographs of individual Afro-Americans, including John Jasper and Gilbert Hunt, are filed under their names.

div2.head: 654. RICHMOND COMMUNITY INTERVIEWS
div2.p:
ca. 15 items, 1985
Video tapes of a number of Richmond residents in connection with a project concerning race relations. Included are tapes of interviews with Virginius Dabney, Elise Richmond, Benjamin Lambert, Oliver Hill, William Hill, Ruth Poindexter, Samuel Tucker, Henry Marsh, and Douglas Wilder.

div2.head: 655. INDEPENDENT ORDER OF ST. LUKE
div2.p:
304 items, 1877-1986
Records including constitutions, financial reports, order rituals, annual meeting papers, and minutes of this Afro-American fraternal organization created to provide for the sick and aged and burial expenses. It later became a business organization which included an insurance company and bank.
(Acc. MS. C 64)

div2.head: 656. SEDGWICK AND MUSSEN FAMILY PAPERS
div2.p:
176 items, 1846-1903
Letters, business papers, and documents relating to these families who migrated to Virginia from Ireland in the early nineteenth century. Over 100 documents concern John R. Sedgwick's purchase and sale of slaves from 1856 to 1863 in Mobile, Alabama, North Carolina, Virginia, and Richmond.
(Acc. MS. C 7)

div2.head: 657. PEYTON SKIPWITH PAPERS
div2.p:
ca. 50 items, 1763-1852
Business and legal correspondence of Sir Peyton Skipwith of Prestwould, Mecklenburg County. The plantation records refer to slaves.
(Acc. MS. C 8)

div2.head: 658. CHARLES SOMMA PAPERS
div2.p:
ca. 3,000 items, 1920-39
Primarily business papers of this Richmond theater owner. Contains records of business dealings with film companies and live acts for performances at the Byrd Theater and the Hippodrome in Jackson Ward. Included is material on black entertainers and films.
(Acc. MS. C 55)

div2.head: 659. CHARLES TALBOTT PAPERS
div2.p:
105 items, 1842-1883
Business and legal papers of this Richmond manufacturer including receipts for the sale of slaves.
(Acc. MS. C 10)

div2.head: 660. MAYOR JOSEPH TATE DOCKET
div2.p:
1 item, 1836-39
The private docket of this Richmond mayor, with many entries concerning slaves and free blacks.
(Acc. MS. B75)

div2.head: 661. TAZEWELL and NORTON DAYBOOK
div2.p:
1 item, 1819-23
Medical daybook of Richmond-area doctors William Tazewell and Daniel Norton, with entries for the medical treatment of slaves.
(Acc. MS. FB 14)

div2.head: 662. TYNDALL, ALLBERGER, AND VAN HORN FAMILY, PAPERS
div2.p:
123 items, 1831-90
Legal, business, and personal papers of Mrs. Frances Tyndall, her son Mark Anthony Tyndall, and her daughter Frances K. Tyndall Van Horn. Included are four receipts for slaves bought by Mark A. and Frances K. Tyndall.
(Acc. MS. C 51)
